headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta Q4 2015 and Full Year Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, to this conference being recorded. I would now look to introduce your host for today's conference call, Mr. Wa
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta Q4 2015 and Full Year Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, to this conference being recorded. I would now look to introduce your host for today's conference call, Mr. Ward Nye, Chairman, President and CEO. You may begin, sir.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us for Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. To facilitate the discussion, we've made available during this webcast and on our website supplemen
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us for Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. To facilitate the discussion, we've made available during this webcast and on our website supplemental financial information, which we believe will be helpful. As detail specifically on Slide 2, please remember that today's teleconference may include forward-looking statements as defined by securities laws in connection with future events or future operating and financial performance. Like other businesses, we're subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause actual results to differ materially. Except as legally required, we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements whether resulting from new information, future developments or otherwise. We refer you to the legal disclaimers contained in our fourth quarter and full year earnings release and other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are available on both our own and the SEC websites. Also as a reminder, any margin references in our discussion are based on net sales and exclude freight and delivery revenue. These, and other non-GAAP measures are also explained in our supplemental financial information as well as on our website and in our SEC filings. 
Upon leveraging the full year of [indiscernible] TXI operations with our heritage business, 2015 enters the books as a record year. Specifically, we achieved record safety results, record net sales and profitability, expanded consolidated gross profit margin, exceeded incremental margin targets for the consolidated heritage business, exceeded acquisition synergies targets in both dollars and time line, invested capital in our business, completed several bolt-on acquisitions and returned nearly $630 million [ph] to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. These impressive results we achieved with both tailwinds and headwinds. 
The tailwinds. 2015 construction markets experienced continued growth in private activity led by housing as well as the emergence of enhanced public sector activity as best revealed by a 7% [ph] increase in highway construction. Nonetheless, we had a very significant headwind as 2015 saw unprecedented amounts of precipitation in our core states of Texas, North Carolina, Iowa, Georgia and Colorado, disproportionately impacting second and fourth quarter performance. By some estimates, and indeed our own calculation and internal plans, multiple sustained extraordinary weather events combined with the downturn in energy sector shale development likely cost us up to $200 million in sales for the year, masking the underlying strength of general construction. That underlying strength is revealed in the solid growth we see across our business with the market acceleration of the construction recovery in key Southeastern markets, fueled by steady employment growth, continued private sector activity and expanded Department of Transportation programs. We thus entered 2016 with what we believe are very favorable market and operating tailwinds, building upon our teams record 2015 results. This past results and future opportunities are tied to our strict and steadfast attention to cost discipline, further underscoring the positive result of years of improving our operating efficiency. We're also specifically very proud of our 2015 record safety performance, a core foundational pillar of our company. We concluded 2015 with incident rates better than what had been 2014's then record results. Notably, we continue to see dramatic improvement in the safety numbers of the former TXI operations, further underscoring our successful operational and cultural integration. Safety is first at Martin Marietta. In December, we completed construction of our state-of-the-art Medina Rock and rail quarry near San Antonio, Texas. Shipments from Medina now are expected to replace rail shipments from our Beckmann Quarry, as a transition from a distance rail and truck-serve quarrying to wholly focusing on the local San Antonio marketplace. The Medina job was on time and on budget. The construction of $160 million facility spanned 3 years is the largest and most complex capital project in the company's history and is now the largest quarry on the Union Pacific Railroad's fast network. Medina began operation in January 2016, and we expect to ship nearly 6 million tons of aggregates this year. 
As highlighted in today's press release, we continue to execute against our strategic objective of securing and solidifying [indiscernible] in Colorado Springs. These 2 bolt-on transactions complement our position in Metro Denver and Northern Colorado, a position we originally acquired in 2011 with our river for the Rockies asset exchange, and provide attractive in leading positions along the Front Range of the Rocky Mountains, home to over 80% of Colorado's population. Following these recent transactions, we've added an estimated 1 billion tons of aggregates reserves. Strategically, 4 years ago we've had no Front Range position whatsoever. Today, we are marketplace leader with nearly 100 years of high-quality construction aggregates in a region with near- and long-term favorable employment and demographic conditions. 
Turning to the fourth quarter performance. We established quarterly records for net sales and profitability driven by strong pricing, disciplined execution of our strategic plan and steady growth in construction activity. Importantly, all segments in the aggregates business delivered
[Audio Gap]
grew with a 630 basis point improvement, largely resulting from strong pricing and realized TXI synergies. As shown on Slide 7, through the end of 2015, we've realized approximately $100 million of our $120 million synergy target, reflected in both the acquired business and heritage West Group performance. We are on track to fully realize our $120 million synergy target by the end of this year. 
On a more granular basis, our 2015 record results were driven by strong pricing across our aggregates, aggregates-related and Cement businesses, shown on Slide 8. Notably, the heritage aggregates product line delivered an increase of more than 7% in average selling price, while heritage ready-mixed concrete prices increased nearly 10%. The acquired businesses, aggregates, ready-mixed concrete and cement, saw a price increases of 13%, nearly 11% and 10%, respectively, in line with our stated objectives. For the year, heritage aggregates product line volume increased 2% and total aggregates product line volume increased 7%. This is again despite record or near record occurring precipitation in 5 of our largest states. 
The Southeast and the Mid-America Groupies led volume growth on the strength of recovery in Georgia, Florida and the Carolinas. The West Group, which was most affected by the adverse weather conditions, reported an increase in aggregates volume of 1.2%, excluding TXI-related divestitures, which affect comparability with the prior year. Aggregates volume growth for the year was notable in North Texas, but was somewhat offset by declines in directional energy aggregate shipments in South Texas. 
Volumes grew across all product lines with the exception of asphalt, where our Texas divestiture in the fourth quarter affected year-over-year comparability. Of note, asphalt margins expanded to 28% or just over 1,000 basis points, clearly reflecting improved profitability in our core Colorado asphalt business. Consolidated gross profit margin was 22% and expanded by 260 basis points for the year, led by margin expansion in all construction materials related segments. Gross profit for the heritage aggregates business increased $130 million over the prior year, with margins expanding 480 basis points to 23.8% [ph] of net sales the incremental gross margin for the heritage aggregates business exceeded targeted objectives for both the fourth quarter and full year 2015. The incremental gross margin of 82% for the full year 2015 was led by growth in both the West Group and the Southeast Group, which achieved incremental gross margin of 100
[Audio Gap]
the acquired businesses gross profit margin also expanded 300 basis points in 2015, led by acquired aggregates product line gross profit margin of nearly 27%, up from 4.6% for the comparable prior year period, reflecting synergy realization and underlying strength in both volume and pricing. Due to the September 2015 sale of our California Cement business, quarterly results for the Cement segments are not comparable to the prior year period. And in fact, comparability will be affected throughout 2016. Quarterly details for the Cement business can be found on Slide 9 for elimination of the California results. However, for the remaining Cement business has benefited from Martin Marietta's significant pricing improvement in 2015. 
Average selling prices increased 10%, aided partly by the expiration of legacy TXI Cement contracts at below-market pricing and the divestiture of the California business. For the year, the business generated $368 million in net sales and delivered a 28% gross profit margin, a 310 basis point improvement over the prior year. 
EBITDA for the business was $101 million, a $30 million increase. 
The Magnesia Specialties business was negatively affected by a slowdown in the steel industry in 2015. Steel capacity utilization was down from approximately 78% in 2014 to 71% in 2015. Full year net sales were $228 million, a decline of $9 million or 4% compared to the prior year. The Magnesia Specialty's team diligently managed the cost profile of the business during the year and despite steel capacity utilization declines delivered an impressive 35% gross profit margin. 
On a consolidated basis, 2015 delivered record net sales of $3.3 billion, an increase of $589 million or 22%; record gross profit of $722 million, an increase of $199 million or 38%, record net earnings of $289 million, an increase of 86% and record adjusted EBITDA of $766.7 million, an increase of 30%. The significant improvement in net earnings coupled with the absence of TXI-related costs, further increase in operating cash flow in 2015 to $573 million compared with $382 million in 2014. Operating cash flow per share of $8.55 improved 8% [ph] when compared to adjusted 2014, which excludes the cash impact of TXI-related expenses. 
We invested $318 million of capital during the year, including $78 million related to the new Medina Rock quarry. For the year, we returned nearly $630 million to our shareholders through the combination of repurchasing 3.3 million shares of our common stock, together with our dividend. As a reminder, we have board authorization to repurchase up to 20 million shares. Finally, our ratio of consolidated net debt to consolidated EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ended December 2015 was 1.9x, in compliance with our leverage covenant and below our target leverage of 2x. 
In summary, 2015 was a remarkable year for Martin Marietta. And despite being tempered by extraordinary weather that cloaked our true earnings potential, our team is poised for an even stronger 2016. We are confident we have the foundation in place for improved growth, profitability and performance. 
We will now look to the future and discuss our 2016 outlook, which we highlight on Slides 11 through 13. Initially, you'll notice an improvement in our expected growth as compared to our very early thoughts provided in third quarter 2015. Our 2016 outlook now reflects growing underlying demand and strong pricing across our entire geographic footprint. National employment growth, a stimulus for construction activity, remained robust in 2015, surpassing the prerecession peak by nearly 5 million jobs. These job gains, in addition to contractor backlogs, which resulting from [indiscernible] 2015 rainfall, should fuel growth and further recovery of the U.S. construction industry in 2016 and beyond. Public sector growth is expected to drive mid-single-digit volume increases in our infrastructure business, which accounted for 41% of our aggregates demand in 2015. The growth reflects continued state-level funding initiatives that are positively impacting several of our key states, including Texas, North Carolina, Iowa, Georgia and Florida. For example, in Texas, nearly $10 billion through Department of Transportation lettings are planned, up from $6.1 billion in 2015. Dallas-Fort Worth alone is the beneficiary of 4 major design build projects aimed at mitigating areas congestion and improving traffic flow. There's also significant and continuing infrastructure work in and around Houston. Additional evidence of state-level infrastructure investment tailwinds is revealed by recent project scheduling changes announced by the North Carolina Department of Transportation or NCDOT. Specifically, after the passage last year of various new state funding initiatives, NCDOT announced an accelerated schedule for 90 [ph] Highway projects. This example is consistent with our [indiscernible] expectations around state construction project backlog. 
In addition to state-level initiatives, we now have the 5-year, $305 billion Fixing America's Surface Transportation Act or FAST Act. Enacted in December 2015 to provide states with the required funding certainty for the first time in nearly a decade to commit to a backlog of longer-term projects needed to improve and expand America's transportation network. We believe the FAST Act, along with state-level funding initiatives, will drive large, multiyear, aggregate-intensive construction projects. Further, it's also likely we will see meaningful projects in rural areas that had been infrastructure-starved during the last decade and will now be better able to develop new avenues for growth and commerce. 
Shipments to nonresidential construction projects, 32% of our 2015 demand, is expected to increase in both the heavy, industrial and light commercial sectors, leading to an increase in aggregates volume in the high single digits. The light nonresidential construction sector is primarily opposite retail, with demand generally tied to employment growth and residential activity. Notably, the Dodge momentum index is near its highest level since 2009, signaling continued growth. Further, core Martin Marietta's states account for 5 of the top 10 and 9 of the top 20 in state-level employment growth, including Florida, Texas, Georgia, North Carolina, Ohio, Indiana, South Carolina, Virginia and Colorado. All positive catalysts for construction activity. The heavy nonresidential construction sector is primarily industrial building as well as energy and energy-related activity. We are currently supplying several large energy-related industrial and infrastructure projects along the Gulf Coast and expect our project backlog to grow, thus largely offsetting the decline in direct shale exploration activity. We believe that direct shale activity will reach a maintenance level in the fourth quarter of 2015 and should sustain at that level throughout 2016. Of course, results for the first and second quarters of last year reflected higher than maintenance level consumption and are expected to affect our comparability to the first half 2016 results. The residential end-use market accounted for 17% of aggregate shipments in 2015 and increased 20% as compared to 2014. We expect a double-digit volume increase again in 2016, reflecting the continued steady recovery of residential investment as a result of positive employment gains, historically low mortgage rates, significant [indiscernible] absorption and higher multifamily rental rates. New housing permit activity was up 12% in 2015, indicating future gains in housing construction. Importantly, Texas, Florida, Colorado, Georgia and North Carolina each ranked in the top 10 states for housing starts. 
Finally, to conclude our discussion of 2015 end-use markets, the ChemRock rail market represented the remaining 10% of aggregates volume is expected to remain relatively flat to modestly down in 2016. 
We'll now focus on Texas, where we continue to be encouraged by the resilience of the broader marketplace. In short, we anticipate increasing overall demand driven by solid population and employment growth. Construction activity in our larger volume markets principally being the vibrant corridor of Dallas, San Antonio, Austin is expected to grow throughout 2016 and beyond led by multiyear infrastructure activity, a strong residential marketplace and solid nonresidential construction. South Texas, of course, has seen a decline in shale oilfield activity, thus reducing our direct shipments by
[Audio Gap]
In late 2016 or early 2017, we'll open a new aggregates facility on Martin Marietta-owned property at the Hunter Cement plant northeast of San Antonio. This undertaking will allow us to transition from our leased and nearly depleted new Brownfields quarry only 10 miles away to a permanent location with over 400 million tons of quality aggregate materials providing improved access to local markets. The Hunter aggregates quarry will be an additional synergy from the TXI acquisition that will benefit our company in 2017 and beyond. 
Our expectations for 2016 volume levels in Houston have moderated from 2015 [ph] levels where we saw an 11% increase in aggregate shipments. We now expect aggregate volume in that marketplace to be broadly flat with any potential upside being spurred by large infrastructure projects and any downside being driven by a sharper deterioration in the used in Houston economy. That said, it's important to remember that our principal Texas markets are located in North and Central Texas and not materially impacted by Houston market conditions. The Portland Cement Association or PCA forecast modest demand growth in Texas in 2016 followed by stronger growth in 2017. We currently expect 2016 cement volume to increase 8% to 11%. We previously announced a cement price increase to $12 per ton effective April 1, 2016. Based on the expected flow of shipments, we'll likely realize a year-over-year average selling price increase of approximately 9%. Both volume and price growth forecasts exclude the 2015 results of the divested California Cement business. Profitability is forecast to increase by an estimated $30 million in 2016. 
On a consolidated basis, 2016 is expected to deliver record-setting results, including net sales ranging from $3.5 billion to $3.7 billion expanded gross profit and expanded EBITDA. As we've consistently stated, our capital allocation priorities remain unchanged. They are investing in aggregates-led acquisitions, organic capital investment to ensure safe, environmentally-sound and highly-efficient operations and returning cash to shareholders in the form of a sustainable, meaningful dividend and share repurchases under our existing authority. 
To conclude, we're optimistic and excited about 2016. We entered the year with an enhanced foundation for further growth and outlook for improved business conditions across the vast majority of our markets, led by solid private sector construction activity and a newly reinvigorated public sector. Our team remains focused on the careful execution of our strategic plan, wholly committed to our core foundation of pillars and dedicated to delivering increased shareholder value. 
If the operator will now give the required instructions, we'll turn our attention to answering your questions.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kathryn Thompson with Thompson Research Group.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kathryn Thompson with Thompson Research Group.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first is just on visibility, in general, particularly related to states that have passed new pieces of legislation that should we've already seen a significant increase in tax receipts for infrastructure. But the question I have for you, particularly
componenttext: The first is just on visibility, in general, particularly related to states that have passed new pieces of legislation that should we've already seen a significant increase in tax receipts for infrastructure. But the question I have for you, particularly for Georgia and North Carolina, and given the changes in 2015, have you seen volumes flow through from these legislative initiatives that were passed last year?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kathryn, the short answer is we're going to see it. Think about North Carolina. They basically put in more money at the end of the last year. And to be specific, that was an additional $700 million over 2 years. The other thing that North Carolina has it'
componenttext: Kathryn, the short answer is we're going to see it. Think about North Carolina. They basically put in more money at the end of the last year. And to be specific, that was an additional $700 million over 2 years. The other thing that North Carolina has it's spending that we'll see voted on later on the year is a $2 billion building bond proposal as well. So I think to answer your question very specifically, when our legislature came out with the additional $700 million, we did see the state implementation plan move forward 90 projects in -- up into the year. So we do anticipate seeing that. So yes, we're seeing activity that we believe will take aggregates volume later in the year. And clearly, we're effectively doubling the Georgia budget, adding that additional $900 million to it. We will clearly see amped-up activity in Georgia. Remember, we were going to be benefited, too, by the [indiscernible] planning that was put in principally in South Georgia a couple of years ago. So now what we will see, I believe, is greater activity across the State of Georgia. But you're seeing the activity that we were seeing in South Georgia, increased activity in North Georgia, principally around Atlanta. And we know we'll see more activity in North Carolina as well. I think it's worth noting, Iowa did put in a $0.10 a gallon gas tax increase last year. Nebraska did as well. We're going to see the benefits of Prop 1 [ph] money in Texas, and we're seeing near-record lettings in Florida this year. So we're seeing new money in a number of states, and we think we see more money coming in a number of states, including states like Indiana, where Governor basically said he'd like to see another $1 billion worth of infrastructure in that state. And we've got 12 different states right now seriously considering gas tax increases in addition to what Georgia and Iowa have passed. So that gives you a little bit of a feel of across the patch, Kathryn.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to clarify, so if you look at all these initiatives in aggregate, we are -- are we in the early earnings, middle innings of seeing the dollars flow through? I would assume the early innings, but you're the one in the field seeing the volumes flow
componenttext: And just to clarify, so if you look at all these initiatives in aggregate, we are -- are we in the early earnings, middle innings of seeing the dollars flow through? I would assume the early innings, but you're the one in the field seeing the volumes flow through.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Kathryn, we are in the early innings. And I think part of what you're seeing, too, it's not just early innings. It's early innings of different type of work. Think of it in these terms. For much of the last decade, we have really been living more on p
componenttext: No, Kathryn, we are in the early innings. And I think part of what you're seeing, too, it's not just early innings. It's early innings of different type of work. Think of it in these terms. For much of the last decade, we have really been living more on private work than public work. And private work is not as aggregate-intensive as public work is. And what we're seeing now is a transition away from repair and maintenance of public work to a very different type of public work that I do believe we're in the early innings of. And I think you and I have both the sense that the more that we're building new lanes, the more that we're building new highways or new roads, and the more of these rural parts of the state are looking to add capacity and open up new lanes and corridors for business, that's awfully powerful to our business and I think very, very much aggregate-intensive. So early, yes. More aggregate-intensive, yes.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then next to questions. One, I appreciate your giving some clarification on the -- increasing your end market with projections from Q3. But could you frame the outlook of that account for the relatively large increase or improvement in the diffe
componenttext: Okay. And then next to questions. One, I appreciate your giving some clarification on the -- increasing your end market with projections from Q3. But could you frame the outlook of that account for the relatively large increase or improvement in the difference? And then the final question would be on cement margins. If you could just help us think about -- it does look to be a big jump and maybe help us understand the improvement in Cement margins.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kathryn. Let's talk about the first part of your question first. I think what we're seeing is increased contract backlogs across our entire footprint. We have also seen the awarding of several large energy-related industrial contracts, particularly
componenttext: Sure, Kathryn. Let's talk about the first part of your question first. I think what we're seeing is increased contract backlogs across our entire footprint. We have also seen the awarding of several large energy-related industrial contracts, particularly in -- along the Gulf Coast. I think what we're seeing in the fourth quarter, when it wasn't raining, the fourth quarter looked very powerful. I'll give you a sense of -- I've been in Texas 3 times over the last 1.5 months, and I was there for part of the holidays. And I'm talking to contractors in that marketplace, literally the weaker Christmas was dry, they were saying they were having really record days even at that time of year, which I'll tell you is unusual, but it gives me a sense of what's out there. And the other point I think goes back to the very beginning of the conversation that we had, and that's just simply more accelerated infrastructure activity in our key states. So we're looking at those $10.1 billion worth of activity, potentially in Texas, more in North Carolina, more in Iowa and more in Colorado. And remember what we said about Colorado. The primary thing that was keeping us from doing more in Colorado is we needed more business in Colorado. And now what we've been able to effectively do is extend our march down the Front Range into the southern part of that as well. So I think all of those together has put us in a position that we feel considerably good about the way 2016 is shaping up. I think as we go back to the second part of your question, that is relative to Cement, I think several things are going to happen. One, Cement was badly effected last year by the rain. I mean it's hard to run a cement business which is a 24/7, 365 business, if you need to take it down more than you would wish. And keep in mind, our aim was to be a price leader in that state. And our view was we would rather take those cones down rather than keep them going and do something that we felt that was going to be foolish relative to the selling price in that marketplace. In large part, we believe we can have greater efficiencies in Cement this year, but we also think we're going to see better pricing in Cement this year. We saw a little bit of share movement in our business since Cement. And the fact is, we were willing to see that share movement move because that was really driven by 2 distinct players in the marketplace. Holcim had brought on a cone again that they had idled for a while at Midlothian, and they were coming back into the marketplace. And our goes, as we discussed, was bringing in some material in South Texas. We believe as we go into the year that everybody is likely to be relatively full. We believe we're going to be efficient. We believe we're going to be successful on our price increases. And we think by the time we put all of that in place, we're looking at very nice improvement in the Cement business. And by the way, we're looking for a very nice improvement in the ready-mix business as well. I think those are your principal drivers in Texas.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kathryn, the only thing I would add is that when you look at comparability between 2015 and 2016, you've got to remember the impact of the California operations, which were really still not at any kind of recovery trajectory.
componenttext: Kathryn, the only thing I would add is that when you look at comparability between 2015 and 2016, you've got to remember the impact of the California operations, which were really still not at any kind of recovery trajectory.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Adam Thalhimer with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adam Thalhimer with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask first about incremental margins. You guys had very strong margins in 2015, but your guidance for '16 is in the 55% to 65% range incremental risk margins for aggregates. Is it possible you're being conservative there?
componenttext: I wanted to ask first about incremental margins. You guys had very strong margins in 2015, but your guidance for '16 is in the 55% to 65% range incremental risk margins for aggregates. Is it possible you're being conservative there?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've always said that that was going to be an average. So we're really not changing what we said over time. Clearly, we exceeded it in this last quarter. I think much of what we said in the past is that's what you're going to see on average across the en
componenttext: We've always said that that was going to be an average. So we're really not changing what we said over time. Clearly, we exceeded it in this last quarter. I think much of what we said in the past is that's what you're going to see on average across the enterprise, but we also said it would likely move much more aggressively if you saw growth coming in the eastern part of the United States, particularly in Mid-Atlantic and Southeast. And if you go back to really what some of those numbers look like, they were most impressive. That's what you were seeing. And to answer your question specifically, I think were going to see the Eastern United States, on a percentage basis, growing in ways that we haven't seen over the last several years. That's certainly the indications that we're getting on activity in Georgia and in Florida and in South Carolina and in North Carolina. And I think the quick answer is, Adam, if we see those areas of the country growing the way that we believe that they will, I'll just say this much, the incremental margins will be a nice story again.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I just wanted to ask on your end-market outlook for 2016, the infrastructure piece and the nonres piece improved from what you said in early November. So I just wondered if you could expand on what got better, maybe just stuff that got push
componenttext: Okay. And then I just wanted to ask on your end-market outlook for 2016, the infrastructure piece and the nonres piece improved from what you said in early November. So I just wondered if you could expand on what got better, maybe just stuff that got pushed because of the weather.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, I think several things. Number one, we didn't have a Highway bill when we're talking about it before. So I think the fact that the Highway bill is actually spurring a lot of increased activity. I don't know how much of that is going to fit
componenttext: You know what, I think several things. Number one, we didn't have a Highway bill when we're talking about it before. So I think the fact that the Highway bill is actually spurring a lot of increased activity. I don't know how much of that is going to fit in the early part of '16, but I think you might see some of that actually coming through the back end of '16, which would be earlier than you would typically see. But I think equally, when you come back and consider the significant state initiatives. And again, we saw initiatives coming out of North Carolina late in the year. We're seeing a big Texas number. We're seeing that gas tax increase pull through in ways that we're excited about in Iowa. Again, another record year -- letting year coming up in Florida. I think all of that helps from the infrastructure side, in particular. I think if we go to nonres, I mean here's what -- here's a statistic that's striking to me. Think of it in these terms. Shale volumes were down 1.1 million tons in the quarter, as you heard me say in the telecom. But net South Texas shipments actually increased, and they increased by large infrastructure and large manufacturing projects. And part of what we're seeing in -- on the nonres side is an awfully nice surge in non-building. So I encourage you go and take a look at what's going on in other non-building. Again, power plants, gas, communications. Those types are really very aggregate-intensive [indiscernible] Non-building, looking at the trailing 12 months to November, was up 19%. And a lot of that activity is concentrated in the Gulf. So again, if we're coming back and seeing what we feel like are really, really attractive DOT projects and awfully nonres projects. That helps. The other piece of it, candidly, we saw a lot of projects awarded in the fourth quarter. And one of the things that I'd like to see is at certain levels, is probably frustrating to our division presidents, but we have signed delegations from here to know exactly what they're bidding on. It's not that we don't trust what they're doing. We just like to see the sheer level of that activity, and we saw a lot of that activity in Q4.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Todd Vencil with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Todd Vencil with Sterne Agee.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the release, you guys said that you're nonres market was 32% of your shipments in the fourth quarter was up 3% for the year, and then lightened on resident, 27% a year -- for the year. Can you split out light and heavy in terms of the volume split with
componenttext: In the release, you guys said that you're nonres market was 32% of your shipments in the fourth quarter was up 3% for the year, and then lightened on resident, 27% a year -- for the year. Can you split out light and heavy in terms of the volume split within the quarter and talk about which way each one went in the fourth quarter?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Here's the easy way to think about that, Todd, the primary way I would encourage you to think about on the heavy side is what was going on relative to shale. I mean that's really your show on what was going on on the heavy side. I mean to give you sense o
componenttext: Here's the easy way to think about that, Todd, the primary way I would encourage you to think about on the heavy side is what was going on relative to shale. I mean that's really your show on what was going on on the heavy side. I mean to give you sense of -- the walk-through quarters, in Q1, to shale, we sold about 1.2 million tons. In Q2, to shale, we sold about 1 million. In Q3, to shale, about 830,000. And in Q4, to shale, about 521,000. Remember, in my prepared comments, I said I thought we were getting to maintenance levels. We view that 500,000 tons a quarter. That's a maintenance level. And that goes back in part to the comment that I think I was sharing with Adam before when I've said, "Look, we saw shale volumes down 1.1 million tons in the quarter, but South Texas shipments actually up." So if you go to the one part of the country that would've felt more acutely, the downturn in shale, than anybody else, and you brush it away, and you say "But their goings were up." That gives you a good sense of what's happening on that lighter side of it, Todd, and then back to that non-building piece of it as well. So the resilience that we're seeing there across our marketplace is pretty comforting to us right now. And we're liking what we're seeing. Does that help?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It does. It does. And not to beat a dead horse, but just to make sure clarifying. If you think about the swing factor from the nonres outlook up slightly in the preliminary outlook that you gave back in November to the high single-digit growth that you're
componenttext: It does. It does. And not to beat a dead horse, but just to make sure clarifying. If you think about the swing factor from the nonres outlook up slightly in the preliminary outlook that you gave back in November to the high single-digit growth that you're talking about today, the swing factor seems like that it's not only resilience there on the light side, but also the fact that there were some significant actual contract signings that you saw in the fourth quarter. Is that fair?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very fair. It goes back to the notion that we go back relative to the negotiations. We've been signing a lot of them. And the other thing is, number one, it's what we're seeing. And that's what's most important. Equally, its off a consistent with F
componenttext: That's very fair. It goes back to the notion that we go back relative to the negotiations. We've been signing a lot of them. And the other thing is, number one, it's what we're seeing. And that's what's most important. Equally, its off a consistent with F.W. Dodge is seeing, too. If you look at the latest forecast out which came out on January 26, they're saying nonres up in those same types of percentages that we're talking about. So again, it's nice to see it. It's also nice to go to third parties and say that their data is same thing that our life experience is seeing.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good, good. We like it when those things dovetail.
componenttext: Good, good. We like it when those things dovetail.

componenttext: It's a beautiful thing.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the rain in the fourth quarter -- I think you said this, how many tons do you think got pushed into 2016 from the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Given the rain in the fourth quarter -- I think you said this, how many tons do you think got pushed into 2016 from the fourth quarter?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, Todd, I think -- let's just say for the year, it's probably somewhere between 3.5 million to 4 million tons. I think the vast majority of that obviously being in Texas. I mean there are places in the Midwest, for example, Q4 was wet. And we
componenttext:
You know what, Todd, I think -- let's just say for the year, it's probably somewhere between 3.5 million to 4 million tons. I think the vast majority of that obviously being in Texas. I mean there are places in the Midwest, for example, Q4 was wet. And we've always discussed the fact that agricultural lime can go if it's really cold but doesn't go up if it's really wet. So there's a lot of stone sales, principally North Texas, that got deferred. There was ag line that was deferred in Iowa. And frankly, there were some stone deferral, not to the same degree that we did -- that we saw in Texas, but we certainly saw some in the Carolinas. We mentioned the fact that we're going to quarry outside Columbia that had several billion gallons of water in it. The other piece of our business, though, that was pretty profoundly affected by the rain was ready-mixed concrete. And obviously, Denver was somewhat affected by it. Texas was profoundly affected by it. And the fact
[Audio Gap]
at those margins in Texas like we have in Denver now. We're not looking for that
[Audio Gap]

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't want to get you too far out front, thinking it's a little bit longer term in the highway program and some of the comments you made about being early days and the visibility we have now. Is it fair to think that we may see maybe able to see a picku
componenttext: I don't want to get you too far out front, thinking it's a little bit longer term in the highway program and some of the comments you made about being early days and the visibility we have now. Is it fair to think that we may see maybe able to see a pickup in the growth rate on Highway spending in '17 from '16?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's no question that it's likely that you'll see that. Because again, even in Texas, when we're talking about $10 billion worth of lettings, a lot of that work is going to be really not occurring in some respects until '17. You're still going
componenttext: I think there's no question that it's likely that you'll see that. Because again, even in Texas, when we're talking about $10 billion worth of lettings, a lot of that work is going to be really not occurring in some respects until '17. You're still going to have Prop 1 monies even next year to the tune of probably $600 million or $700 million. And then suddenly, you're going to have the Prop 7 money coming into that. And then North Carolina was put in that extra $700 million over couple of years to it. You're going to continue to have the gas tax hitting what's going on in Iowa. And the other thing that's important is you're seeing a number of TIFIA projects. Let's not forget that while TIFIA is smaller in this new Highway bill, TIFIA isn't going away. If we're simply taking a look at what's going on in Colorado relative to, I think, it was Highway -- Interstate 70 and Interstate 4 70, those are 2 significant TIFIA projects that I think are like $1.7 billion to $2 billion. To your point, I think this can be a good, slow, steady build, one that industry can meet; but two, fills, I think an overhang of serious need for a long time.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ted Grace with Susquehanna.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ted Grace with Susquehanna.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, could you just -- I want to make sure I understood kind of how to think about the 2016 guidance for cement in Texas. I know you talked about feeding some share, to some degree, by design. But are we expecting to recapture all that share i
componenttext: I was wondering, could you just -- I want to make sure I understood kind of how to think about the 2016 guidance for cement in Texas. I know you talked about feeding some share, to some degree, by design. But are we expecting to recapture all that share in 2016? Just want to make sure we appreciate what drives kind of -- the volume guidance that you've framed out.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The fact is our share has moved around a little bit from, call it, the high teens to the low 20s. And the fact is you're talking about 2% or 3% share in that marketplace. The fact is, Ted, we really believe that the pricing in that marketplace is more imp
componenttext: The fact is our share has moved around a little bit from, call it, the high teens to the low 20s. And the fact is you're talking about 2% or 3% share in that marketplace. The fact is, Ted, we really believe that the pricing in that marketplace is more important than the share that we have given in some respect there. The other thing that I've said to people before, we are very good cement operators in that marketplace. And if we need to compete in a way to make sure that we're protecting share, we're certainly willing to do that. But at this point, today, I think we had about a 20.5% market share. That's a reduction of 2 percentage points. To put math to it, it's about 325,000 tons, just to be really granular. And again, I think we've got a good sense of where that breakpoint is between share and price. And our sense has been price has been more important. And I think you can tell, given what we've done relative to the business, that it's certainly shown that. I mean one important thing to remember, though, is weather needs to stabilize. And as it stabilizes, part of what I think is going to happen is the imports, in particular, that were coming at the South Texas that is bringing in would suddenly start to be utilized for their own self-supply. And I think the heavy rain impact state last year and their inability to utilize [indiscernible] supply and going into marketplace differently was part of what we were seeing relative to the volumes and to the share loss, if that helps, Ted.

componenttext: It does. But so just -- when we look at 8% to 11% volume growth, we should think about a large majority of that being underlying growth in the market that you participate in Texas?

componenttext: That's correct. And I would say, in particular, North Texas.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, we said it's going to be $30 million, and the majority of it is likely going to be driven by the price component of it, but we are going to get efficiencies out of that business if we just have normal precipitation in that state that would be p
componenttext: And again, we said it's going to be $30 million, and the majority of it is likely going to be driven by the price component of it, but we are going to get efficiencies out of that business if we just have normal precipitation in that state that would be pretty notable as well. I'm not I've got a specific percentage breakdown on that, but I would say the pricing is going to be more notable in some respects than volume.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the order thing I had to add quickly in terms of the contribution on a volume basis from the Colorado aggregate acquisition, can you just give us a sense of what those are going to bring on in terms of production realized volumes in 2016?
componenttext: Okay. And the order thing I had to add quickly in terms of the contribution on a volume basis from the Colorado aggregate acquisition, can you just give us a sense of what those are going to bring on in terms of production realized volumes in 2016?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll give you a sense of that. We're looking for probably about 1.5 million tons of that business. Again, what we picked up there, Ted, and what we're very careful that we're trying to do, it goes back to what we said out in our store process, our strateg
componenttext: I'll give you a sense of that. We're looking for probably about 1.5 million tons of that business. Again, what we picked up there, Ted, and what we're very careful that we're trying to do, it goes back to what we said out in our store process, our strategic planning. We wanted to make sure we had leading positions in attractive regions. That's what we've done. We wanted to make sure that we were getting generational types of deposits in those areas. That's what we've done with nearly 1 billion tons in that marketplace. Here's an important note for us to consider, because we haven't had a recent talk about this in the past, but actually November, voters in Colorado Springs actually put in a sales and used tax increase of 0.62% to fund road repair and maintenance in that part of the state. We believe that's going to generate about $250 million over 5 years just in Southern Colorado. So when we come back with what we feel like will be about net sales of that business of that $90 million this year, EBITDA margins have probably 17% to 20%, which is below where we would like to see it. It's actually better than the business that we bought in the Rocky Mountains when we acquired it, and we brought it up. With that very capable team that we have in Denver, I don't have any doubt that we will see those percentages move up nicely and move up, I think, in trajectory in a much more quick time frame than they did for us originally in Denver, which, by the way, I don't think anyone ever complained about. So again, call it $90 million in net sales, EBITDA margin, 17%, 20%, probably about 1.5 million tons of ags.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question cames from James Armstrong with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question cames from James Armstrong with Vertical Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first one is, could you help us understand how to get comfortable with the 7% pricing guidance for 2016? Specifically, do you have any contracts in hand that really lead you to believe that the 7% in aggregates is in hand? And could it be -- with the
componenttext: The first one is, could you help us understand how to get comfortable with the 7% pricing guidance for 2016? Specifically, do you have any contracts in hand that really lead you to believe that the 7% in aggregates is in hand? And could it be -- with the type of volume you're talking about, could it be conservative?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, guess what I would say is that, the wonderful thing about pricing story in our industry is, I think, this is held together so remarkably well all the way through a downturn. Our sense has long been that is if we hit an upturn, the pricing s
componenttext: You know what, guess what I would say is that, the wonderful thing about pricing story in our industry is, I think, this is held together so remarkably well all the way through a downturn. Our sense has long been that is if we hit an upturn, the pricing story works even better. I think that's what we're seeing. I think the other thing that I would say is, one of the earlier comments I made was, "We see the Eastern United States recovering now at a faster rate than we've seen for a while. Eastern quarries are higher-priced quarries." So I guess what I would say this to you to answer your question very specifically, James, I don't have any concerns about being able to at least make sure we get our pricing. If I worry about things, if I'd got a worrying list from 1 to 100, I put pricing clearly at 101. So I got a lot of confidence around that. And again, depending on what's some of the geographic mix looks like, I'll leave it to your observations on whether there could be upside in that, but we certainly put a range out there that we have a high degree of confidence on.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That helps. Two follow-ups. Are you seeing any ability to ship further as diesel prices fall?
componenttext: That helps. Two follow-ups. Are you seeing any ability to ship further as diesel prices fall?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sure people could. Here's what I think is more of an issue. I think the barriers to entry and the regulatory environment of which we operate have gotten so difficult that the notion of trying to ship product farther and deplete quarries faster is not
componenttext: I'm sure people could. Here's what I think is more of an issue. I think the barriers to entry and the regulatory environment of which we operate have gotten so difficult that the notion of trying to ship product farther and deplete quarries faster is not something that I think most competitors are interested in doing. So I think with cheaper diesel, could it happen? I suppose math could say it could happen. Are we seeing that and can I go to specific markets and call it out as instances where I'm concerned about it? Not really at all. I think the other practical matter is twofold. One, people are having a hard time getting drivers in the marketplace, just finding them. And the number two, actually paying for them on the wages that they're looking for. So I think you've got an industry issue relative to aggregates that I think makes taking cheaper diesel and hauling stone farther a bit of an anathema. And I think you've also got a driver situation that makes it even more of a challenge. So to date, not an issue. And really, would not anticipate being an issue this year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That helps. And then lastly, is there a debt level your comfortable at? And at what debt level EBITDA ratio would you be comfortable taking out to buy back stock?
componenttext: That helps. And then lastly, is there a debt level your comfortable at? And at what debt level EBITDA ratio would you be comfortable taking out to buy back stock?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me turn to Anne to talk about...
componenttext: Let me turn to Anne to talk about...

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: James, as we've indicated pretty consistently, we said we would keep a minimum 2x debt to EBITDA. Obviously, at the end of 2015, we ended at a net debt of 1.9x. We've indicated we would keep that level of debt and then that we would continue to use excess
componenttext: James, as we've indicated pretty consistently, we said we would keep a minimum 2x debt to EBITDA. Obviously, at the end of 2015, we ended at a net debt of 1.9x. We've indicated we would keep that level of debt and then that we would continue to use excess cash over and above what we used both for organic and inorganic capital and use that in the form to pay back -- to buy back shares during the course of the year. So therefore, I think what you could think about is we likely are much more active in that market as we move through the second quarter and into the second half of the year. As we've indicated in the press release, we've used our available funds to produce some acquisitions in the business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And James, one thing to remember. We like these acquisitions that we've just got in Denver a lot. The other thing that we'll say is we like ourselves a lot, too. We feel like we've got a good business. So yes, the fact is, we believe this business continu
componenttext: And James, one thing to remember. We like these acquisitions that we've just got in Denver a lot. The other thing that we'll say is we like ourselves a lot, too. We feel like we've got a good business. So yes, the fact is, we believe this business continues to delever very, very quickly. And we like ourselves when we were $30 a share higher than we are now. So we really like ourselves a lot right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question just on pricing guidance. Just wondering if you could talk about how much of the price improvement that you're anticipating in 2016 is driven by improved mix and the lower-priced contracts rolling off as opposed to securing a meaningful con
componenttext: First question just on pricing guidance. Just wondering if you could talk about how much of the price improvement that you're anticipating in 2016 is driven by improved mix and the lower-priced contracts rolling off as opposed to securing a meaningful contracts of the April price increases? As we think about Cement pricing, in general, correct me if I'm wrong, it does take a little bit of time to be fully realized in earnings. So I'm just wondering if you could walk us through the price progression in 2016 and the different components.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Garik, you said it exactly right. Number one, to go back to your initial question. Really, almost all of the legacy TXI [indiscernible] those contracts are gone. So in large part, what you're talking about here on these price increases are real price
componenttext: Yes, Garik, you said it exactly right. Number one, to go back to your initial question. Really, almost all of the legacy TXI [indiscernible] those contracts are gone. So in large part, what you're talking about here on these price increases are real price increases, and it's what we anticipate putting into the marketplace in North Texas and South Texas. Now again, I think it's going to be easier in many respects to get pricing in North Texas than South Texas. I think we'll see it in both. I think we'll get it in both. They're just going to be easier in North. And I agree with you as well. We are going to have some of our own contracts that we need to work through. And part of what I've tried to do in the telecom is give some color around how that would play out over the year and put some specific percentages to it. But I mean, we'll we go in and get $12 across the board on everything this year? No, we won't because we do have to work through our own. But at least at this point, Garik, it is our own contracts now that we're working off and not TXI legacy contracts. Does that help?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does.
componenttext: Yes, it does.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Garik, you can see, Garik, where the pricing is at the end of 2015 such that by the end of the year that the guidance we've provided on average selling price per ton is that can kind of give you a sense of the trajectory realization to the course of t
componenttext: And Garik, you can see, Garik, where the pricing is at the end of 2015 such that by the end of the year that the guidance we've provided on average selling price per ton is that can kind of give you a sense of the trajectory realization to the course of the year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, of course. Two more questions, if I could. Just a point of clarification on the volumes that you picked up, the 1.5 million tons in Colorado. Just want to be clear that -- whether or not that is included in your volume guidance for the full year, the
componenttext: Yes, of course. Two more questions, if I could. Just a point of clarification on the volumes that you picked up, the 1.5 million tons in Colorado. Just want to be clear that -- whether or not that is included in your volume guidance for the full year, the 164 million to 167 million tons.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Short answer is no, it's not, Garik.
componenttext: Short answer is no, it's not, Garik.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, in the Magnesia specialties. The business calling for growth in 2016, fourth quarter did see some deceleration. Steel markets remained challenged. Just wondering if you could walk us through your underlying assumptions in that busin
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, in the Magnesia specialties. The business calling for growth in 2016, fourth quarter did see some deceleration. Steel markets remained challenged. Just wondering if you could walk us through your underlying assumptions in that business and what gives you the confidence that the market will turn around.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess a couple of things. One, we're looking at where the American Iron and Steel Institute is right now relative to their forecast. They're basically seeing steel at a 70% utilization rate. And if you recall going back over time, that's been the p
componenttext: Yes, I guess a couple of things. One, we're looking at where the American Iron and Steel Institute is right now relative to their forecast. They're basically seeing steel at a 70% utilization rate. And if you recall going back over time, that's been the point where we said is really important for this business. So if we're 70% or more, the business is going to do quite well. The other input that's important to remember is we are going to end up having decent amount of usage of natural gas in that business. If we look at what net gas did last year for the year, it's 28% lower. Even if we look at the quarter, it was about 26% lower. So again, if we're going into the year, and the Steel Institute is right at 70%, that's hitting a magic number. If the input on gas is going to continue to be low, that's helpful. To the extent that the business comes under pressure, the thing that I would tell you, too, is there's no team that we have in this company that's better at managing costs and managing their cost profile than our Magnesia Specialties business. So when I go back to our Q4 and look at a 35% margin, even if that business came under some degree of duress. And again, I'm not thinking that it will. But even if it did, I think you're looking at a business that's still going to have a margin in the low 30s. And from where I'm sitting, if we've got a low 30 margin, I'll take it every day.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Trey Grooms of Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Trey Grooms of Stephens.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So with the pent-up demand that you were talking about from weather, how quickly can that come through award? I mean, should that impact 1Q? Or really just trying to think about quarterly cadence of volume.
componenttext: Okay. So with the pent-up demand that you were talking about from weather, how quickly can that come through award? I mean, should that impact 1Q? Or really just trying to think about quarterly cadence of volume.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would think of it in these terms. Could it affect Q1? I suppose it could affect Q1. But remember what we've always said about Q1. Q1 is either made or broken the last 2 weeks of March in most instances. Because you've got to have relatively warm we
componenttext: Yes, I would think of it in these terms. Could it affect Q1? I suppose it could affect Q1. But remember what we've always said about Q1. Q1 is either made or broken the last 2 weeks of March in most instances. Because you've got to have relatively warm weather to put down hot mix in most markets. The other thing to remember, and we try to outline it pretty clearly in the telecon, we aren't going to have that shale headwind, at least in the Southwest throughout the first half of the year, but I think that clearly goes away once we're through the first half. That said -- and here's a good way to think of it. If you want to look at the midpoint of our guidance, what you're really saying is you're going to aggregate volume at the midpoint at about 166 million tons. I mean that's my quick math. If we want to stay there was whether deferral of, call it, 3.5 million, 4 million tons, and then you've got the shale maintenance level that could take it down another 1.5 million tons. I mean it rain in that first half, and then the other component that we're managing through, and we'll manage through it, it'll be just fine, it's a transition from New Braunfels to Hunter. And anytime you do a ship like that, it's never going to be a perfect handoff. There's going to be a little bit of shuffling that goes on because you're going from one large quarry to another large quarry. So as I look at that and start tallying it all up, yes, I could see 2016 ag volume at that 7% end of our range and 167 million tons. And could you see some of that go in Q1? You could, but you do have that shale play that I would just encourage you to be mindful of during the first half of the year. So if you think about it, Trey, last year Q1 was pretty good quarter. Q2 was a rainy mess. Q3 was relatively normal weather. And I think the performance we saw in Q3 was what you'd expect. And then Q4, we went back to building the ark. So the fact is if we end up with a good Q1 in normal weather, I think we'd be very, very pleased with that. And given what would be just the optical headwind on that portion of shale. Does that help?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Absolutely. Very helpful color, Ward. And on ready-mix, you mentioned a couple of times that you're expecting a much better year for ready-mix. I mean that segment is already below the downstream is putting up some really good margins. What's driving
componenttext: Yes. Absolutely. Very helpful color, Ward. And on ready-mix, you mentioned a couple of times that you're expecting a much better year for ready-mix. I mean that segment is already below the downstream is putting up some really good margins. What's driving the big margin improvement you're expecting there, specifically in ready-mix? Is that primarily material spread improvement? Or are there other drivers there that could be moving the needle?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, it's going to be spread. It's going to be primarily efficiencies. It's going to be more volume. And the fact is, you could see probably 900,000 cubic yards more volume in that business in Texas than we saw last year. I think the other piece
componenttext: You know what, it's going to be spread. It's going to be primarily efficiencies. It's going to be more volume. And the fact is, you could see probably 900,000 cubic yards more volume in that business in Texas than we saw last year. I think the other piece of it is, part of what we're seeing on some contracts now that are coming in in that South Texas area, we talked about those large projects like Cheniere and others. So the fact is we'll see what we feel like is a good bit of that going in this year as well. I think just better costs, better efficiency. I mean here's some interesting anecdote for you, Trey. I mean, at some point late in the fourth quarter, we actually got a call here in the corporate office. And we got a call from this poor guy who's trying to build a hotel and get concrete poured because he's opening the doors the next week, and he couldn't get concrete poured. And here's why he couldn't get concrete poured. Because the 4 other times we had been ready to deliver concrete to the site, he couldn't take it because the site was so wet. That's the type of backlog and backfill that we see in that business. So that type of carryover, much better efficiency, new contracts going as we think will be continued price leadership in that market gives us the type of confidence we have in ready-mix.

componenttextpreview: You know what, I think we're working our way through that. I mean I think that -- and I've always said probably by the time we got to the end of Q1, it would've shaken itself out. Yes, the fact is, go back and time and reflect on what TXI had done when th
componenttext: You know what, I think we're working our way through that. I mean I think that -- and I've always said probably by the time we got to the end of Q1, it would've shaken itself out. Yes, the fact is, go back and time and reflect on what TXI had done when they brought on more capacity throughout our ownership and then that worked itself out as well. Candidly, I think that's a little bit of what we've seen particularly in North Texas. And I think to the extent that Argos really becomes more of a sole supplier with their own Cement in South Texas, I think those 2 were in the type of stabilizing effect that I would affect -- that I would expect in both of those markets this year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, I don't see the dollar strengthening is really being a big component of that. I mean most of the imports that could come into Texas are coming through Texas through people who are domestic users there. Argos is the exception. And Argos is r
componenttext: You know what, I don't see the dollar strengthening is really being a big component of that. I mean most of the imports that could come into Texas are coming through Texas through people who are domestic users there. Argos is the exception. And Argos is really tapped out at 100,000 tons coming in through Houston. So I don't see that as something that I believe would be a driving force in that market, Timna.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I know you talked a lot about M&A being an important focus of the investor, and I just wonder if you could update us on how you're seeing opportunities there, valuations, appetite and if you'd have to expand from your current geographies or there's more opportunities from where you're already positioned?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess what I would say there continues to be a lot of just broad general activity in M&A. Period. I think we're seeing more approaches, and we're having more approaches than to others than we've seen in a while. I would expect that to persist. And
componenttext: Well, I guess what I would say there continues to be a lot of just broad general activity in M&A. Period. I think we're seeing more approaches, and we're having more approaches than to others than we've seen in a while. I would expect that to persist. And I think the notion of private companies seeing, I've got a 5-year Highway Bill, it looks more aggregate-intensive. This is probably not a bad place for us to ask somebody to job off the modeling tour, in their minds, it's probably not a bad place to be. I mean part of what I'd like about the deals we've just done is we were able to do those within EBITDA multiple ranges that make a lot of sense for our business. I mean we're picking up hard rock reserves at the end of the day from what we feel could be tonnage prices tons [indiscernible] selling gravel-type reserves. You shouldn't expect us to be looking at M&A in marketplaces that really are outside of where we are, unless we have the ability to go into a new market place either as a leader or what we feel like is a clear executable plan to be a leader. And what I would always draw you back to is what we did in Colorado in 2011. We went into that market with a swap that we did with La Farge. The other transaction we did literally back to back and put us sales overnight in leadership position and really have extended that march with this latest transaction. But going into an attractive market in being a 1C, 2C in it and really not having a good way to become a leader in that marketplace is not consistent with our strategy. So I wanted to articulate that to you because as you watch for us to grow, those really should be the boundaries to it.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually [indiscernible] on behalf of Jerry. Can you talk about how aggregates price increases for January 1 this year compared to last year and maybe how you expect the pricing cadence to play out? If I'm not mistaken, you had a bigger January 1
componenttext: This is actually [indiscernible] on behalf of Jerry. Can you talk about how aggregates price increases for January 1 this year compared to last year and maybe how you expect the pricing cadence to play out? If I'm not mistaken, you had a bigger January 1 increase last year than typical seasonality would suggest that those you had lower midyear prices throughout the year?  Well, what I would tell you is we've gone to the market pretty consistently with what we feel like the pricing needs to be. And obviously, pricing anywhere in the low end from $0.50 a ton to the middle range of about $1 a ton to some places, $1.50 a ton or more in some instances, I think one of the best examples that I can give you, if you go back to when we did our acquisition of TXI, part of what we said was, TXI's pricing was roughly 60% of our corporate average, and we said we thought it probably take about 3 years to get that closer to our corporate average, mindful that our corporate average continues to move up during that same period of time. Right now, TXI is about 75% of our corporate average. So again, from a rhythm and cadence perspective, that's certainly what we're seeing. Would I expect this to come back and talk about midyear price increases again this year? The short answer is I would, if we're seeing the types of volume increases and the more infrastructure-type work, honestly, I think you can find yourself in a position toward the latter part of '16, certainly in '17, that in some markets you could be short on some products. That was exactly what happened last year, principally because of flooding in North Texas with respect to sand, in particular. So again, I think the rhythm of it will be, you'll see most prices and effective January 1, in some places, you're going to see some pricing that won't go into effect until March or April. The long and short answer is that doesn't so much matter because there's not a lot of volume going on in Q1 anyway. And we will come back at some point later in the year and talk to you more about midyear price increases that I think customer should expect those conversations.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

And then clearly, we're still believing that that's going to be the case. This year, in Texas, we're probably looking -- trying to remember exactly, but we're looking at for the -- kind of give me one second on the additions this year. You know what, I have to come back and probably talk to you about that off-line.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: But really, if we're looking -- I'm giving you a good sense of what we look at on the kiln expenses for the year. That's probably a very worthy number for you to have right now. So we're looking at kiln expenses for the year on downtime, and these are imp
componenttext: But really, if we're looking -- I'm giving you a good sense of what we look at on the kiln expenses for the year. That's probably a very worthy number for you to have right now. So we're looking at kiln expenses for the year on downtime, and these are important numbers, we're looking probably in Q1 at about $6.6 million. We're looking into Q2 at about $3.7 million. We're looking Q3 at about $2 million, and Q4 is always the heavy quarter. That's going to be right at almost $11 million, $10.9 million. And now have found what I looking for. I apologize for that delay. Relative to capital, what we have said we would do is we would add some additions to cost of capital in 2015 and at about 200,000 additional tons at Hunter and about 50,000 additional tons at Midlothian. And then what we spelled out an Analyst Day and beyond is that we thought we would come back in '16, and these are in our capital plans, by the way, and add an additional 140,000 tons at Hunter. Again, that's in San Antonio, which brings you -- if we're looking 2017 through the additional tonnage that we're looking to add, it would put us at capacity in Texas of 4.75 million tons. So there's your build.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
