headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And again, we said it was going to be up $30 million. And the majority of that's likely going to be driven by the price component of it, but we are going to get efficiencies out of that business if we just had normal precipitation in that state, tha
componenttext: Okay. And again, we said it was going to be up $30 million. And the majority of that's likely going to be driven by the price component of it, but we are going to get efficiencies out of that business if we just had normal precipitation in that state, that would be pretty notable as well. I'm not I've got a specific percentage breakdown on that, but I would say the pricing is going to be more notable in some respects than with the volume.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the order thing I just want to ask quickly is, in terms of the contribution on the volume basis from the Colorado aggregate acquisition, can you just give a sense for what those are going to bring on in terms of production, realized volumes
componenttext: Okay. And then the order thing I just want to ask quickly is, in terms of the contribution on the volume basis from the Colorado aggregate acquisition, can you just give a sense for what those are going to bring on in terms of production, realized volumes in 2016?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can give you a sense of that. I mean, we're looking for probably about 1.5 million tons out of that business. Again, what we picked up there, Ted, and what we're very careful that we're trying to do, it goes back to what we said out in our soar [ph] pro
componenttext: I can give you a sense of that. I mean, we're looking for probably about 1.5 million tons out of that business. Again, what we picked up there, Ted, and what we're very careful that we're trying to do, it goes back to what we said out in our soar [ph] process, our strategic planning. We wanted to make sure we had leading positions in attractive regions. That's what we've done. We wanted to make sure that we were getting generational types of deposits in those areas. That's what we've done with nearly 1 billion tons in that marketplace. Here's an important note for us to consider because we haven't had a recent talk to you about this in the past, but actually in November, voters in Colorado Springs actually put in a sales and use tax increase of 0.62% to fund road repair and maintenance in that part of the state. We believe that's going to generate about $250 million over 5 years just in Southern Colorado. So when we come back with what we feel like will be about net sales of that business of about $90 million this year, EBITDA margins at probably 17% to 20%, which is below where we would like to see it, it's actually better than the business that we bought in the Rocky Mountains when we acquired it. And we brought it up. With that very capable team that we have in Denver, I don't have any doubt that we will see those percentages move up nicely and move up, I think, in trajectory in a much more quick time frame than they did for us originally in Denver, which, by the way, I don't think anyone ever complained about. So again, call it $90 million in net sales, EBITDA margin, 17%, 20%, probably about 1.5 million tons of ags.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question cames from James Armstrong with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question cames from James Armstrong with Vertical Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first one is, could you help us understand how to get comfortable with the 7% pricing guidance for 2016? Specifically, do you have any contracts in hand that really leads you to believe that the 7% in aggregates is in hand? And could it be -- with the
componenttext: The first one is, could you help us understand how to get comfortable with the 7% pricing guidance for 2016? Specifically, do you have any contracts in hand that really leads you to believe that the 7% in aggregates is in hand? And could it be -- with the type of volume you're talking about, could it be conservative?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, guess what I would say is this. The wonderful thing about the pricing story in our industry is that, I think, this has held together so remarkably well all the way through a downturn. Our sense has long been that as we hit an upturn, the pr
componenttext: You know what, guess what I would say is this. The wonderful thing about the pricing story in our industry is that, I think, this has held together so remarkably well all the way through a downturn. Our sense has long been that as we hit an upturn, the pricing story works even better. I think that's what we're seeing. I think the other thing that I would say is, one of the earlier comments I made was, "We see the Eastern United States recovering now at a faster rate than we've seen for a while. Eastern quarries are higher-priced quarries." So I guess what I would say this to answer to your question very specifically, James, I don't have any concerns about being able to at least make sure we get our pricing. If I worry about things, if I've got a worrying list from 1 to 100, I put pricing clearly at 101. So I've got a lot of confidence around that. And again, depending on what some of the geographic mix looks like, I'll leave it to your observations on whether there could be upside in that, but we certainly put a range out there that we have a high degree of confidence on.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That helps. Two follow-ups. Are you seeing any ability to ship further as diesel prices fall?
componenttext: That helps. Two follow-ups. Are you seeing any ability to ship further as diesel prices fall?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sure people could. Here's what I think is more of an issue. I think the barriers to entry and the regulatory environment in which we operate have gotten so difficult that the notion of trying to ship product farther and deplete quarries faster is not
componenttext: I'm sure people could. Here's what I think is more of an issue. I think the barriers to entry and the regulatory environment in which we operate have gotten so difficult that the notion of trying to ship product farther and deplete quarries faster is not something that I think most competitors are interested in doing. So I think with cheaper diesel, could it happen? I suppose math could say it could happen. Are we seeing that and can I go to specific markets and call it out as instances where I'm concerned about it? Not really at all. I think the other practical matter is twofold. One, people are having a hard time getting drivers in the marketplace, just finding them. And then number two, actually paying for them on the wages that they're looking for. So I think you've got an industry issue relative to aggregates that I think makes taking cheaper diesel and hauling stone farther a bit of an anathema. And then I think you've also got a driver situation that makes it even more of a challenge. So to date, not an issue. And really would not anticipate it being an issue this year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That helps. And then lastly, is there a debt level you're comfortable at? And at what debt level to EBITDA ratio would you be comfortable taking out to buy back stock?
componenttext: That helps. And then lastly, is there a debt level you're comfortable at? And at what debt level to EBITDA ratio would you be comfortable taking out to buy back stock?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me turn to Anne to talk about...
componenttext: Let me turn to Anne to talk about...

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: James, as we've indicated pretty consistently, we've said we would keep a minimum 2x debt to EBITDA. Obviously, at the end of 2015, we ended at a net debt of 1.9x. We've indicated we would keep that level of debt and then that we would continue to use exc
componenttext: James, as we've indicated pretty consistently, we've said we would keep a minimum 2x debt to EBITDA. Obviously, at the end of 2015, we ended at a net debt of 1.9x. We've indicated we would keep that level of debt and then that we would continue to use excess cash over and above what we used both for organic and inorganic capital and use that in the form to pay back -- to buy back shares during the course of the year. So therefore, I think what you could think about is that we likely are much more active in that market as we move through the second quarter and into the second half of the year. As we've indicated in the press release, we've used our available funds to do some acquisitions in the business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: James, one thing to remember. We like these acquisitions we've just done in Denver a lot. The other thing that we'll say is we like ourselves a lot, too. We feel like we've got a good business. So the fact is, we believe this business continues to delever
componenttext: James, one thing to remember. We like these acquisitions we've just done in Denver a lot. The other thing that we'll say is we like ourselves a lot, too. We feel like we've got a good business. So the fact is, we believe this business continues to delever very, very quickly. And if we like ourselves when we're $30 a share higher than we are now, so we really like ourselves a lot right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question was on your cement pricing guidance. Just wondering if you could talk about how much of the price improvement that you're anticipating in 2016 is driven by improved mix and the lower-priced TXI contracts rolling off as opposed to securing a
componenttext: First question was on your cement pricing guidance. Just wondering if you could talk about how much of the price improvement that you're anticipating in 2016 is driven by improved mix and the lower-priced TXI contracts rolling off as opposed to securing a meaningful portion of the April price increase. Because as we think about Cement pricing in general, correct me if I'm wrong, it does take a little bit of time to be fully realized in earnings. So I'm just wondering if you can walk us through the price progression in 2016 in the different components.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Garik, you said it exactly right. Number one, to go back to your initial question. Really, almost all of the legacy TXI facilities, those contracts are gone. So in large part, what we're talking about here on these price increases are real price incr
componenttext: Yes, Garik, you said it exactly right. Number one, to go back to your initial question. Really, almost all of the legacy TXI facilities, those contracts are gone. So in large part, what we're talking about here on these price increases are real price increases, and it's what we anticipate putting into the marketplace in North Texas and South Texas. Now again, I think it's going to be easier in many respects to get pricing in North Texas than in South Texas. I think we'll see it in both. I think we'll get it in both. They're just going to be easier in North. And I agree with you as well. We are going to have some of our own contracts that we need to work through. And part of what I've tried to do in the telecon is give some color around how that would play out over the year and put some specific percentages to it. But I mean, will we go in and get $12 across the board on everything this year? No, we won't because we do have to work through our own. But at least at this point, Garik, it is our own contracts now that we're working off and not TXI legacy contracts. Does that help?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does.
componenttext: Yes, it does.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Garik. And you can see, Garik, where the pricing is at the end of 2015 such that by the end of the year, the guidance that we've provided on average selling price per ton is that can kind of give you a sense of the trajectory of realization through the co
componenttext: Garik. And you can see, Garik, where the pricing is at the end of 2015 such that by the end of the year, the guidance that we've provided on average selling price per ton is that can kind of give you a sense of the trajectory of realization through the course of the year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, of course. Two more questions, if I could. Just a point of clarification on the volumes that you picked up, the 1.5 million tons in Colorado. Just want to be clear that -- whether or not that is included in your volume guidance for the full year, the
componenttext: Yes, of course. Two more questions, if I could. Just a point of clarification on the volumes that you picked up, the 1.5 million tons in Colorado. Just want to be clear that -- whether or not that is included in your volume guidance for the full year, the 164 million to 167 million tons.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Short answer is no, it's not, Garik.
componenttext: Short answer is no, it's not, Garik.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, in Magnesia specialties. The business calling for growth in 2016, fourth quarter did see some deceleration. Steel markets remained challenged. Just wondering if you could walk us through your underlying assumptions in that business
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, in Magnesia specialties. The business calling for growth in 2016, fourth quarter did see some deceleration. Steel markets remained challenged. Just wondering if you could walk us through your underlying assumptions in that business and what gives you the confidence that the market will turn around.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess a couple of things. One, if we're looking at where the American Iron and Steel Institute is right now relative to their forecast, they're basically seeing steel at a 70% utilization rate. And if you recall going back over time, that's been th
componenttext: Yes, I guess a couple of things. One, if we're looking at where the American Iron and Steel Institute is right now relative to their forecast, they're basically seeing steel at a 70% utilization rate. And if you recall going back over time, that's been the point that we said was really an important for this business. So if we're 70% or more, the business is going to do quite well. The other input that's important to remember is we are going to end up having a decent amount of usage of natural gas in that business. If we look at what net gas did last year for the year, it's 28% lower. Even if we look for the quarter, it was about 26% lower. So again, if we're going into the year and the Steel Institute is right at 70%, that's hitting a magic number. If the input on gas is going to continue to be low, that's helpful. To the extent that, that business comes under pressure, the thing that I will tell you, too, is there's no team that we have in this company that's better at managing costs and managing their cost profile than our Magnesia Specialties business. So when I go back to our Q4 and look at a 35% margin, even if that business came under some degree of duress. And again, I'm not thinking that it will. But even if it did, I think you're looking at a business that's still going to have a margin in the low 30s. And from where I'm sitting, if we've got a low 30 margin, I'll take it every day.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Trey Grooms of Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Trey Grooms of Stephens.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So with the pent-up demand that you were talking about from weather, how quickly could that come through, Ward? I mean, should that impact 1Q? Or really just trying to think about quarterly cadence of volume.
componenttext: Okay. So with the pent-up demand that you were talking about from weather, how quickly could that come through, Ward? I mean, should that impact 1Q? Or really just trying to think about quarterly cadence of volume.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I would think of it in these terms. Could it affect Q1? I suppose it could affect Q1. But remember what we've always said about Q1. Q1 is either made or broken the last 2 weeks of March in most instances. Because you've got to have relatively warm
componenttext: I guess I would think of it in these terms. Could it affect Q1? I suppose it could affect Q1. But remember what we've always said about Q1. Q1 is either made or broken the last 2 weeks of March in most instances. Because you've got to have relatively warm weather to put down hot mix in most markets. The other thing to remember, and we tried to outline it pretty clearly in the telecon, we are going to have that shale headwind, at least in the Southwest, throughout the first half of the year. But I think that clearly goes away once we're through with the first half. That said -- and here's a good way to think of it. If you want to look at the midpoint of our guidance, what you're really saying is you're going to have aggregate volume at the midpoint at about 166 million tons. I mean, that's my quick math. If we want to say there was whether deferral of, call it, 3.5 million, 4 million tons, and then you've got the shale maintenance level that could take it down another 1.5 million tons, I mean, it rain in that first half. And then the other component that we're managing through, and we'll manage through it, it'll be just fine, it's that transition from New Braunfels to Hunter. And any time you do a shift like that, it's never going to be a perfect handoff. There's going to be a little bit of shuffling that goes on because you're going from one large quarry to another large quarry. So as I look at that and start tallying it all up, yes, I could see 2016 ag volume at that 7% end of our range, in 167 million tons. And could you see some of that go in Q1? You could, but you do have that shale play that I would just encourage you to be mindful of during the first half of the year. So if you think about it, Trey, last year Q1 was pretty good quarter. Q2 was a rainy mess. Q3 was relatively normal weather. And I think the performance we saw in Q3 was what you'd expect. And then Q4, we went back to building the ark. So the fact is if we end up with a good Q1 and normal weather, I think we'd be very, very pleased with that, given what would be just the optical headwind on that portion of shale. Does that help?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Absolutely. Very helpful color, Ward. And then on ready-mix, you mentioned a couple times that you're expecting a much better year for ready-mix. I mean, that segment is already -- well, the downstream is already putting up some really good margins.
componenttext: Yes. Absolutely. Very helpful color, Ward. And then on ready-mix, you mentioned a couple times that you're expecting a much better year for ready-mix. I mean, that segment is already -- well, the downstream is already putting up some really good margins. What's driving the big margin improvement you're expecting there, specifically in ready-mix? Is that primarily material spread improvement? Or are there other drivers there that could be moving the needle?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, it's going to be spread. It's going to be primarily efficiencies. It's going to be more volume. I mean, the fact is, you could see probably 900,000 cubic yards more volume in that business in Texas than we saw last year. I think the other p
componenttext: You know what, it's going to be spread. It's going to be primarily efficiencies. It's going to be more volume. I mean, the fact is, you could see probably 900,000 cubic yards more volume in that business in Texas than we saw last year. I think the other piece of it is, part of what we're seeing on some contracts now that are coming in, in that South Texas area, we talked about those large projects, like Cheniere and others. So the fact is we'll see what we feel like is a good bit of that going this year as well. I think just better cost, better efficiency. I mean, here's an interesting anecdote for you, Trey. I mean, at some point late in the fourth quarter, we actually got a call here in the corporate office. And we got a call from this poor guy who's trying to build a hotel and get concrete poured because he's opening the doors the next week and he couldn't get concrete poured. And here's why he couldn't get concrete poured, because the 4 other times we had been ready to deliver concrete to the site, he couldn't take it because the site was so wet. That's the type of backlog and back-build that we see in that business. So that type of carryover, much better efficiency, new contracts going and what we think will be continued price leadership in that market gives us the type of confidence we have in ready-mix.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very encouraging. Last one for me. On the share movement you mentioned in Cement, the 325,000 tons, do you feel like that is pretty well run its course? I know the TXI legacy contracts have all rolled off. Do you feel like that's pretty well behind
componenttext: That's very encouraging. Last one for me. On the share movement you mentioned in Cement, the 325,000 tons, do you feel like that is pretty well run its course? I know the TXI legacy contracts have all rolled off. Do you feel like that's pretty well behind us at this point?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, I think we're working our way through that. I mean, I think that -- and I've always thought probably by the time we got to the end of Q1, it will have shaken itself out. The fact is, I go back and time and reflect on what TXI had done when
componenttext: You know what, I think we're working our way through that. I mean, I think that -- and I've always thought probably by the time we got to the end of Q1, it will have shaken itself out. The fact is, I go back and time and reflect on what TXI had done when they brought on more capacity prior to our ownership and then that worked itself out as well. Candidly, I think that's a little bit of what we've seen, particularly in North Texas. And I think to the extent that Argos really becomes more of a self-supplier with their own cement in South Texas, I think those 2 bring the type of stabilizing effect that I would affect -- that I would expect in both of those markets this year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you still think kind of end of Q1 is the target on that?
componenttext: So you still think kind of end of Q1 is the target on that?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do.
componenttext: Yes, I do.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just if I could sneak one more in for Anne, just kind of housekeeping here for modeling. The $102.44 you announced on Cement pricing for the quarter, is that basically where you ended the quarter for pricing there in Cement?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Timna Tanners with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Timna Tanners with Bank of America.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to do just touch base on the additional cement risk potential if the dollar continues to strengthen. How would you frame that risk? Or what extent do you see there?
componenttext: I wanted to do just touch base on the additional cement risk potential if the dollar continues to strengthen. How would you frame that risk? Or what extent do you see there?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, I've got to tell you. I don't see the dollar strengthening as really being a big component of that. I mean, most of the imports that come into Texas are coming in through Texas through people who are domestic producers there. Argos is the e
componenttext: You know what, I've got to tell you. I don't see the dollar strengthening as really being a big component of that. I mean, most of the imports that come into Texas are coming in through Texas through people who are domestic producers there. Argos is the exception. And Argos is really tapped out at 500,000 tons coming in through Houston. So I don't see that as really something that I believe would be a driving force in that market, Timna.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I know you talked a lot about M&A being an important focus as of the Investor Day. And I just wonder if you could update us on how you're seeing opportunities there, valuations, appetite. And if you'd have to expand from your cur
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I know you talked a lot about M&A being an important focus as of the Investor Day. And I just wonder if you could update us on how you're seeing opportunities there, valuations, appetite. And if you'd have to expand from your current geographies. Or if there's more opportunities from where you're already positioned.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess what I would say is there continues to be a lot of just broad general activity in M&A. Period. I think we're seeing more approaches, and we're having more approaches than -- to others than we've seen in a while. I would expect that to persis
componenttext: Well, I guess what I would say is there continues to be a lot of just broad general activity in M&A. Period. I think we're seeing more approaches, and we're having more approaches than -- to others than we've seen in a while. I would expect that to persist. And I think the notion of private companies seeing, hey, I've got a 5-year highway bill, it looks more aggregate-intensive. This is probably not a bad place for us to ask somebody to jump off on a modeling tour. In their minds, it's probably not a bad place to be. I mean, part of what I liked about the deals that we've just done is we were able to do those within EBITDA multiple ranges that make a lot of sense for our business. I mean, we're picking up hard rock reserves at the end of the day for what we feel like could be tonnage prices, at times, for sand and gravel-type reserves. You shouldn't expect us to be looking at M&A in marketplaces that really are outside of where we are, unless we have the ability to go into a new marketplace either as a leader or with what we feel like is a clear, executable plan to be a leader. And what I would always draw you back to is what we did in Colorado in 2011. We went into that market with a swap that we did with Lafarge, with the other transaction that we did literally back-to-back and put ourselves overnight in a leadership position and really have extended that march with this latest transaction. But going into an attractive market and being a onesie-twosie in it and really not having a good way to become a leader in that marketplace is -- it is not consistent with our strategy. So I wanted to articulate that to you because as you watch for us to grow, those really should be the boundaries to it.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And the last one, if I could. I just want to clarify what you said. I was confused on the Magnesia Specialty segment because utilization lately in steel -- sorry, I know this is like 72% in it over -- as of last year, and it's 72% or so now.
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And the last one, if I could. I just want to clarify what you said. I was confused on the Magnesia Specialty segment because utilization lately in steel -- sorry, I know this is like 72% in it over -- as of last year, and it's 72% or so now. So is it fair to say that at the same utilization, you'd make the same profits? Or is there other driving forces that we should be aware of.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the same utilization with the same profit. I guess what I was saying last year, we got to be careful to understand when I say last year, right, because we're in between years.
componenttext: No, the same utilization with the same profit. I guess what I was saying last year, we got to be careful to understand when I say last year, right, because we're in between years.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: In 2014, it was 78%. In 2015, 72%. And so what we're saying is we think it's probably going to be around that 70%. That's certainly what we're hearing right now. And if it stays there, we're going to see something that feels relatively consistent, I think
componenttext: In 2014, it was 78%. In 2015, 72%. And so what we're saying is we think it's probably going to be around that 70%. That's certainly what we're hearing right now. And if it stays there, we're going to see something that feels relatively consistent, I think, back to your question, Timna.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Brandon Jaffe on behalf of Jerry. Can you talk about how aggregates price increases for January 1 this year compared to last year? And maybe how you expect the pricing cadence to play out? If I'm not mistaken, you had a bigger January 1 i
componenttext: This is actually Brandon Jaffe on behalf of Jerry. Can you talk about how aggregates price increases for January 1 this year compared to last year? And maybe how you expect the pricing cadence to play out? If I'm not mistaken, you had a bigger January 1 increase last year than typical seasonality would suggest, unless you had lower midyear prices throughout the year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would tell you is we've gone to the market pretty consistently with what we feel like the pricing needs to be. And obviously, in pricing anywhere on the low end, from $0.50 a ton to the middle range of about $1 a ton to some places, $1.50 a t
componenttext: Well, what I would tell you is we've gone to the market pretty consistently with what we feel like the pricing needs to be. And obviously, in pricing anywhere on the low end, from $0.50 a ton to the middle range of about $1 a ton to some places, $1.50 a ton or more in some instances, I think one of the best examples that I can give you, if you go back to when we did our acquisition of TXI, part of what we said was TXI's pricing was roughly 60% of our corporate average, and we said we thought it'd probably take about 3 years to get that closer to our corporate average, mindful that our corporate average continues to move up during that same period of time. Right now, TXI is about 75% of our corporate average. So again, from a rhythm and cadence perspective, that's certainly what we're seeing. Would I expect us to come back and talk about midyear price increases again this year? The short answer is I would. If we're seeing the types of volume increases and the more infrastructure-type work, honestly, I think you could find yourself in a position toward the latter part of '16, certainly in '17, that in some markets, you could be short on some products. That was exactly what happened last year, principally because of flooding in North Texas with respect to sand, in particular. So again, I think the rhythm of it will be you'll see most prices into effect in January 1, in some places, you're going to see some pricing that won't go into effect until March or April. The long and short answer is that doesn't so much matter because there's not a lot of volume going on in Q1 anyway. And we will come back at some point later in the year and talk to you more about midyear price increases, but I think customers should expect those conversations.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the TXI Cement business, now that you've had more time to run those assets, can you talk about the opportunities you see there to invest in that business? And maybe update us on the Cement CapEx plans currently compared to what you laid
componenttext: Great. And then on the TXI Cement business, now that you've had more time to run those assets, can you talk about the opportunities you see there to invest in that business? And maybe update us on the Cement CapEx plans currently compared to what you laid out at the last Analyst Day?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I don't think the CapEx plans have changed materially since the last Analyst Day. I mean, part of what we said that we could do, and we were talking at that point not just about the Texas plants, we were talking about California plants as well becau
componenttext: Look, I don't think the CapEx plans have changed materially since the last Analyst Day. I mean, part of what we said that we could do, and we were talking at that point not just about the Texas plants, we were talking about California plants as well because we were saying that we could take our capacity up over time. And clearly, we're still believing that, that's going to be the case. This year in Texas, we're probably looking -- I'm trying to remember exactly, but we're looking at for the -- kind of give me one second, on the additions this year. You know what, I'm going to have to come back and probably talk to you about that off-line.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No problem.
componenttext: No problem.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: But really, if we're looking -- I can give you a good sense of what we're looking at on the kiln expenses for the year. That's probably a very worthy number for you to have right now. So if we're looking at kiln expenses for the year on downtime, and thes
componenttext: But really, if we're looking -- I can give you a good sense of what we're looking at on the kiln expenses for the year. That's probably a very worthy number for you to have right now. So if we're looking at kiln expenses for the year on downtime, and these are important numbers, we're looking probably in Q1 at about $6.6 million. We're looking in Q2 at about $3.7 million. We're looking in Q3 at about $2 million. And Q4 is always the heavy quarter, that's going to be right at almost $11 million, $10.9 million. And I now have found what I looking for. I apologize for that delay. Relative to capital, what we had said we would do is we would add some additions to cost of capital in 2015 and add about 200,000 additional tons at Hunter and about 50,000 additional tons at Midlothian. And then what we had spelled out at Analyst Day and beyond is that we thought we would come back in '16, and these are in our capital plan, by the way, and add an additional 140,000 tons at Hunter. Again, that's in San Antonio. Which brings you -- if we're looking 2017 through the additional tonnage that we're looking to add, it would put us at capacity in Texas of 4.75 million tons. So there's your build.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stephen Kim with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen Kim with Barclays.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered. But earlier in the year, we heard you guys talking about labor constraints, particularly on the ready-mix side. And I guess with all the rainy weather, it really kind of wasn't much of an issue. But was curious if
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. But earlier in the year, we heard you guys talking about labor constraints, particularly on the ready-mix side. And I guess with all the rainy weather, it really kind of wasn't much of an issue. But was curious if you had any insight into how that situation has developed. Has it improved, do you sense? Because I assume that part of the 3.5 million, 4 million catch-up or deferment in 1Q would sort of presume that you're going to be able to see some of those labor constraints not return or intensify. So if you could just talk a little bit about what you're seeing there on the labor side.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, if you go back, particularly in Texas, and then look at what is going on in that marketplace, a lot of it would tie back into what we talked about earlier, and that is simply what's going on with drivers, or what's not going on with drivers.
componenttext: Sure. I mean, if you go back, particularly in Texas, and then look at what is going on in that marketplace, a lot of it would tie back into what we talked about earlier, and that is simply what's going on with drivers, or what's not going on with drivers. So a lot of drivers were, frankly, engaged in what was going on in the shale fields at the time. So what's happening now is you've got more drivers who are available. But here's the other piece of it that's important, and we went through this very carefully last October when we were going to our planning cycle. Our 2 ready-mix businesses are in Colorado and Texas. And what we were hearing from both of those groups is, "If we could get more trucks, then we would have the ability to come back and safely serve the market in the most efficient way that we could. And the short answer is, at this point, we think we're able to: One, put more trucks in, in a thoughtful way; number two, put drivers in those trucks; and three, be in a position both in the Rocky Mountains as well as in the Metroplex, and I think that's going to be the primary marketplace that delivery can be tight at times. So I do think from a capital perspective, we're where we need to be. And I do think from a labor perspective, it's going to feel, in our world, much better in 2016 than it did in 2015, in large part if you just look at the rhythm and cadence of what has happened in those shale fields. Remember what we were talking about in some of the earlier conversations about what it looked like last year, Q1 in the shale fields, and what it looks like this year. And I think we'll really be able to meet that demand.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. No, that's very helpful. And then just lastly, I know that resi isn't a super high percentage of your business, but it's still almost 20%, I would guess. You talked a little bit about, I think, if you put up double-digit-type numbers that you're f
componenttext: Got it. No, that's very helpful. And then just lastly, I know that resi isn't a super high percentage of your business, but it's still almost 20%, I would guess. You talked a little bit about, I think, if you put up double-digit-type numbers that you're forecasting, and I think you talked about -- you referenced permits being strong. Obviously, in Texas, was curious -- there's some concerns, obviously, about what permits might do in Texas. And if you could just talk a little bit about what your guidance is assuming in terms of permit activity in Texas?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's talk about it in a number of different ways. Number one, permit activity that we see are up 12%, starts are up 11% and completions up 9%. So you still got more starts than completions, which we feel like is an attractive place to be. I think as we l
componenttext: Let's talk about it in a number of different ways. Number one, permit activity that we see are up 12%, starts are up 11% and completions up 9%. So you still got more starts than completions, which we feel like is an attractive place to be. I think as we look at what most forecasts are saying for 2016, they're looking for starts up around -- I think they're 1.25 million starts number. I mean, that's up around 13%. I think most people know -- this is getting farther out -- are looking starts to be up another 10%, even as we go into '17. So if we look at Texas more specifically, to your question, Texas ranked #4 in housing permit activity. Dallas-Fort Worth, which is our single largest market in Texas, is ranking second in housing permits. And to us, that continues to indicate good future strength in that market. There other thing that's remarkable to look at, if you look at residential units in 2015 in Dallas, what I'm seeing is data that reveals there's about 43,000 unit starts. If you look at Houston-Sugar Land, there's around 51,000 starts. You put those 2 together, that's almost 10% of the total starts in the United States. And we're not seeing any slowdown in North Texas at all right now. And the fact is, housing inventory in Houston is still at about 4 months. So...

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Stephen, I would just add, this is a point of clarification. Residential is about 15% of our end use, which is actually a very healthy percentage. At prior peak, we hit -- we knocked on the door of 20%, 22%, which gets it little bit out of balance. So
componenttext: And Stephen, I would just add, this is a point of clarification. Residential is about 15% of our end use, which is actually a very healthy percentage. At prior peak, we hit -- we knocked on the door of 20%, 22%, which gets it little bit out of balance. So we feel like we're still in that there are -- quite honestly, a good sweet spot in the residential activity.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Betts with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Betts with Jefferies.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any question I've got left is on the asphalt. And I guess it's 2 or 3 parts. You've obviously sold the San Antonio asphalt business. I see the volumes are down 45% in Q4 in the external sales in asphalt. Is that entirely due to that disposal? Or is that d
componenttext: Any question I've got left is on the asphalt. And I guess it's 2 or 3 parts. You've obviously sold the San Antonio asphalt business. I see the volumes are down 45% in Q4 in the external sales in asphalt. Is that entirely due to that disposal? Or is that due to weather or contracts ending or anything like that? I guess what I'm really after...

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Mike.
componenttext: Go ahead, Mike.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what I'm really after is some guidance as how much volume has gone with that disposal for the 9 months. It won't be in there next year. And then just sort of finally on the asphalt business, can you talk about the strategy for what you've got left
componenttext: I guess what I'm really after is some guidance as how much volume has gone with that disposal for the 9 months. It won't be in there next year. And then just sort of finally on the asphalt business, can you talk about the strategy for what you've got left there? I mean, are you looking to exit it? Because it is quite small now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, thanks for your question. Here are a couple of things that I would say. A few years ago, we had an asphalt business in Arkansas, which we no longer have. So that was sold about 1.5 years ago. Number two, what we did sell was basically an FOB asphalt
componenttext: Mike, thanks for your question. Here are a couple of things that I would say. A few years ago, we had an asphalt business in Arkansas, which we no longer have. So that was sold about 1.5 years ago. Number two, what we did sell was basically an FOB asphalt business that was in San Antonio. Here's the quick answer in that. We weren't the best owner of it. We did with asphalt in San Antonio exactly what we did with Cement in California. Somebody else was a better owner. It was not core to us in that marketplace. So we sold it. From a tonnage perspective, you're probably looking somewhere, let's call it, 700,000 tons a year. And so the single biggest piece of our asphalt business is in Denver. And to Denver, it is very much a core part of our business there. And the asphalt business does very well in Denver. And so we do see it as core in that marketplace because that's the way that marketplace is built up and down the Front Range. So people tend to be in aggregates, they tend to be in ready-mix, and they tend to be in hot mix. So we don't see a changing in that part of the world. And as we sit here today, Mike, that's the only place that we have asphalt left.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the acquisition of Colorado, will that add further significant asphalt volumes?
componenttext: So the acquisition of Colorado, will that add further significant asphalt volumes?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It does add some asphalt volume. Again, it tends to be an aggregates-led business. You're looking at probably about 340,000 tons in that southern Front Range marketplace that came with these transactions.
componenttext: It does add some asphalt volume. Again, it tends to be an aggregates-led business. You're looking at probably about 340,000 tons in that southern Front Range marketplace that came with these transactions.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Craig Bibb with CJS Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Bibb with CJS Securities.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on opening the Medina quarry. That's a big deal. Could you give us a little color on the impact on production volume and profitability, both in '16 and beyond?
componenttext: Congratulations on opening the Medina quarry. That's a big deal. Could you give us a little color on the impact on production volume and profitability, both in '16 and beyond?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, as we said, that's going to be about 6 million tons coming out of there. It's the largest quarry in the UP network. It's going to be going principally into Houston and South Texas. The primary issue that you've got there is that's going to
componenttext: You know what, as we said, that's going to be about 6 million tons coming out of there. It's the largest quarry in the UP network. It's going to be going principally into Houston and South Texas. The primary issue that you've got there is that's going to be an area of the state that's going to be starved for DOT specification stone. So number one, it's going to be highly efficient operation to get material to that part of the state for a long time. The other thing that it does, Craig, and this is important. If you ever fly into San Antonio, you're going to fly right over our Beckmann Quarry. Beckmann, for several times over the last decade, has been the largest-producing quarry in the United States, and it's almost situated in Metro San Antonio. And here's something I think most people don't appreciate. San Antonio is actually is the second-largest city in Texas. Houston's largest, San Antonio is #2. San Antonio is larger than Dallas, and our aim was to make sure we were utilizing Beckmann Quarry, which is really a diamond, in the most efficient way for that quarry, and to make sure we've got that quarry there for another 20-plus years. And we also were in a position to make sure that we could feed South Texas in the most efficient fashion, and thus the move to Medina. So that's probably a little bit more than you were looking for, Craig. But again, the strategy and the operations around it are important. What I can tell you is that plant opened on the day that we expected that plant to open. Railcars are going out of there on the day that we expected them to go. As you recall, we've got several hundred car unit facilities not just in Houston but throughout South Texas, and that's where that material is going.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a point of clarification, Craig. As Ward indicated in the teleconference script, that 6 million tons is actually just replacing tonnage. We're going to lower the tonnage at the Beckmann Quarry and move it through Medina. But as you look forward,
componenttext: And just a point of clarification, Craig. As Ward indicated in the teleconference script, that 6 million tons is actually just replacing tonnage. We're going to lower the tonnage at the Beckmann Quarry and move it through Medina. But as you look forward, that Medina quarry is capable of producing up to 10 million tons, but that's probably a couple of years out.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks again for joining our Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Call. Again, we are confident entering 2016, as I hope you can glean from our comments. We see strong employment growth in our key states, solid construction activity with increased materi
componenttext:
Thanks again for joining our Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Call. Again, we are confident entering 2016, as I hope you can glean from our comments. We see strong employment growth in our key states, solid construction activity with increased materials demand and attractive pricing opportunities. 
We look forward to discussing our first quarter results with you in May, and importantly, seeing you at our recently announced Investor and Analyst Day on May 9 in Dallas, Texas. We hope we'll see you then. 
Thank you very much, and thanks for your support of Martin Marietta.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
