headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a couple of things. If you look at diesel, Timna, we use just about 10 million gallons diesel for the quarter. If we're looking at the prices at $1.84 [ph] a gallon. And keep in mind, that does include the cost of the fixed price hedge that we hav
componenttext: I guess a couple of things. If you look at diesel, Timna, we use just about 10 million gallons diesel for the quarter. If we're looking at the prices at $1.84 [ph] a gallon. And keep in mind, that does include the cost of the fixed price hedge that we have in that. So really, if we look at it and think of it in our numbers, the hedge actually gave us about a $4.5 million headwind as we're going through the quarter. As a reminder, the hedge wraps up at the end of this year. But if we also look ahead, I can give you a good sense of what gallons look like last year. We did 9.9 gallons -- 9.9 million Q1 this year versus 9.2 million Q1 last year. In Q2 last year, we did a little bit more than 11 million gallons. In Q3, it was almost 12 million gallons. In Q4, it was a little bit over 10.1 million for a total of almost 42.5 million gallons. So that will give you a sense of it. The other thing that I would say is if we're looking back to Q1 last year, diesel is at $2.04 versus $1.84 this year. And if somebody had told us last year in Q1 that we would still have energy as a tailwind and a friend overall, I'm not sure I would have believed it, but here we are.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And the specialty -- the magnesia segment, I'm a little confused by the comments because steel demand is pretty low, as you've mentioned, and then you had a pretty solid results. So just wondering is that a structural change? Have you done
componenttext: That's helpful. And the specialty -- the magnesia segment, I'm a little confused by the comments because steel demand is pretty low, as you've mentioned, and then you had a pretty solid results. So just wondering is that a structural change? Have you done some cost cutting? Or does this mean that you can have higher profitability at a lower steel utilization going forward?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you think about it, Timna, the primary thing that we've said is that 2 things really drive that business. If you get steel utilization at 70% or better, and if you got natural gas prices that are well behaved, those 2 things will help that business pre
componenttext: If you think about it, Timna, the primary thing that we've said is that 2 things really drive that business. If you get steel utilization at 70% or better, and if you got natural gas prices that are well behaved, those 2 things will help that business pretty considerably. If we're looking at what the cost of nat gas was, that was down about 32% per quarter. So nat gas was giving that a tailwind. But even while steel was down 2.5% versus where it was last quarter, it was still at that 70% number that Anne referenced in the last conversation that we were just having with Kathryn. And candidly, 70 isn't an overheated number. I mean we built that business with our very capable team, recognizing that 70 was probably a pretty safe number to have out there. And look, are we awfully proud of staying margins at 38% when you have steel at 70%? I think those are tremendous numbers, and I think that team really should take about. So while we're pleased that results, I would say very pleased. Have we changed anything structurally? The answer is no. We really built it to make sure that those levels would operate very well with everyone want to take the business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to supplement side, Timna, the [indiscernible] really is the principal product that goes into the steel industry. The mag Business is actually seeing some good, solid demand across really all of the geographies that we serve, which is, as a remin
componenttext: And just to supplement side, Timna, the [indiscernible] really is the principal product that goes into the steel industry. The mag Business is actually seeing some good, solid demand across really all of the geographies that we serve, which is, as a reminder, is an international business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I just wanted to know if you could characterize what you're seeing in M&A because of some small deals and obviously the cash position is great. So just wanted to know your balance sheet position in general. Just wanted to get a sense of h
componenttext: Okay, great. And I just wanted to know if you could characterize what you're seeing in M&A because of some small deals and obviously the cash position is great. So just wanted to know your balance sheet position in general. Just wanted to get a sense of how you're seeing that M&A environment for now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Timna. We have a very busy team and strategy development. So they are looking at a number of different transactions today. I think what you saw us announced at the end of last year, what you've seen as announced earlier this year are the types
componenttext: Thank you, Timna. We have a very busy team and strategy development. So they are looking at a number of different transactions today. I think what you saw us announced at the end of last year, what you've seen as announced earlier this year are the types of bolt-on transactions that you should expect us to continue to look at. Specifically, I'm talking about what we did in Southern Colorado simply as an example. Those are markets that we feel like we're going to be attractive near term and long term. So you should expect us to be active, looking forward importantly the right deals. Because I think we're in a coveted space. I think we're in a spot that we can participate in deals. We can add synergy to those deals. But we're also in a space that we can buy back our shares as well. And they're not a lot of companies who can do that 1-2 punch that we can offer right now. So that's our take on M&A as it pertains to third parties and M&A as it pertains to ourselves.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to dig in a little bit on the gross profit guidance within the aggregates product line, if I could. You raised your volume guidance by about 1.5 million tons, cut the pricing that the same, but the profit guidance was raised by about $55 million
componenttext: Just want to dig in a little bit on the gross profit guidance within the aggregates product line, if I could. You raised your volume guidance by about 1.5 million tons, cut the pricing that the same, but the profit guidance was raised by about $55 million. So if you take the volume increase and apply the full drop-through, it will be about $20 million. Was just wondering if you can maybe provide a little bit of color, talked about efficiency, talk about geographic mix. But how should we think about the -- maybe the $35 million bridge from the growth in revenues versus the growth in profits that you're expecting?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Garik, I think you fit the 2 drivers I think we anticipate if we have normal weather, the efficiencies will be much better. And that's a powerful lever. I don't want to undersell that lever. I think, candidly, the more powerful lever right now is what's g
componenttext: Garik, I think you fit the 2 drivers I think we anticipate if we have normal weather, the efficiencies will be much better. And that's a powerful lever. I don't want to undersell that lever. I think, candidly, the more powerful lever right now is what's going on in Georgia, it's going on in Florida, what's going in South Carolina and what's going on in North Carolina. And keep in mind, what you haven't really seen in any significant material way yet is what we feel like is going to be a pretty busy year in Indianapolis in our Mideast business and is likely to be a very busy year in our Midwest business as well. Garik, as I sit here and really just think about our aggregates business and take a measure of it, but I would say to you is it wouldn't surprise me at the end of the year to have a record year in the Rocky Mountain division. It wouldn't surprise me to have a record year in our Midwest division. I think we're going to have a record year in our Southwest division. We're going to have a remarkably better year in our Southeast division, and we're going to have remarkably better year in our Mid-Atlantic Division. And candidly, it's possible to have a record year in our Mideast division. So if you're thinking about those different divisions, which ones of those are pure aggregates and the sheer number of those that are now transitioning to the Eastern half of the United States, I think that type of activity both from an infrastructure perspective and frankly other perspectives, combined with higher efficiencies really drives that delta that you're seeing in profitability.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Garik, just to add a little color to that, our first quarter margins of 20% and the drilling down into aggregates business even more, we actually had some acceleration of stripping cost and repair and maintenance cost in the first quarter as our teams
componenttext: And Garik, just to add a little color to that, our first quarter margins of 20% and the drilling down into aggregates business even more, we actually had some acceleration of stripping cost and repair and maintenance cost in the first quarter as our teams in the field are prepping for what they think -- for the backlog that's out there for the balance of the year. So part of that margin expansion and efficiency do come from a lot of those cost that have been incurred. And as Ward said, ready to let the horse run.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That sounds good. Just wanted to follow up on Cement. It seems like you won back market share in the first quarter. Just wondering how you feel your market share is positioned right now as you look the Texas Cement market through the remainder of the year
componenttext: That sounds good. Just wanted to follow up on Cement. It seems like you won back market share in the first quarter. Just wondering how you feel your market share is positioned right now as you look the Texas Cement market through the remainder of the year? And then you also did reduce your Cement pricing guidance. So I just wanted to see how you're anticipating the [indiscernible] price increases to go and what that means with respect to the market share question that I asked previously? .

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess a couple of things, Garik. If you go back to the conversation we had in February, I think, in large part, the first quarter, I think the term we used are shaking out. Shaking out about the we thought it would. I think we said we've got -- it
componenttext: Sure. I guess a couple of things, Garik. If you go back to the conversation we had in February, I think, in large part, the first quarter, I think the term we used are shaking out. Shaking out about the we thought it would. I think we said we've got -- it would be an easier or better pricing environment in North Texas, that it was going to be in South Texas. I think that's been entirely true. The Comptroller said very helpful for in inputting out a lot of different numbers that marketplace can see. That 21% market share or in that ZIP Code is not a place that we think is a bad place for our business to be. I've also referenced the fact that we, I believe, can be a remarkably efficient producer of cement in that marketplace as well. I think one reason that you saw a modest pullback perhaps in the pricing is we've seen relatively good activity on volumes that you saw. And what we've also done is we've had some wholesale sales, particularly in that North Texas market to other producers that are in that marketplace. And the wholesale prices clearly go at a different number. So if I'm looking at probably about 40,000 tons that we sold in the quarter that were wholesale tons and then take a look at really what were some product mix issues, simply -- really selling more customers picking a product, FOB, the plant, and I would say that was more driven in South Texas than it was driven in North Texas, and then back to -- as we discussed in February, there are some competitive dynamics there that we're sensitive do. I think when you tally those together, it brings you to the point that you see in the full results. I believe is we have the weather in Texas that I think we're going to have, I think we're likely to have a very active year in Texas. I'd like the way I'm seeing our ready-mix business run right there I'm seeing other ready-mix business is run in Texas right now. The fact is, it's pretty conceivable that you can have cement shortages in Texas as we get to the main part of the year. And I'll let you draw your own conclusions on what that may mean relative to cement pricing going forward. Again, as we're looking at this business from an efficiency perspective, on pricing and really running it for profitability, I'm very comfortable with where that is. The other thing that's interesting to me, Garik, is to see what's going on with cement pricing in other parts of the United States as well. So if I'm looking in places like Colorado, or the Carolinas or otherwise, I'm seeing cement prices in those markets that are at times $25 or more a ton of where we sit in Texas right now, which gives me a sense we've got some nice runway ahead of us on this. But keep in mind, as we take a look at where we sit on pricing in cement in Texas today, we're 20% up in South Texas from where the prices were when we combined with TXI, and we're 30% up in North Texas of where prices were. I'm trying to give some context. I'd apologize for the length of my response, but I think the context is important.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk about how you expect the pricing cadence to play out over the course of this year? Last year, you opted for major price increase on January 1. And I'm wondering if you could see potential for sequential price increases this
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk about how you expect the pricing cadence to play out over the course of this year? Last year, you opted for major price increase on January 1. And I'm wondering if you could see potential for sequential price increases this year as we go through the year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then we're talking aggregates, Jerry?
componenttext: And then we're talking aggregates, Jerry?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: In aggregates, yes.
componenttext: In aggregates, yes.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we look at our aggregates pricing, here's what I would say. We've got 17 out of 20 districts where it's just remarkably positive. We've got almost half of those where it's up at least $1 a ton and several districts where we're up $2 a ton. So we're see
componenttext: As we look at our aggregates pricing, here's what I would say. We've got 17 out of 20 districts where it's just remarkably positive. We've got almost half of those where it's up at least $1 a ton and several districts where we're up $2 a ton. So we're seeing nice price movement in really important markets. The only markets where we're not seeing remarkable price movement, it's fascinating to me, we got some freight adjustments that we had to deal with some and we simply have some mix issues in others. So I'm looking quarry by quarry, product by product. I'm seeing good price increases in all those. But I would say, too, Jerry, is we're in a marketplace where volumes continue to go up. So pricing, as you know, having botched the scope of the cycle behaved exceptionally well even in a down market. From when I'm sitting right now, Jerry, I think trying to measure it going forward at F.W. Dodge is a good indicator. Dodge right now is looking at 3 good years ahead of us right now. We probably would've said the same thing last year, and that was before we ended up with the 5-year Highway Bill. So as we're sitting here, Jerry, I think the rhythm and cadence of price increases this year won't be dramatically different than they were last year, for example. I think they've been very strong so far. I think you're going to have a geographic mix that's going to give a tailwind to the way pricing is looking. But I also think that what we said for the last couple of years is entirely true, and that is the Western United States, on a percentage basis, has more pricing power ahead of it than does the East simply because the East is a more mature market, prices are higher, so your percentages up won't be as great. But again, as North Carolina continues to recover, as Georgia continues to recover, as Florida continues to recover and as places like Dallas-Fort Worth, as I've referenced in my comments, have the type of volume growth and pricing growth that they're experiencing, the pricing story we think will continue to be a very good one, not just for a matter of quarters. It's probably for better years.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've commented in the past, that based on the reserve position in Colorado and Dallas markets where you participate, you would look for aggregates pricing to approach company average pricing over time. Can you just give us an update on where that stands
componenttext: You've commented in the past, that based on the reserve position in Colorado and Dallas markets where you participate, you would look for aggregates pricing to approach company average pricing over time. Can you just give us an update on where that stands today and how much do you think the gap  could narrow in '17?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. If you recall, when we were looking at the transactions Texas, particularly in North Texas, I want to say at the day in the hour, those prices were about 60% of the corporate average. As we look at it today, it's about 75% of the corporate ave
componenttext: Absolutely. If you recall, when we were looking at the transactions Texas, particularly in North Texas, I want to say at the day in the hour, those prices were about 60% of the corporate average. As we look at it today, it's about 75% of the corporate average. And what we have spoken of the time, Jerry, is we thought it would probably take about 3 years for that to build to something that felt more like a corporate average. I think that's still not a bad place for us to be as we look at it. The other thing that I would tell you is really, starting last year, that we saw aggregate pricing in Colorado start to move on percentages that were really better than what you are seeing across the corporate average. Now do I think Colorado is going to be there from a time perspective at the same time as Texas is? No, I don't. It's likely to move a little bit more slowly than Texas. But I still think probably over a 5-year period. Basically, over what we look at as our strategic planning period. Colorado should be closing in on it. Texas very much should be there. Is that responsive, Jerry?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You also saw obviously the West Group pricing dynamics and that's where about -- that's where the Dallas market, the Colorado market would be reported. I think you can continue to expect those area -- that in the country in that segment to report pri
componenttext: Yes. You also saw obviously the West Group pricing dynamics and that's where about -- that's where the Dallas market, the Colorado market would be reported. I think you can continue to expect those area -- that in the country in that segment to report pricing at a higher rate than the balance of the country or the corporate average.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's super helpful. And lastly, I'm wondering if you could talk about what proportion of your sales were out of your long-haul network within aggregates this quarter compared to last year and how do you expect the full year mix to look like the long-hau
componenttext: That's super helpful. And lastly, I'm wondering if you could talk about what proportion of your sales were out of your long-haul network within aggregates this quarter compared to last year and how do you expect the full year mix to look like the long-haul versus truck-served markets for you.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, Jerry, I'd rather not go into specific percentages of that. Tell you, for example, is the yards that we have in Florida right now are really some of the best businesses that we have in the East. If you think about what's going on in Florida
componenttext: You know what, Jerry, I'd rather not go into specific percentages of that. Tell you, for example, is the yards that we have in Florida right now are really some of the best businesses that we have in the East. If you think about what's going on in Florida, if you think about what's going on in South Texas coming out of that new Medina Rock & Rail facility, those businesses to us look better than they did last year. And when we come back and take a look at the full year, my guess is going to be somewhere in the teens overall from a volume perspective. Keep in mind, what we move by rail in the United States all by itself, ignoring everything else that's shipped by truck or otherwise, is the top 10 aggregates producer in the United States. So it's a considerable piece of the business, but the areas that we have that business, it's performing exactly as we would have thought, maybe modestly ahead.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Armstrong with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Armstrong with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, you talked about weather a little bit and if the weather holds up. What are you seeing in Texas and the South in general following the storms? Did that have any impact in the first quarter at all? And do you think it will impact the sec
componenttext: My first question, you talked about weather a little bit and if the weather holds up. What are you seeing in Texas and the South in general following the storms? Did that have any impact in the first quarter at all? And do you think it will impact the second quarter any -- on a volume basis?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, the first quarter was relatively benign, and I would say not that negatively weather-impacted. Now it varies. April is pretty wet. I mean, you saw pretty massive flooding in places like Houston [indiscernible] slow work down for a while? Ye
componenttext: You know what, the first quarter was relatively benign, and I would say not that negatively weather-impacted. Now it varies. April is pretty wet. I mean, you saw pretty massive flooding in places like Houston [indiscernible] slow work down for a while? Yes, it does. At the same time, you're close enough to the Gulf in areas like Houston that you tend to have areas that can dry out relatively well, particularly if you have a windy circumstance. So I'll put it this way, James. May is an important month. It always has been. The 2 months in the aggregates business that tend to be disproportionately important are May and October. May, because this is the first time across the geographic footprint that you have every bit of your business usually really hitting on it's all cylinders and October because that's the last month that, a, is usually dry and a lot of contractors feel like by the time they get to Thanksgiving, in many respects, they'll be packing up their equipment for the year. So was April a wet month? Yes, it was. Does May need to be a relatively dry month for the industry? Yes, I would tell you that it does.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Extremely helpful. And then just coming back to ancient history hopefully at this point. Any leftovers from fracturing falling off? Or was that pretty much completely gone at this level? And And what are you seeing in that market?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, thanks for the question on that. I want to be really clear because, really, what we sell in the marketplace to different shale energy prices, just to be clear, is not frac material. So we're selling materials to the shale energy players for bui
componenttext: And again, thanks for the question on that. I want to be really clear because, really, what we sell in the marketplace to different shale energy prices, just to be clear, is not frac material. So we're selling materials to the shale energy players for building roads or building their pads. I want to make sure we're clear on that. What we had indicated we thought is that we would see relatively maintenance levels stone going to these different shale plays in the United States. And what we said for the year is we thought that would be probably in the ZIP Code of 2 million tons or about 0.5 million tons a quarter. That's what we viewed as maintenance. So actually, as we come back and take a look at exactly where we are in Q1, what -- it's good to be right. And we were right on that. So I guess we'll take that. We'll take being right. I'm sorry. It's 500,000 tons. I'd love to see 3x that because that's where we were last year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Adam Thalhimer with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adam Thalhimer with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kind of following up on that. The heavy nonres, you had some nice growth in the quarter, and I think that's changed from previously. Was that due to some of the awards you talked about earlier this year?
componenttext: Kind of following up on that. The heavy nonres, you had some nice growth in the quarter, and I think that's changed from previously. Was that due to some of the awards you talked about earlier this year?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You know what it is. It's not that much of a change for us because a lot of what we're seeing is driven by work that we're seeing not just in South Texas. And that's where a lot of it is. But we're seeing good, nice, nonres in portions of South Carol
componenttext: Yes. You know what it is. It's not that much of a change for us because a lot of what we're seeing is driven by work that we're seeing not just in South Texas. And that's where a lot of it is. But we're seeing good, nice, nonres in portions of South Carolina. In fact, I call out South Carolina specifically on some infrastructure in our prepared remarks. But we're seeing good nonres market. We're also seeing good nonres in Dallas, in Denver, in Orlando, in college station in Texas as well. So the nonres that we're seeing looks pretty good. I think one data point that's probably worth noting is 6 of the Martin Marietta states ranked in the top 10 for growth in nonres starts. And 2 of those states include Florida and Colorado. I think a lot of it, Adam, really comes back to this notion that we discussed I think a lot over the last couple of years because we were hoping that it would come to fruition the way that it has where you are matters. And as we're looking at the states in which we have leading positions, and keep in mind, those leading positions today, 1 or 2, are on 85% versus 65% of our markets 5 years ago. We've tried to position ourselves in states that have near-term and long-term growth and that tend to have multiple economic drivers in them as well. So again, I don't think the nonres story is dramatically different. But we are seeing some of those very large projects, for example, in South Texas firm up and taking those backlogs even more capably in our pocket right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're still staying projects on to bid on the heavy side? Or...
componenttext: So you're still staying projects on to bid on the heavy side? Or...

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I mean what I would tell you is, our teams, both in Martin Marietta as well as our customer base, probably feel as optimistic right now as I've seen people feel in about 10 years. And I think a lot of that is driven by the fact that the Easter
componenttext: Absolutely. I mean what I would tell you is, our teams, both in Martin Marietta as well as our customer base, probably feel as optimistic right now as I've seen people feel in about 10 years. And I think a lot of that is driven by the fact that the Eastern United States lag the West not by a matter of months but really by a matter of years in coming back with some degree of nonres projects in particular. And keep in mind, a lot of times we said those projects will follow varying degrees of housing recovery with a 9- to 18-month lag. And if we continue to see permits, starts and completions on housing, all of those double digits, and we also continue to see single-family housing ramp up, that's going to be more aggregate-intensive and we're going to see the nonres, both light and heavy, I think continue to follow that in a very constructive manner.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Adam, one of the things we've seen pretty consistently across the footprint is a lot of distribution activity, distribution centers and channels like that. I would say uniformly across the footprint. That's been an accelerated level of activity o
componenttext: I think, Adam, one of the things we've seen pretty consistently across the footprint is a lot of distribution activity, distribution centers and channels like that. I would say uniformly across the footprint. That's been an accelerated level of activity over the past several months or at least reported activity that's on its way down the pipe.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then just lastly on the -- I don't know how fair this question is, but can you compare at all the FAST Act to the state-level initiatives? Just trying to get a sense for what's coming in '17 from the FAST Act versus what we've
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then just lastly on the -- I don't know how fair this question is, but can you compare at all the FAST Act to the state-level initiatives? Just trying to get a sense for what's coming in '17 from the FAST Act versus what we've got in '16 from the state-level initiatives.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what I would say is this, I'd don't want to go into '17 volume shipped as we look at it. But I would say is, you're going to see states continue to let more long-term aggregate-intensive projects over the next several years than they have over th
componenttext: You know what I would say is this, I'd don't want to go into '17 volume shipped as we look at it. But I would say is, you're going to see states continue to let more long-term aggregate-intensive projects over the next several years than they have over the last several years. And I do think the FAST Act will give states who have not been coming up with very specific state initiatives a lot more runway than they've had for a while. I think the real blessing we're going to have, though, if you really pause and reflect on the key states for us, that will have both. I mean think of it in these terms. Colorado is going to have both. Separate and distinct from what's going on in Colorado Springs. Iowa has both. Nebraska has both. Texas has both. Remember, the extra funding that comes into Texas just from Prop 7, by the time we get to September 2017, is more money than the increase on a per annum basis than you see even the FAST Act. So the FAST Act is nice because it does put dollars there. But the primary component of the FAST Act is going to be helpful is time. So what's going to happen, You're going to take extra state dollars and combine that with extra time from the Fed. It's going to be the confluence of those 2 factors that will be more profound, particularly beginning in '17 and then in the out years.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Betts with Jefferies.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My 2 questions, please. You sounded pretty positive in aggregate prices, Ward. But the average $13.04 in Q1, but the guidance for the year is only $12.75 to $13. So pretty flat. So is there some change going on that you'd expect to offset some of the mayb
componenttext: My 2 questions, please. You sounded pretty positive in aggregate prices, Ward. But the average $13.04 in Q1, but the guidance for the year is only $12.75 to $13. So pretty flat. So is there some change going on that you'd expect to offset some of the maybe underlying growth later in the year? Or am I just being maybe too picky by comparing those numbers? And then secondly, I don't think we talked much about the asphalt business. I mean could you remind me what sort of made you divest that impact of that volume number? And secondly, your old firm is commenting yesterday that it's going to be much more difficult business this year because the escalator clauses are going to kick in or the adjustment clauses, which would impact -- which would mean the lower -- price would seep through and therefore there will be less pricing power. Does that impact you at all?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, Mike, I would never call you being too picky for asking the questions. That's not a problem. What I would say is this, when you look at Q1, don't ever take Q1 in a vacuum as really a good litmus test on exactly what's going on in prici
componenttext: Well, first of all, Mike, I would never call you being too picky for asking the questions. That's not a problem. What I would say is this, when you look at Q1, don't ever take Q1 in a vacuum as really a good litmus test on exactly what's going on in pricing. Going back to a conversation that we had a few minutes ago, the Midwest is not cranking during Q1. The Middle East is not cranking into Q1. So what you're seeing in Q1 is a lot of North Carolina, South Carolina, Florida, all of which in the Eastern U.S. are pretty high-priced markets. And then you're obviously seeing pricing in Texas, particularly North Texas, move at very nice percentages. So what I would tell you is you're going to continue to see good robust pricing. But it's going to happen in Mideast, which is principally Indiana and Ohio, and the Midwest, which is principally Iowa and Minnesota and Nebraska come in. Those tend to be more corporate average-y on pricing. So again, I think we feel very comfortable with the percentages that we put out there. To your question an asphalt. The way I would think of it, if we look at asphalt, we did about 2.1 million tons of asphalt last year in the Rocky Mountain division. As we look at it now, that's the only asphalt that we have left. So we did sell, frankly, a pretty modest asphalt position that we had around the San Antonio marketplace. So the fact that we don't have that business anymore is not going to be a dramatic driver or not on what we're seeing relative to our business. With respect to the liquid asphalt or bitumen and where it is, Mike, my guess is that story is going to change a lot back to what I've said before, depending on where you are in the marketplace. The circumstance up and down the Front Range in Colorado. And when I speak to the front Range, I'm really talking about the I-25 corridor that's where 80% of the people who live in Colorado reside. That market is very, very busy right now on public. It's very, very busy on private res and nonres. And in large parts, you've got a good asphalt market, particularly on subdivision side and on the infrastructure side. And a lot of the work in Colorado, particularly 1 year, 1.5 years ago was having to be lead couple times, more times because they weren't having enough bidders were available. That's going to be a tight market relative to aggregate. It's going to be a tight market relative to contractors who are able to do much of that work. And again, thank as we're looking at our asphalt business that is principally a Colorado asphalt business, we feel pretty good about it. Now relative to your question on how it do in the first quarter, it really didn't do much in the first quarter. We don't expect it to do much in the first quarter. Again, because they're in the Rocky Mountains. If we're looking at what asphalt sales were for us both internally and externally in the first quarter, it was 134,000 tons versus 147,000 tons in the prior year. And the 147,000 tons the prior year had the Texas business in it as well.

componenttext: Yes -- no, Craig, I think the big issue that was going on there is we got rained on all last year. I mean the ready-mix business that really are looking at when you look at these numbers is what's going on in Texas. And in Texas, just really never have the ability to show last year what it can do. So again, looking at volume up 21% [ph] of pricing, up 12%, you can see what's happened with gross profit. Again, I think this is really more of a story that candidly we're not that surprised by. We think we've got a very good position in ready-mix both Texas and in Colorado. I'm particularly pleased to see what we're doing in Texas, though, the relative to the EBITDA. Part of what we've said before, we would like to see those margins in Texas approach what we see in margins in Colorado. So if you're looking at EBITDA-ish this year in the Southwest of $38 million, if we're able to do in the Southwest on margins what we've been doing ourselves doing in Colorado, that can translate at the right day in the right hour to about $75 million in gross margins. So  it's a very good story the first quarter. Two, we expect it to be a very good start for the rest of the year, but we also expect to see that Texas business continue to do better.

componenttext: Thank you again for joining our first quarter 2016 earnings call. We're poised for a great 2016. headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta First Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now turn the call over to your host, Ward Nye, Cha
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta First Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would now turn the call over to your host, Ward Nye, Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.To facilitate today's discussion, we've made available during this webcast
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
To facilitate today's discussion, we've made available during this webcast and our website supplemental financial information which we believe will be helpful. As detailed specifically on Slide 2, please remember that today's teleconference may include forward-looking statements as defined by securities laws in connection with future events or future operating or financial performance. Like other businesses, we're subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially. Except as legally required, we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether resulting from new information, future developments or otherwise. We refer you to the legal disclaimers contained in our first quarter earnings release and other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are available on both our own and the SEC websites.
Also, as a reminder, any margin references on our discussion are based on net sales and exclude freight and delivery revenues. These and other non-GAAP measures are explained in our supplemental financial information on our website and in our SEC filings. 
As detailed in the release we distributed, Martin Marietta delivered record first quarter results reflecting strong operational performance as we began to reap the benefits of a more favorable, broad-based construction-centric phase of recovery in some geographic areas and expansion in others. Our impressive first quarter numbers included record net sales, record net earnings, consolidated gross margin expansion of 790 basis points and an increase in earnings per share of nearly 9x the $0.07 reported last quarter. 
On a consolidated basis, our operations achieved a nearly 70% incremental gross margin. Another notable highlight is our nearly 20% gross margin, mirroring the level attained in the first quarter of 2006, a time when the overall economy was near an all-time highs and annual housing starts in the United States were nearly 2 million units. To deliver similar performance in 2016, with an economy only in the early stages of construction recovery in many of our key markets, is indicative of the strength and benefit of our geographic positioning and strategic planning.
Against that backdrop, the Aggregates product line delivered robust volume and pricing growth of 13% and 8% respectively. The Mid-America Group led with a 28% increase in aggregates product line shipments. This performance was driven by the commencement of several large, principally state-funded highway projects across the Carolinas, together with increased residential and nonresidential construction activity. The West Group reported a 5% increase in shipments and an 11% increase in average selling price. Of particular note for the quarter, North Texas aggregates product line shipments and volume and pricing increased 28% and 12% respectively. The Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex is the fastest growing area in Texas, and one of the top nationally for both employment growth and residential construction. Additionally, the Texas Department of Transportation has announced construction plans in excess of $8 billion per annum over the next several years. This program, which, together with the funding provided by the North Texas and Harris County Tollway Authorities, should lead to further growth in customer backlogs. Our attractive leading Texas market positions will allow us to capitalize on these opportunities for the balance of the year and indeed for years to come.  In addition to volume growth in the quarter, we benefited from a stronger pricing environment. Simply put, aggregate pricing is up broadly across the company's business.
The ready-mixed concrete product line enjoyed strong demand and much improved operating conditions in Texas. This twofold combination drove a 31% increase in shipments and a nearly 12% increase in average selling price. The result, a 46% increase in net sales and an 810 basis point improvement in gross margin. Texas-based ready-mixed concrete operations are expected to contribute significantly to full year profitability following a profoundly weather-impacted 2015 that effectively masked the potential of this TXI-acquired business. The stated aim and expectation is for profit margins in the Texas ready-mixed concrete business to rival that of our Colorado-based business. We see these early 2016 results as a good start for the fulfillment of that goal.
As a result of the September 2015 sale of our California Cement business, comparability of results for the Cement segment will be affected throughout the year. The 2015 impact of the California Cement operations is detailed on Slide 5. Our remaining cement business, which is entirely in Texas, benefited from considerably better weather, but importantly, strong demand, which is forecasted by the Portland Cement Association to continue for the next several years. For the quarter, the business generated nearly $70 million of net sales and $33 million of gross profit. This translated to a 47% gross margin, which increased over 1,000 basis points as compared to the prior year period. EBITDA for the Cement business was $37.8 million, a 37.5% increase from the prior year quarter. 
Lastly, the Magnesia Specialties business delivered record first quarter net sales of $59.5 million. The Magnesia Specialties team continues to diligently manage the cost profile of the business. And despite U.S. steel capacity utilization being nearly 2.5% lower than the prior year quarter, our business delivered gross margin expansion of 430 basis points to a first quarter record 38.6% gross profit margin.
Looking at our entire business, given the strong first quarter performance and increasingly positive outlooks for the Southeast, most of Texas and our downstream businesses, we have raised our full year EBITDA guidance. We now anticipate a range of $1 billion to $1,050,000,000 of EBITDA with increased profitability and margin expansion expected across nearly every business line. 
The broad-based acceleration in construction recovery is visible in all 3 primary end-use markets. Again, first quarter growth was driven by large projects in the Mid-America and Southeast Groups with a 25% and a 11% increase, respectively, in infrastructure shipments. Notably, important cities in the Carolinas are enjoying the benefits of this trend. Places like Charlotte are benefiting from the new I-77 HOT lanes P3 project and ongoing work at the Charlotte Douglas International Airport. Also, Charleston, South Carolina has significant port growth as well as strong attended infrastructure development. 
Similarly, in the southeast, the long anticipated I-4 activity in Florida contributed to the positive quarter-over-quarter change. Overall, aggregates product line shipments to the infrastructure end-use market accounted for approximately 39% of our shipments and increased 13% over the prior year quarter. We are encouraged by solid growth across this end-use market resulting from state-level funding initiatives passed just last year. With the acceleration of projects in North Carolina, Georgia and Iowa, combined with another year of robust Texas Department of Transportation program lettings, we expect continued meaningful demand growth.
The nonresidential end-use market comprised of 2 components, light construction and heavy construction, accounted for 33% of quarterly aggregate shipments and increased 14% as compared with the prior year quarter. The light component is primarily office and retail, with demand generally tied to employment growth and residential demand. Consistent with the drivers, light nonresidential aggregates volumes increased 20%, led by nearly 26% growth in the Mid-America Group, following several years of modest recovery in this area of our business, strong employment growth and residential activity in North Carolina is driving increased nonresidential construction investment. The heavy nonresidential construction component is primarily industrial building as well as energy and energy-related activity. These shipments represented 24% of quarterly aggregates product line volumes and increased 12% compared with the first quarter of 2015. 
The residential market accounted for 18% of quarterly aggregates product line shipments and reported a 20% increase compared with the prior year quarter. Strength in housing activity is evident across the United States, as housing permits, starts and completions are each up more than 10% for the trailing 12 months ended March 2016. Although U.S. housing activity remains well below historic averages, the re-acceleration of growth in our key states, particularly in the Southeastern portion of the country, is expected to drive increased aggregates demand throughout the year. The ChemRock/Rail market accounted for the remaining 10% of aggregates product line volumes and increased slightly. 
Consolidated gross profit margin was nearly 20% and expanded by the previously mentioned 790 basis points over the prior year first quarter, reflecting margin expansion in all reportable segments. Robust demand and much improved weather conditions drove significant growth for the ready-mixed concrete and Cement businesses, which increased gross profit margins by 810 basis points and over 1,000 basis points respectively. 
To summarize the growth in our consolidated results, first quarter 2016 delivered record net sales of $734 million, an increase of $102 million or 16%; gross profit of $145 million, an increase of $70 million or 95%; record earnings from operations of $84 million, an increase of 228%; and EBITDA of $153 million, an increase of 67%. Net earnings growth drove a 91% increase in operating cash flow in the first quarter to $67 million compared with $35 million in the prior year quarter.
During the quarter, we repurchased an additional 1 million shares of our common stock in line with our stated capital allocation strategy. And together with our dividend, we returned $176 million to our shareholders. We have authorization to repurchase up to 20 million shares of our stock. Since the initial share repurchase authorization in February 2015, through the end of the first quarter 2016, we repurchased 4.3 million shares, returning nearly $670 million to shareholders. As a result, 15.7 million shares remain under the current authorization.
Finally, our ratio of consolidated debt to consolidated EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ended March 2016 was 2.1x, in compliance with our leverage covenant and in line with our targeted leverage of 2x.
As we also noted in today's earnings release, we have upwardly revised our 2016 guidance for aggregates volume and EBITDA. Our improved outlook reflects additional strength in underlying demand, and increased margin expansion from our original projections. We're confident that continued positive employment growth in our key markets, strong contractor backlogs and normal weather patterns would drive more than $1 billion of EBITDA in 2016, a new milestone for Martin Marietta. You will also note that we increased our expectations for public sector growth from mid-single digits to mid- to high single digit volume growth in 2016. The growth reflects continued state and/or municipal-level funding initiatives that are positively impacting several of our key states, including Texas, North Carolina, Colorado, Iowa, Georgia and Florida.
To conclude, we are very pleased with our first quarter performance and improved expectations for the balance of the year. We're positioned to deliver record results as we continue to recognize the considerable benefits of our unwavering focus on our leading positions in economically diverse, high-growth markets. We remain committed to the diligent execution of our strategic plan, steadfast to our core foundational pillars and dedicated to delivering increased shareholder value.
If the operator will now give the necessary instructions, we'll turn our attention to addressing your questions.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kathryn Thompson with Thompson Research Group.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kathryn Thompson with Thompson Research Group.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first is going to focus on the margin -- excuse me, the guidance that you gave for the quarter. First, on the end-market growth projections and then shifting to margins. But in light of Q1's results in infrastructure nonres growth rates that you outli
componenttext: The first is going to focus on the margin -- excuse me, the guidance that you gave for the quarter. First, on the end-market growth projections and then shifting to margins. But in light of Q1's results in infrastructure nonres growth rates that you outlined in your guidance and [indiscernible] you did bump up your infrastructure end-market guidance. But the projections seemed to be -- could potentially be conservative, in our view. What is your best estimate as to the pull-forward in demand from Q1 from just easy comps and extremely warm weather throughout the U.S.?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kathryn, thanks for your question. I think as we look at Q1 and we look at the rest of the year, I think the primary thing that I would say to you it's Q1. So really, we're not going to look at Q1 and let that necessarily dictate the way the entire rest o
componenttext: Kathryn, thanks for your question. I think as we look at Q1 and we look at the rest of the year, I think the primary thing that I would say to you it's Q1. So really, we're not going to look at Q1 and let that necessarily dictate the way the entire rest of the year looks. To answer your question very directly relative to what we saw as pull-forward as you recall when we ended the year last year, we thought we had probably 3.5 million to 4 million tons of aggregates that we felt like had some form of deferral because of the remarkably wet weather that we've experienced in 2015. Our best estimate is we saw about 1 million ton pull forward in Q1. Our guess is we're looking forward is that's probably not a bad number for you to think about relative to Q2 and Q3, with the number then getting marginally smaller as we go into Q4. So again, from a timing perspective, based on what we see on infrastructure, we just feel like this is the first quarter. Again, trying to address the other piece of your question, what did we see pull forward, I'll try to address very specifically what we saw in the quarter and what we anticipate in the quarters going forward.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And sticking to the theme of infrastructure and particular visibility, this is something as you know that we've been focusing on for quite sometime in certain states, some of which you noted on the call, including Georgia, North Carolina passed chan
componenttext: Okay. And sticking to the theme of infrastructure and particular visibility, this is something as you know that we've been focusing on for quite sometime in certain states, some of which you noted on the call, including Georgia, North Carolina passed changes and how states fund -- approach funding infrastructure projects. Are you seeing -- are you yet seeing the impact of those dollars flowing through? Or is it -- realistically, is this something that we'll -- you'll start seeing flowing through later this year or even into next year?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the answer is yes, Kathryn. I think it depends on the state. I mean, here's the way for you to think about it. North Carolina has put forward a bunch of bid, it could add up to $1.1 billion -- $1 billion through the biennium. And what we saw -- ac
componenttext: I think the answer is yes, Kathryn. I think it depends on the state. I mean, here's the way for you to think about it. North Carolina has put forward a bunch of bid, it could add up to $1.1 billion -- $1 billion through the biennium. And what we saw -- actually, North Carolina did that last fall, was the acceleration of about 90 projects in North Carolina. Some of those were going out as far as 2025 and even beyond. So we're seeing that type of pull-forward, not just here in our home state. We're seeing that to a degree in Georgia as well. Governor, Deal, came forward with a series of projects that he would like to see accelerated. So I think we will see some of that this year. If you recall, last year, we had seen the gas price -- the gas tax go up in Iowa. It was going to add about 30% to what that state DOT could do. We've also seen some near-term initiatives in Nebraska that will clearly be more profoundly felt next year. We've also seen good activity, not just at the state level in Colorado, but we've also seen it at the municipal level in Colorado. Colorado Springs has put some very specific plans in place that will help drive volumes. We feel like in southern Colorado, to a degree, even this year. So Kathryn, what I would say, our state and local initiatives helping in some places now? Yes. Will that continue? I think to be even more profound as we go into next year, I think the answer to that is, yes as well. Remember, to the extent that we get a benefit from the FAST Act, that's going to principally be a 2017 and after event. We will likely feel some of that in some discrete markets this year, but we will likely feel more state impact in those markets and then probably the 1, 2 impact of that beginning, more in earnest in 2017.
