headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kathryn, it's a couple of things. One, volume always helps, and more volume in the East always helps, too. So if we come and take a look at really what it happened if we're just looking at margin guidance in the Eastern United States, in particular, if we
componenttext: Kathryn, it's a couple of things. One, volume always helps, and more volume in the East always helps, too. So if we come and take a look at really what it happened if we're just looking at margin guidance in the Eastern United States, in particular, if we're seeing volumes obviously moving in a better direction in North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia, that's an awfully nice help. And the fact is if you look at incrementals for the business, we were right on target or ahead of target, if you look at the numbers that we put forward. But interestingly, if you take a look at Mid-America, that group had margin improvement to 46% versus 37% in the first quarter of last year. But here's the trick there, Kathryn. The Mid-Atlantic Division was almost 70%, Mideast was 42% and the Midwest really this time of year doesn't make any money because they're caught up in winter. So again, as we're looking at the type of improvement that we think we can see, where that's going to come from is going to matter. The other piece of it that matters is we were able to operate remarkably more efficiently in Texas simply because it was dry. So if you pull together 2 different things: One, more normalized or friendly weather, which helps; and then a certain degree of geographic mix, that helps as well. The simple fact is, Kathryn, we could do something this quarter we haven't been able to do in a while. We had a dry track to run on and we just put the reins down and let the horse go. And when you do that, those are the types of results that we think we can see.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Kathryn, it's Anne. I think, to supplement that, you would -- we saw good profitability coming out of the ready-mixed concrete business, and so that, that business line margin expanded as well as out of the Cement business. So it really was across the
componenttext: And Kathryn, it's Anne. I think, to supplement that, you would -- we saw good profitability coming out of the ready-mixed concrete business, and so that, that business line margin expanded as well as out of the Cement business. So it really was across the board. And I would say Magnesia Specialties had delivered a strong quarter. And probably slightly ahead of our expectations for the year, principally energy, our steel demand at about 70% utilization, which is a critical factor, favorable natural gas cost and then incredible cost control by that group of managers.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Timna Tanners with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Timna Tanners with Bank of America.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to get a little bit more color on the timing of the diesel tailwinds that have been helping. And assuming more flattish prices going forward, is that a factor? And maybe margins tailing off a little bit? If you could elaborate on what you're seeing
componenttext: Wanted to get a little bit more color on the timing of the diesel tailwinds that have been helping. And assuming more flattish prices going forward, is that a factor? And maybe margins tailing off a little bit? If you could elaborate on what you're seeing in diesel?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a couple of things. If you look at diesel, Timna, we use just about 10 million gallons diesel for the quarter. And if we're looking at the prices, about $1.84 a gallon. And keep in mind, that does include the cost of the fixed priced hedge that we
componenttext: I guess a couple of things. If you look at diesel, Timna, we use just about 10 million gallons diesel for the quarter. And if we're looking at the prices, about $1.84 a gallon. And keep in mind, that does include the cost of the fixed priced hedge that we have in that. So really, if we look at it and think of it in our numbers, the hedge actually gave us about a $4.5 million headwind as we're going through the quarter. As a reminder, the hedge wraps up at the end of this year. But if we also look ahead, I can give you a good sense of what the gallons looked like last year. We did 9.9 gallons -- 9.9 million Q1 this year versus 9.2 million Q1 last year. In Q2 last year, we did a little bit more than 11 million gallons. In Q3, it was almost 12 million gallons. In Q4, it was a little bit over 10.1 million for a total of almost 42.5 million gallons. So that will give you a sense of it. The other thing that I would say is if we're looking back to Q1 last year, diesel is at $2.04 versus $1.84 this year. And if somebody had told us last year in Q1 that we would still have energy as a tailwind and a friend overall, I am not sure I would have believed it, but here we are.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. On the Specialty -- On the Magnesia segment, I'm -- I was a little confused by the comments because steel demand is pretty low, as you've mentioned, and then you had a pretty solid results. So just wondering is that a structural chan
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. On the Specialty -- On the Magnesia segment, I'm -- I was a little confused by the comments because steel demand is pretty low, as you've mentioned, and then you had a pretty solid results. So just wondering is that a structural change? Have you done some cost cutting? Or does this mean that you can have higher profitability at a lower steel utilization going forward?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you think about it, Timna, the primary thing that we've said are 2 things really drive that business. If you got steel utilization at 70% or better, and if you got natural gas prices that are well behaved, those 2 things will help that business pretty
componenttext: If you think about it, Timna, the primary thing that we've said are 2 things really drive that business. If you got steel utilization at 70% or better, and if you got natural gas prices that are well behaved, those 2 things will help that business pretty considerably. If we're looking at what the cost of nat gas was, that was down about 32% for the quarter. So nat gas was giving that a tailwind. But even while steel was down 2.5% versus where it was last quarter, it was still at that 70% number that Anne referenced in the last conversation that we were just having with Kathryn. And candidly, 70% isn't an overheated number. I mean, we built that business with our very capable team, recognizing that 70 was probably a pretty safe number to have out there. And look, are we awfully proud of staying margins at 38% when you got steel at 70%? I think those are tremendous numbers, and I think that team really should take about. So while we're pleased with those results, I would say very pleased. Have we changed anything structurally? The answer is no. We really built it to make sure that those levels would operate very well with where we wanted to take the business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, and just to supplement that, Timna, the dolomitic line really is the principal product that goes into the steel industry. The Mag-Chem Business is actually seeing some good, solid demand across really all of the geographies that we serve, which is,
componenttext: Well, and just to supplement that, Timna, the dolomitic line really is the principal product that goes into the steel industry. The Mag-Chem Business is actually seeing some good, solid demand across really all of the geographies that we serve, which is, as a reminder, that is in the international business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And if I could one last one. I just wanted to know if you could characterize what you're seeing in M&A because there's been some small deals and, obviously, your cash position is great. So just wanted to -- or your balance sheet position in g
componenttext: Okay, great. And if I could one last one. I just wanted to know if you could characterize what you're seeing in M&A because there's been some small deals and, obviously, your cash position is great. So just wanted to -- or your balance sheet position in general. Wanted to just get a sense of how you're seeing that M&A environment for now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Timna. We have a very busy team and strategy and development. So they are looking at a number of different transactions today. I think what you saw us announce at the end of last year, what you've seen us announce earlier this year, are the typ
componenttext: Thank you, Timna. We have a very busy team and strategy and development. So they are looking at a number of different transactions today. I think what you saw us announce at the end of last year, what you've seen us announce earlier this year, are the types of bolt-on transactions that you should expect us to continue to look at. Specifically, I'm talking about what we did in Southern Colorado simply as an example. Those are markets that we feel like we're going to be attractive near term and long term. So you should expect us to be active, looking forward though importantly the right deals. Because I think, we're in a coveted space. I think we're in a spot that we can participate in deals. We can add synergy to those deals. But we're also in a space that we can buy back our shares as well. And they're not a lot of companies who can do that 1-2 punch that we can offer right now. So that's our take on M&A as it pertains to third parties and M&A as it pertains to ourselves.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to dig a little bit on the gross profit guidance within the aggregates product line, if I could. You raised your volume guidance by about 1.5 million tons, cut the pricing guidance the same, but the profit guidance was raised by about $55 millio
componenttext: Just want to dig a little bit on the gross profit guidance within the aggregates product line, if I could. You raised your volume guidance by about 1.5 million tons, cut the pricing guidance the same, but the profit guidance was raised by about $55 million. So if you take the volume increase and apply the full drop-through, it will be about $20 million. So I was just wondering if you can maybe provide a little bit of color, you talked about efficiencies, you talked about geographic mix. But how should we think about the -- maybe the $35 million bridge from the growth in revenues versus the growth in profits that you're expecting?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Garik, I think you fit the 2 drivers very candidly, and I think we anticipate if we have normal weather, the efficiencies will be much better. And that's a powerful lever. I don't want to undersell that lever. I think, candidly, the more powerful lever ri
componenttext: Garik, I think you fit the 2 drivers very candidly, and I think we anticipate if we have normal weather, the efficiencies will be much better. And that's a powerful lever. I don't want to undersell that lever. I think, candidly, the more powerful lever right now is what's going on in Georgia, what's going on in Florida, what's going in South Carolina and what's going on in North Carolina. And keep in mind, what you haven't really seen in any significant material way yet is what we feel like is going to be a pretty busy year in Indianapolis in our Mideast business, and is likely to be a very busy year in our Midwest business as well. Garik, as I sit here and really just think about our aggregates business and take a measure of it, what I would say to you is, it wouldn't surprise me at the end of the year to have a record year in the Rocky Mountain division. It wouldn't surprise me to have a record year in our Midwest division. I think we're going to have a record year in our Southwest division. We're going to have a remarkably better year in our Southeast division, and we're going to have remarkably better year in our Mid-Atlantic division. And candidly, it's possible to have a record year in our Mideast division. So if you're thinking about those different divisions, which ones of those are pure aggregates and the sheer number of those that are now transitioning to the Eastern half of the United States, I think that type of activity, both from an infrastructure perspective and frankly other perspectives, combined with higher efficiencies, really drives that delta that you're seeing in profitability.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Garik, just to add a little color to that, our first quarter margins of 20% and drilling down into the aggregates business even more, we actually had some acceleration of stripping cost and repair and maintenance cost in the first quarter as our teams
componenttext: And Garik, just to add a little color to that, our first quarter margins of 20% and drilling down into the aggregates business even more, we actually had some acceleration of stripping cost and repair and maintenance cost in the first quarter as our teams in the field are prepping for what they think -- for the backlog that's out there for the balance of the year. So part of that margin expansion and efficiency do come from a lot of those costs that have been incurred. And as Ward said, ready to let the horse run.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That sounds good. Just wanted to follow up on Cement. It seems like you won back market share in the first quarter. Just wondering, how you feel are your market share is positioned right now as you look in the Texas Cement market through the remainder of
componenttext: That sounds good. Just wanted to follow up on Cement. It seems like you won back market share in the first quarter. Just wondering, how you feel are your market share is positioned right now as you look in the Texas Cement market through the remainder of the year? Then also you did reduce your Cement pricing guidance. So I just wanted to see on how you're anticipating the April price increases to go and what that means with respect to the market share question that I asked previously?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess a couple of things, Garik. If we go back to the conversation that we had in February, I think, in large part, the first quarter, I think the term we used was shaking out. It's probably shaking out about the way that we thought that it would.
componenttext: Sure. I guess a couple of things, Garik. If we go back to the conversation that we had in February, I think, in large part, the first quarter, I think the term we used was shaking out. It's probably shaking out about the way that we thought that it would. I think, we said we've got -- it would be an easier or better pricing environment in North Texas, that it was going to be in South Texas. I think that's been entirely true. The Comptroller is very helpful in putting out the different numbers that marketplace can see. That 21% market share or in that ZIP Code is not a place that we think is a bad place for our business to be. I've also referenced the fact that we, I believe, can be a remarkably efficient producer of cement in that marketplace as well. I think one reason that you saw a modest pullback perhaps in the pricing is, we've seen relatively good activity on volumes that you saw. And what we've also done is we've had some wholesale sales, particularly in that North Texas market to other producers that are in that marketplace. And the wholesale prices clearly go at a different number. So if I'm looking at probably about 40,000 tons that we sold in the quarter that were wholesale tons, and then take a look at really what were some product mix issues, simply -- really selling more customers picking a product, FOB, the plant, and I would say that was more driven in South Texas than it was driven in North Texas, and then back to -- as we discussed in February, there are some competitive dynamics there that we're sensitive to. I think when you tally those together, it brings you to the point that you see in the full results. What I believe is if we have the weather in Texas that I think we're going to have, I think we're likely to have a very active year in Texas. I like the way I'm seeing our ready-mixed business run, right there. I'd like to what I'm seeing other ready-mixed businesses run in Texas right now. I think the fact is, it's pretty conceivable that you could have cement shortages in Texas as we get to the main part of the year. And I'll let you draw your own conclusions on what that may mean relative to cement pricing going forward. Again, as we're looking in this business from an efficiency perspective, on pricing and really running it for profitability, I'm very comfortable with where that is. The other thing that's interesting to me, Garik, is to see what's going on with cement pricing in other parts of the United States as well. So if I'm looking in places like Colorado, or the Carolinas or otherwise, I'm seeing cement prices in those markets that are at times $25 or more a ton of where we sit in Texas right now, which gives me a sense we've got some nice runway ahead of us on this. But keep in mind, as we take a look at where we sit on pricing in cement in Texas today, we're 20% up in South Texas from where the prices were when we combined with TXI, and we're 30% up in North Texas of where prices were. So I have tried to give you some context. I apologize for the length of my response, but I think the context is important.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk about how you expect the pricing cadence to play out over the course of this year? Last year, you opted for major price increase on January 1. And I'm wondering if you see potential for a sequential price increases this yea
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk about how you expect the pricing cadence to play out over the course of this year? Last year, you opted for major price increase on January 1. And I'm wondering if you see potential for a sequential price increases this year as we go through the year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then we're talking aggregates here?
componenttext: And then we're talking aggregates here?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: In aggregates, yes.
componenttext: In aggregates, yes.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I look at aggregates pricing, here's what I would say. We've got 17 out of 20 districts where it's just remarkably positive. We've got almost half of those where it's up at least $1 a ton and several districts where we're up $2 a ton. So we're see
componenttext: Yes. As I look at aggregates pricing, here's what I would say. We've got 17 out of 20 districts where it's just remarkably positive. We've got almost half of those where it's up at least $1 a ton and several districts where we're up $2 a ton. So we're seeing nice price movement in really important markets. The only markets where we're not seeing remarkable price movement, it's fascinating to me, we got some freight adjustments that we had to do in some, and we simply have some mix issues in others. So I am looking quarry by quarry, product by product. I'm seeing good price increases in all of those. But I would say, too, Jerry, is we're in a marketplace where volumes continue to go up. So pricing, as you know, having botched the scope of the cycle behaved exceptionally well even in a down market. From where I'm sitting right now, Jerry, I think trying to measure it going forward if F.W. Dodge is a good indicator. Dodge right now is looking at 3 good years ahead of us right now. We probably would have said the same thing last year, and that was before we ended up with the 5-year Highway Bill. So as we're sitting here, Jerry, I think the rhythm and cadence of price increases this year won't be dramatically different than they were last year, for example. I think they've been very strong so far. I think you're going to have a geographic mix that's going to give a tailwind to the way pricing is looking. But I also think that what we said for the last couple of years is entirely true, and that is the Western United States, on a percentage basis, has more pricing power ahead of it than does the East simply because the East is a more mature market, prices are higher so your percentage is up, won't be as great. But again as North Carolina continues to recover, as Georgia continues to recover, as Florida continues to recover and as places like Dallas-Fort Worth, as I referenced in my opening comments, have the type of volume growth and pricing growth that they're experiencing, the pricing story we think will continue to be a very good one, not just for a matter of quarters, probably for a matter of years.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ward you've commented in the past, that based on the reserve position in Colorado and Dallas markets where you participate, you would look for aggregates pricing to approach company average pricing over time. Can you just give us an update on where th
componenttext: And Ward you've commented in the past, that based on the reserve position in Colorado and Dallas markets where you participate, you would look for aggregates pricing to approach company average pricing over time. Can you just give us an update on where that stands today and how much do you think the gap could narrow in '17?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, absolutely. If you recall, when we were looking at the transactions in Texas, particularly in North Texas, I want to say at the day in the hour, those prices were about 60% of the corporate average. As we look at it today, it's about 75% of the corpor
componenttext: No, absolutely. If you recall, when we were looking at the transactions in Texas, particularly in North Texas, I want to say at the day in the hour, those prices were about 60% of the corporate average. As we look at it today, it's about 75% of the corporate average. And what we have spoken [indiscernible] of it at that time, Jerry, is we thought it would probably take about 3 years for that to build to something that felt more like a corporate average. I think that's still not a bad place for us to be as we look at it. The other thing that I would tell you is really, with starting last year, that we saw aggregate pricing in Colorado start to move on percentages that were really better than what you we're seeing across the corporate average. Now do I think Colorado is going to be there from a time perspective at the same time as Texas is? No, I don't. It's going to move a little bit more slowly than Texas. But I still think probably over a 5-year period. Basically, over what we look at is our strategic planning period. Colorado should be closing in on it. Texas very much should be there. Is that responsive, Jerry?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You also saw obviously the West Group pricing dynamics and that's where the Dallas market and the Colorado market would be reported. And I think you can continue to expect those area -- that area of the country that segment to report pricing at a hig
componenttext: Yes. You also saw obviously the West Group pricing dynamics and that's where the Dallas market and the Colorado market would be reported. And I think you can continue to expect those area -- that area of the country that segment to report pricing at a higher rate than the balance of the country or the corporate average.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's super helpful. And lastly, I'm wondering if you could talk about what proportion of your sales were out of your long-haul network within aggregates this quarter compared to last year and how do you expect the full year mix to look like, long-
componenttext: Okay. That's super helpful. And lastly, I'm wondering if you could talk about what proportion of your sales were out of your long-haul network within aggregates this quarter compared to last year and how do you expect the full year mix to look like, long-haul versus truck-served markets for you.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, Jerry, I'd rather not go into specific percentages on that. What I'll tell you for example though is the yards that we have in Florida right now are really some of the best businesses that we have in the East. So if you think about what's g
componenttext: You know what, Jerry, I'd rather not go into specific percentages on that. What I'll tell you for example though is the yards that we have in Florida right now are really some of the best businesses that we have in the East. So if you think about what's going on in Florida, and if you think about what's going on in South Texas coming out of that new Medina Rock & Rail facility, those businesses to us look better than they did last year. And when we come back and take a look at the full year, my guess is those are probably going to be somewhere in the teens overall from a volume perspective. Keep in mind, what we move by rail in the United States all by itself, ignoring everything else that's shipped by truck or otherwise, is the top 10 aggregates producer in the United States. So it's a considerable piece of the business, but the areas that we have that business, it's performing exactly as we would have thought, maybe modestly ahead.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Armstrong with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Armstrong with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, you talked about weather a little bit and if the weather holds up. What are you seeing in Texas, in the South in general following the storms? Did that have any impact in the first quarter at all? And do you think it will impact the sec
componenttext: My first question, you talked about weather a little bit and if the weather holds up. What are you seeing in Texas, in the South in general following the storms? Did that have any impact in the first quarter at all? And do you think it will impact the second quarter any -- on a volume basis?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what, the first quarter was relatively benign, and I would say not that negatively weather-impacted. Now it varies. April is pretty wet. I mean, you saw pretty massive flooding in places like Houston and this's that slow work down for a while? Ye
componenttext: You know what, the first quarter was relatively benign, and I would say not that negatively weather-impacted. Now it varies. April is pretty wet. I mean, you saw pretty massive flooding in places like Houston and this's that slow work down for a while? Yes, it does. At the same time, you're close enough to the Gulf in areas like Houston that you tend to have areas that can dry out relatively well, particularly if they have a windy circumstance. So I'll put it this way, James. May is an important month. It always has been. The 2 months in the aggregates business that tend to be disproportionately important are May and October. May, because this is the first time across the geographic footprint that you have every bit of your business usually really hitting on almost all cylinders and October because that's the last month that, a, it's usually dry and a lot of contractors feel like by the time they get to Thanksgiving, in many respects, they'll be packing up their equipment for the year. So was April a wet month? Yes, it was. Does May need to be a relatively dry month for the industry? Yes, I would tell you that it does.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Extremely helpful. And then just coming back to ancient history hopefully at this point. Any leftovers from fracking falling off? Or was that pretty much completely gone at this level? And what are you seeing in that market?
componenttext: Extremely helpful. And then just coming back to ancient history hopefully at this point. Any leftovers from fracking falling off? Or was that pretty much completely gone at this level? And what are you seeing in that market?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, thank you for the question on that. I want to be really clear because, really, what we sell in the marketplace to the different shale energy plays, just to be clear, is not frac material. So we're selling materials to the shale energy players,
componenttext: And again, thank you for the question on that. I want to be really clear because, really, what we sell in the marketplace to the different shale energy plays, just to be clear, is not frac material. So we're selling materials to the shale energy players, who are building roads or building their pads. I want to make sure we're clear on that. What we had indicated we thought is that we would see relatively maintenance levels of stone going to these different shale plays of the United States. And what we said is for the year we thought that would probably be in the zip code of 2 million tons or about 0.5 million tons a quarter. That's what we viewed as maintenance. So actually, as we come back and take a look at exactly where we are in Q1, what -- it's good to be right. And we were right on that. So I guess we'll take that. We'll take being right. I'm sorry. It's 500,000 tons. I'd love to see 3x that because that's where we were last year.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Adam Thalhimer with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adam Thalhimer with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kind of following up on that. The heavy nonres, you had some nice growth in the quarter, and I think that's a change from previously. Was that due to some of the awards you talked about earlier this year?
componenttext: Kind of following up on that. The heavy nonres, you had some nice growth in the quarter, and I think that's a change from previously. Was that due to some of the awards you talked about earlier this year?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You know what it is. It's not that much of a change for us because a lot of what we're seeing is driven by work that we're seeing, not just in South Texas. And that's where a lot of it is. But we're seeing good, nice, nonres in portions of South Caro
componenttext: Yes. You know what it is. It's not that much of a change for us because a lot of what we're seeing is driven by work that we're seeing, not just in South Texas. And that's where a lot of it is. But we're seeing good, nice, nonres in portions of South Carolina. In fact, I call it out South Carolina specifically on some infrastructure in our prepared remarks. But we're seeing good nonres in that market. We're also seeing good nonres in Dallas, in Denver, in Orlando, in College Station in Texas as well. So the nonres that we're seeing looks pretty good. I think one data point that's probably worth knowing is 6 of the Martin Marietta states rank in the top 10 for growth in nonres starts. And 2 of those states include Florida and Colorado. I think a lot of it, Adam, really comes back to this notion that we discussed, I think a lot over the last couple of years because we were hoping that it would come to fruition the way that it has where you are matters. And as we're looking at the states in which we have leading positions, and keep in mind, those leading positions today, 1 or 2, are in 85% versus 65% of our markets 5 years ago. We've tried to position ourselves in states that have near-term and long-term growth and they tend to have multiple economic drivers in them as well. So again, I don't think the nonres story is dramatically different. But we are seeing some of those very large projects, for example, in South Texas firm up and we're sticking those backlogs even more capably in our pocket right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're still staying projects to bid on the heavy side? Or...
componenttext: So you're still staying projects to bid on the heavy side? Or...

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I mean, what I would tell you is, with our teams, both in Martin Marietta as well as our customer base, probably feel as optimistic right now as I have seen people feel in about 10 years. And I think a lot of that's driven by the fact that the
componenttext: Absolutely. I mean, what I would tell you is, with our teams, both in Martin Marietta as well as our customer base, probably feel as optimistic right now as I have seen people feel in about 10 years. And I think a lot of that's driven by the fact that the Eastern United States lag the West not by a matter of months, but really by a matter of years in coming back with some degree of nonres projects in particular. And keep in mind, a lot of times we said those projects will follow varying degrees of housing recovery with a 9- to 18-month lag. And if we continue to see permits, starts and completions on housing, all in those double digits, and we also continue to see single-family housing ramp up, that's going to be more aggregate-intensive and we're going to see the nonres, both light and heavy, I think continue to follow that in a very constructive manner.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Adam, one of the things that we've seen pretty consistently across the footprint is a lot of distribution activity, distribution centers and channels like that. I would say uniformly across the footprint. That's been at accelerated level of activ
componenttext: I think, Adam, one of the things that we've seen pretty consistently across the footprint is a lot of distribution activity, distribution centers and channels like that. I would say uniformly across the footprint. That's been at accelerated level of activity over the past several months or at least reported activity that's on its way down the pipe.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then just lastly on the -- And I don't know how fair this question is, but can you compare at all the FAST Act to the state-level initiatives? Just trying to get a sense for what's coming in '17 from the FAST Act versus what we
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then just lastly on the -- And I don't know how fair this question is, but can you compare at all the FAST Act to the state-level initiatives? Just trying to get a sense for what's coming in '17 from the FAST Act versus what we've got in '16 from the state-level initiatives.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know what I would say is this, I don't want to go into '17 volume share as we look at it. But what I would say is, you're going to see states continue to let more long-term, aggregate-intensive projects over the next several years than they have over
componenttext: You know what I would say is this, I don't want to go into '17 volume share as we look at it. But what I would say is, you're going to see states continue to let more long-term, aggregate-intensive projects over the next several years than they have over the last several years. And I do think the FAST Act will give states who have not been coming up with very specific state initiatives, a lot more runway than they've had for a while. I think the real blessing we're going to have, though, if you really pause and reflect on the key states for us, that will have both. I mean think of it in these terms. Colorado is going to have both. Separate and distinct from what's going on in Colorado Springs. Iowa has both. Nebraska has both. Texas has both. Remember, the extra funding that comes into Texas is just from Prop 7, by the time we get to September 2017, is more money than the increase on a per annum basis than you see even the FAST Act. So the FAST Act is nice because it does put dollars there. But the primary component of the FAST Act is going to be helpful is time. So what's going to happen, you're going to take extra state dollars and combine that with extra time from the Fed. It's going to be the confluence of those 2 factors that will be more profound, particularly beginning in '17 and then in the out years.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Betts with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Betts with Jefferies.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My 2 questions, please. You sounded pretty positive on aggregate prices, Ward. But the average $13.04 in Q1, that the guidance for the year is only $12.75 to $13. So pretty flat. Is there some change going on that you'd expect to offset some of the, maybe
componenttext: My 2 questions, please. You sounded pretty positive on aggregate prices, Ward. But the average $13.04 in Q1, that the guidance for the year is only $12.75 to $13. So pretty flat. Is there some change going on that you'd expect to offset some of the, maybe underlying growth later in the year? Or I just being maybe too picky by comparing those numbers? And then secondly, I don't see we talked much about the asphalt business. I mean, could you remind me what sort of made your divestment that impacted that volume number? And secondly, your old firm is commenting yesterday, it is going to be much more difficult business this year because the escalator clauses were going to kick in or the adjustment clauses, which would impact -- which would mean that the lower bitumen price would seep through and therefore there will be less pricing power. Does that impact you at all?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, Mike, I would never call you being too picky for asking the questions. That's not a problem. What I would say is this, when you look at Q1, don't ever take Q1 in a vacuum as really a good litmus test on exactly what's going on in prici
componenttext: Well, first of all, Mike, I would never call you being too picky for asking the questions. That's not a problem. What I would say is this, when you look at Q1, don't ever take Q1 in a vacuum as really a good litmus test on exactly what's going on in pricing. Going back to the conversation that we had a few minutes ago, the Midwest is not cranking during Q1. The Middle East is not cranking into Q1. So what you're seeing in Q1 is a lot of North Carolina, South Carolina, Florida, all of which in the Eastern U.S. are pretty high-priced markets. And then you're obviously seeing pricing in Texas, particularly North Texas, move at very nice percentages. So what I would tell you is you're going to continue to see good robust pricing. But what's going to happen is when Mideast, which is principally Indiana and Ohio, and the Midwest, which is principally Iowa and Minnesota and Nebraska come in. Those tend to be more corporate average-y on pricing. So again, I think we feel very comfortable with the percentages that we put out there. To your question an asphalt. Here is the way I would think of it, if we look at asphalt, we did about 2.1 million tons of asphalt last year in the Rocky Mountain division. As you really look at it now, that's the only asphalt that we have left. So we did sell, frankly, a pretty modest asphalt position that we had around the San Antonio marketplace. So the fact that we don't have that business anymore is not going to be a dramatic driver or not on what we're seeing relative to our business. With respect to liquid asphalt or bitumen and where it is, Mike, my guess is that story is going to change a lot back to what I've said before, depending on where you are in the marketplace. Here is the circumstance, up and down the Front Range in Colorado. And when I speak to the Front Range, I'm really talking about the I-25 corridor that's where 80% of the people who live in Colorado reside. That market is very, very busy right now on public. It's very, very busy on private res and nonres. And in large parts, you've got a good asphalt market, particularly on subdivision side and on the infrastructure side. And a lot of the work in Colorado, particularly 1 year, 1.5 years ago was having to be lead a couple, some times, more times because they weren't having enough bidders who're available. That's going to be a tight market relative to aggregate. It's going to be a tight market relative to contractors, who are able to do much of that work. And again, I think it's we're looking at our asphalt business that is principally a Colorado asphalt business, we feel pretty good about it. Now relative to your question on how it did do in the first quarter, it didn't really do much in the first quarter. And we don't expect it to do much in the first quarter. Again, because you are there in the Rocky Mountains. If we're looking at what asphalt sales were for us both internally and externally in the first quarter, it was 134,000 tons versus 147,000 tons in the prior year. And the 147,000 tons in the prior year had the Texas business in it as well.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: No, no. The 147,000 excludes the Texas business. So Mike, from an asphalt tonnage perspective, it was about 123,000 tons in the first quarter of 2015 related to that divested business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, Craig, I think the big issue that was going on there is we got rained on all last year. I mean the ready-mixed business that really you are looking at when you look at these numbers is what's going on in Texas. And in Texas, just really never h
componenttext: Yes -- no, Craig, I think the big issue that was going on there is we got rained on all last year. I mean the ready-mixed business that really you are looking at when you look at these numbers is what's going on in Texas. And in Texas, just really never had the ability to show last year what it can do. So again, as you're looking at volume is up 31%, the pricing is up 12%, you can see what's happened with gross profit. Again, I think this is really more of a story that candidly we're not that surprised by. We think we've got a very good position in ready-mix, both in Texas and in Colorado. I'm particularly pleased to see what we're doing in Texas, though, relative to the EBITDA. Because part of what we've said before, we would like to see those margins in Texas approach what we see in margins in Colorado. So if we're looking at EBITDA-ish this year in the Southwest of $38 million, if we're able to do in the Southwest on margins what we've been seeing ourselves doing in Colorado, that could translate at the right day in the right hour to about $75 million in gross margins. So it's a -- one, it was a very good story in the first quarter. Two, we expect it to be a good story for the rest of the year, but we also expect to see that Texas business continue to do better.

componenttext: It was seeing volume go through. It was seeing really, the plant capacities working in large part and the 80%-ish. headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you again for joining our first quarter 2016 earnings call. We're poised for a great 2016. We continue to experience strong employment growth in our key markets, robust construction activity with increased materials demand and significant pricing op
componenttext: Thank you again for joining our first quarter 2016 earnings call. We're poised for a great 2016. We continue to experience strong employment growth in our key markets, robust construction activity with increased materials demand and significant pricing opportunities. Many view the current United States construction market as among the world's best. Martin Marietta's superior geographic positions and focused execution of it's strategic plan should provide a firm foundation, enhancing long-term shareholder value. We look forward to seeing many of you next week at our 2016 Investor and Analyst Day in Dallas and to discussing our second quarter results with you in August. Until then, take care. Thank you very much.
