headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta Q2 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded.I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr.
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta Q2 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Ward Nye, Chairman and CEO.  You may begin, sir.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. To facilitate today's discussion, we've made available during this webcast
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Martin Marietta's quarterly earnings call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
To facilitate today's discussion, we've made available during this webcast and on our website supplemental financial information which we believe will be helpful. As detailed specifically on Slide 2, please remember that today's teleconference may include forward-looking statements as defined by securities laws in connection with future events or future operating or financial performance. Like other businesses, we're subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially. Except as legally required, we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether resulting from new information, future developments or otherwise. We refer you to the legal disclaimers contained in our second quarter earnings release and other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are available on both our own and the SEC websites. 
Also, as a reminder, any margin references in our discussion are based on net sales and exclude freight and delivery revenues. These and other non-GAAP measures are explained in our supplemental financial information on our website and in our SEC filings. 
As detailed in our release distributed earlier this morning, Martin Marietta delivered strong top line and bottom line growth in a record-setting second quarter. These results were driven by broad-based gains across the majority of the company's geographic footprint.
Importantly, this was enabled by our strategic approach of developing leading positions in markets along higher growth corridors possessing attractive near and long-term economic characteristics.
For the quarter, we delivered record net sales of $915 million, an increase of 8% or $65 million gain over the second quarter of last year. That increase, combined with an improvement in our gross margin, led to record gross profit and net earnings. In fact, gross profit increased $47 million and net earnings increased $40 million, respectively. These outstanding results underscore the earnings power of our business model as well as the overall health of our markets and demonstrate our ability to capitalize on improving economic conditions.
Consolidated gross profit margin expanded 340 basis points to nearly 27% and diluted earnings per share of $1.90 increased 56%, both compared with the prior year quarter. The efficiencies achieved by our steadfast commitment to operational excellence is also evident and in -- that on a consolidated basis for every $1 in net sales, our operations delivered $0.71 of additional gross profit, above our stated target of 60%.
As will be expanded upon in a moment, we're pleased to note that in addition to increased volume, widespread pricing improvement contributed significantly to the quarter's results. Aggregates product line pricing increased 7%, led by the West Group's 10% growth with notable strength across our Texas and Colorado footprints. The ready-mixed concrete business delivered a 15% increase in pricing, again, with strength in both Texas and Colorado, led by robust pricing along the I-35 corridor, running from North to South through Dallas, Austin and San Antonio, Texas.
Despite the near-term threefold impact of adverse weather conditions, declining railroad balanced volumes and lower direct shale energy shipments, our aggregates product line delivered volume growth of 1.3%.
During the quarter, poor weather in our top markets nearly rivaled that experience in the second quarter 2015. We faced extremely wet conditions particularly in the first 2 months of the second quarter in many of our key states, including Texas and the Carolinas as shown in the divisional precipitation mass on Slide 5.
As forecasted by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the El Niño weather pattern, which began in the second quarter of 2015 continued through May 2016. What does that mean? Last year, we reported that enough rain fell in Texas to meet New York City's water needs for 7 years. This May, the National Weather Service reported 35 trillion gallons of rain fell in Texas, enough to cover the entire state in water 8 inches deep.
This rainfall led to extreme flooding due to saturated land conditions from an already very wet spring. Saturated soils are significant impediment to new construction activity. 
The Mid-America Group led the company with a nearly 5% increase in aggregates product line shipments driven by acceleration of residential and nonresidential construction activity across the Carolinas. The Southeast Group shipments increased nearly 2%. Large infrastructure projects in Georgia and Florida were catalyst for growth in the Southeast Group, but were partially offset by lower balanced shipments. The West Group, where shipments were affected by heavy rainfall, reported a 3% decline, including the volumes related to the recently completed Colorado acquisitions.
In addition to weather-deferred shipments, the West Group aggregate product line volumes were impacted by decline in shale-related shipments, delays associated with several Texas Department of Transportation projects and lower balanced sales due to reduced capital and maintenance expenditures by railroads as highlighted in recent press releases from that industry group.  These factors drove the West Group's negative volume comparison to prior year.
Overall, aggregates shipments for the first half of 2016 increased over 6%, in line with our full year expectations. The pace and trajectory of volume increases are particularly visible along the high-growth corridors to the Carolinas, Georgia and into Florida.
As anticipated, economic recovery in the Southeastern United States is accelerating.
For example, Georgia's net tax revenue collections through this past May compared to last year's comparable period were up nearly 10% or $1.7 billion.
Further, product demand in portions of the Carolinas have us considering adding work shifts to better serve customer needs. We expect continued steady construction growth in this important part of our geography to complement expansion in other regions of the country.
The ready-mixed concrete product line is benefiting from strong demand in North Texas and Colorado. Robust volumes, combined with improved cost performance, together with modestly improving operating conditions, drove 43% increase in net sales and a 560 basis point expansion of gross margin. The expectation remains for our Texas ready-mixed concrete profit margins to continue to improve similar to the pattern experienced in our Colorado-based business. We view the results for the 6 months of the year as confirmation that our expectations are well-placed.
For the second quarter, the Cement business generated nearly $60 million of net sales and $24 million of gross profit, representing a 40% gross margin. Note that as a result of the September 2015 sale of our California Cement business, comparability of results for this segment will be affected throughout the year. The 2015 impact of the California Cement operations is detailed on Slide 6.
Lastly, the Magnesia Specialties business delivered another solid quarter, with second quarter net sales of nearly $59 million. Our continued focus on diligently managing the cost profile of the business led to a gross profit margin of 36.8%, an expansion of 170 basis points versus the prior year second quarter.
Varying degrees of construction recovery are visible in all 3 primary end-use markets. Infrastructure shipments accounted for approximately 43% of our aggregates' volume and increased 1.3% over the prior year quarter, driven by large projects in the Southeast Group.
Notably, the acceleration of projects in the Atlanta market along the I-95 and I-75 corridors in addition to continued I-4 activity in Central Florida enabled positive quarter-over-quarter growth despite the impact of weather delayed shipments in the Mid-America and West Groups.
Importantly, we continue to see increasing demand across this end-use market and remain confident in its study and meaningful growth particularly as we move into 2017 and begin to see and enjoy the benefits of increased federal highway spending under the FAST Act and the multiple state initiatives. Among them, the Texas Department of Transportation plans to spend $70 billion on its highway from 2017 to 2026, especially in the growing Martin Marietta metro areas such as Dallas, San Antonio, Austin and Houston, doubling the prior decade's record investment level. 
The nonresidential end-use market comprised of 2 components: light construction and heavy construction accounted for 33% of aggregate shipments in the quarter and increased 2.8% compared with the prior year quarter. The light component is primarily office and retail construction with demand generally tied to employment growth and residential demand. While the heavy nonresidential component is primarily industrial building as well as energy and energy-related activity.
Growth in the nonresidential end-use market was led by an approximate 14% increase in the Mid-America Group, driven by office and retail development in North Carolina resulting from continued employment gains and solid residential activity.
The residential market accounted for 17% of quarterly aggregates product line shipments and reported a nearly 11% increase compared with prior year quarter. Strength in housing activity is evident across the United States as starts and completions are each up considerably for the trailing 12 months ended June 2016.
While U.S. housing activity remains well below historic averages, the re-acceleration of growth in our key states, particularly in the Southeastern portion of the country, is expected to drive increased aggregates demand throughout the remainder of the year. 
The ChemRock/Rail market accounted for the remaining 7% of aggregates product line volumes, which decreased compared to the prior year quarter as a result of reduced ballast sales. 
In addition to our quarterly results presented in today's earnings release, we also provided 2 updates to portions of our previously provided guidance.
First, SG&A guidance of $220 million has been increased to a range of $225 million to $230 million. This modest change is primarily related to the timing and value share-based compensation.
Second, the company's guidance on 2016 cement pricing change, current expectations are for full year increase of 2% to 4%. This change lowered our full year outlook for the Cement business' net sales by $10 million and results primarily from the sharp downturn in energy and energy-related activity.  We believe markets have now broadly stabilized and anticipate healthier pricing momentum as the company benefits from its leading positions in high-growth Texas regions.
To summarize, our consolidated second quarter results by virtually every meaningful and controllable metric, Martin Marietta delivered a very strong quarter, highlighted by record net sales, record gross profit and record net earnings.
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, depletion and amortization, was over $266 million for the quarter, an increase of $60 million. EBITDA as a percentage of net sales, excluding freight and delivery revenues, expanded 478 basis points to over 29%, approaching our prior peak level of EBITDA margin on 20% fewer times.
During the quarter, we repurchased an additional 215,000 shares of our common stock for $40 million. And together with our dividend, we returned $66 million to our shareholders. 
We have authorization to repurchase up to 20 million shares of our stock. Since the initial share repurchase authorization in February 2015 through the end of the second quarter 2016, we repurchased 4.5 million shares, which, coupled with our sustained dividend, returned $869 million to shareholders.
As a result, 15.5 million shares remain under the current authorization. 
Finally, our ratio of consolidated net debt to consolidated EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ended June 2016 was 1.98x in compliance with our leverage covenant and in line with our targeted leverage of 2x.
As we look forward to the balance of the year and beyond, we expect continued steady growth in construction activity in our markets. Both Dodge and PCA forecast growth in construction starts for the balance of 2016 and the next several years. The Dodge Momentum Index, which measures the initial report of nonresidential construction projects and tends to lead nonresidential construction spending by one full year, increased over 11% in June to 134.4, its highest level since early 2009.
Residential construction permits starts and completions remains strong. Infrastructure activity should continue to accelerate as the FAST Act and other state initiatives drive increased construction of highways, streets, roads and bridges.
Strong employment gains would serve as a key indicator of economic growth underpinned the construction forecast. In fact, of our key states Florida ranks second nationally in job growth; Texas ranks third; Georgia ranks fourth and North Carolina ranks eighth.
A host of key metropolitan areas in our markets had employment gains above 3%, including Dallas and Austin, Texas; Atlanta, Georgia; Orlando, Tampa and Jacksonville, Florida; Raleigh, North Carolina and Charleston, South Carolina. 
To conclude, we are very pleased with our second quarter performance, and we're well positioned to deliver solid results in the last half of the year. We will continue to realize the considerable benefits of our superior geographic positions, operating in markets that are economically diverse and high-growth. We remain committed to the diligent execution of our strategic plan, steadfast to our core foundation of pillars of operational excellence, cost discipline, customer satisfaction and sustainability and dedicated to delivering increased shareholder value. 
If the operator will now give the required instructions, we'll turn our attention to addressing your questions.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kathryn Thompson with Thompson Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Kathryn Thompson with Thompson Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first is really more on volumes and backlogs, in particular. Could you give more color on backlogs, particularly in areas affected by weather in the quarter? And how much do you think is the volume shortfall in the quarter was driven by weather and or
componenttext: The first is really more on volumes and backlogs, in particular. Could you give more color on backlogs, particularly in areas affected by weather in the quarter? And how much do you think is the volume shortfall in the quarter was driven by weather and or delayed start of projects?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathryn. What I would say is volumes are down approximately 2 million tons for the quarter based on what we thought it would be. And, really, as we rack it up, it falls into 3 different buckets. Number one, I would say shale volume was down abo
componenttext: Thank you, Kathryn. What I would say is volumes are down approximately 2 million tons for the quarter based on what we thought it would be. And, really, as we rack it up, it falls into 3 different buckets. Number one, I would say shale volume was down about 750,000 tons versus the prior year. So that's your first bridge number. Your second bridge number, Kathryn, should be on the railroad balance. We saw that down about 250,000 tons compared to the prior year. But still the single largest moving factor there is relative to what we experienced with respect to weather. We're seeing tonnage affected by weather somewhere between 1 million and 1.5 million tons a quarter. So that gives you your bridge. The other part of your question, I think, it's a good one, Kathryn, is what are we looking relative to backlogs and how does that feel. And what I would say, in particular, Texas last year, had the wettest May in history. This year, it had one other wettest May in history. I mentioned that because if we simply look at a portion of the Texas market, let's look at what we got in North Texas, we've got about 3.6 million tons of backlog in North Texas and only about 600,000 of that shift during the first half of 2016. So clearly, there's pretty considerable, a, backlog and pretty considerable jam up on that backlog. There's some big jobs that are really waiting to go in a more robust fashion U.S. 380, near Denton is one of them. State Highway 175 outside of Dallas is another, and Interstate 45 and 35 both had considerable work. So from a volume perspective, what did we see deferred? It was the 2 million tons broken down into those buckets that I gave you relative to large projects and what the backlog looks like. We feel very comfortable with our backlog, at this position, we just need to be able to go on a number of those jobs, particularly textile [ph] jobs. Kathryn, was that a good response?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, that is very helpful. Do you have any parameters how we can think about it for 2 other important states, Colorado and North Carolina?
componenttext: Yes, no, that is very helpful. Do you have any parameters how we can think about it for 2 other important states, Colorado and North Carolina?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well here's what I would say with respect to Colorado. Colorado had a much better quarter. If we look at what's going on in Colorado, in the Rocky Mountain group, what I would tell you is everything within the borders of Colorado was really very healthy.
componenttext: Well here's what I would say with respect to Colorado. Colorado had a much better quarter. If we look at what's going on in Colorado, in the Rocky Mountain group, what I would tell you is everything within the borders of Colorado was really very healthy. The only place in the Rocky Mountain group that we're seeing any degree of volume struggle is outside of Colorado, where it's more balanced driven. So we do have some ballast rise in Utah, we have one up in Wyoming as well, so we are seeing some pressure of those back to those same issues that we discussed before. What I will tell you is what we're seeing in Metro Denver, what we're seeing North of Denver, what we're seeing South of Denver, whether its aggregates, ready-mix or hot mix is all a very, very healthy marketplace, particularly downstream paving, we're getting considerably more work this year than we were last year at the same time. I want to say for the quarter, we had been on nearly 35 more jobs in Metro in North than we've been on last year. So we see Colorado being very busy not just for the balance of this year. We see Colorado being very busy for next year. With respect to the other part of your question on North Carolina, we're seeing a very healthy sharp so that's been a market that has continued to perform well. Importantly, as we go East in Charlotte and get to triad, we're seeing considerably more infrastructure work in Greensboro, High Point and Winston-Salem. That's a part of the state because of textiles, furniture and other manufacturing that suffered more than the rest of the state. We are now seeing both residential and nonresidential recovery in that marketplace. As we come further East yet and hit Raleigh-Durham and Chapel Hill, infrastructure work here is very healthy. Multifamily residential has been very, very healthy. Residential is starting to move in the direction that we would expect. So again, we're seeing a much healthier North Carolina. The part of this state is still waiting for more economic [indiscernible] to hit it are the more coastal areas that are continuing to get better and better quarter after quarter. So I didn't want to make sure I went through those areas pretty clearly with you, Kathryn.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's very helpful. And one follow up related to rails. One, I just wanted to make sure that I'm correct in thinking that rail operators can kick the can down the road only so far in terms of deferring maintenance CapEx. And then second, along with
componenttext: Yes, that's very helpful. And one follow up related to rails. One, I just wanted to make sure that I'm correct in thinking that rail operators can kick the can down the road only so far in terms of deferring maintenance CapEx. And then second, along with that, which is really a separate subject, but how do you think margins cost structure may be impacted in the future by various changes that the rail operators are currently undergoing?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kathryn, I guess, I'll respond to your first comment and really just agree to it. Maintenance is something that in the early and since in the downturn, it's always going to see the stick pull back. And I think that's exactly we're doing I think it's fairl
componenttext: Kathryn, I guess, I'll respond to your first comment and really just agree to it. Maintenance is something that in the early and since in the downturn, it's always going to see the stick pull back. And I think that's exactly we're doing I think it's fairly predictable once they saw their volumes declining. That cannot endure because they have thousands of miles of track that they need to maintain. So that's not a matter of if, it's a matter of when. I think with respect to the second part of your question, I think what's going to happen is aggregate business will likely get better service under railroads because we have been a very steady customer all the way through. So if you go back to the notion that with a larger shippers stoned, on 4 out of the 5 Class I railroads and our network is at least double the next largest network, our ability, I believe, to move stone from stone producing areas to stone starts parts of the country, particularly in South Texas and along the Gulf and Atlantic Coast will oddly enough most likely be held by the circumstance.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jerry Revich with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ward, and I wonder if you could talk about just the ChemRock and Rail guidance for the year. So year-to-date, that part of your business is down 19%. I think your full year guidance implies a significant pickup in the back half of the year. But as we step
componenttext: Ward, and I wonder if you could talk about just the ChemRock and Rail guidance for the year. So year-to-date, that part of your business is down 19%. I think your full year guidance implies a significant pickup in the back half of the year. But as we step through the qualitative comments and the call, just want to make sure that still reflects your current views on that end market.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it does right now, Jerry. Keep in mind the numbers that we put out at the beginning of the year were based on the balanced numbers that we had been supplied by Class I railroads. So again, the dialogue is active with them. They've been very clear
componenttext: I think it does right now, Jerry. Keep in mind the numbers that we put out at the beginning of the year were based on the balanced numbers that we had been supplied by Class I railroads. So again, the dialogue is active with them. They've been very clear that was going to be back half pushed. If we're looking simply to the graded power volume or others down on the different railroads. I mean, the fact is we can look at year-to-date car volumes and say UP is down 10%, CSX is down almost 7%, Norfolk Southern down almost 6%.  So you can clearly see why they would pull back. I think going back to Kathryn's point in her question, it can only be held back so long. And keep in mind, a lot of these places, too, have seen pretty considerable flooding in the first half of the year. So railroads have been underwater and have seen that type of duress. They will have needs as we head into the back half of the year. Now in fairness, if we're looking at what headwinds and tailwinds could be, and it's probably a good moment to think about that as we do at this question. I would clearly put that in a potential headwind for us as we go into the back half of the year. So I really think about those probably in 2 different tranches, Jerry. I think tailwinds that we have going into the back half of the year is the rate and trajectory of recovery into Carolinas and Southeast and some of that, by the way , could be ballast. I think another tailwind that we have is strong demand in the Midwest and Rocky Mountains. And I think a strong contracted backlog is a tailwind as well. So I think you've got those 3. But I do think that if you are looking at what the headwinds are, I think the ballast shipments could be a headwind. And if we don't see some improvement at the back half of the year, there are probably 600,000-ish tons that could be at risk there. Clearly, we do need good normal weather for the balance of the year, and we do need TxDOT to have more of their work go in a more timely basis. Now the other issue, and I don't think the railroads necessarily suffer from this, but I think a lot of other trades do right now, getting truck drivers, tradesmen, welders, other things simple within the supply chain are under varying degrees of duress in different parts of the country. So I do think there's some headwinds, I do think there's some tailwinds and I give you that in the context of I do believe ballast is the potential headwind. So fair enough here.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jerry, just a reminder, that ChemRock and Rail segment only about, I guess, 3 percentage point of that is the ballast. It also has agricultural lime and other chemical grade stones. So there are other factors that can potentially mitigate that volume
componenttext: And Jerry, just a reminder, that ChemRock and Rail segment only about, I guess, 3 percentage point of that is the ballast. It also has agricultural lime and other chemical grade stones. So there are other factors that can potentially mitigate that volume guidance.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate the color. And then can you talk about across your footprint, what are you hearing regarding the case of public construction work ramping up versus your expectations. I guess, it sounded like last quarter projects got moving a little bi
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate the color. And then can you talk about across your footprint, what are you hearing regarding the case of public construction work ramping up versus your expectations. I guess, it sounded like last quarter projects got moving a little bit faster than we expected. Is that -- was that effectively you look at them now some pull-forward demand and things are evening out now? Or what's your take on the pace of public activity that we saw in the quarter outside of the weather issues that you outlined?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you are seeing a pickup, but we've always said it was going to be more of a '17 event than it was going to be a '16 event. I think our verbiage in the past is because of how long we had gone without a highway bill, it was more likely than us
componenttext: Well, I think you are seeing a pickup, but we've always said it was going to be more of a '17 event than it was going to be a '16 event. I think our verbiage in the past is because of how long we had gone without a highway bill, it was more likely than usual that we might see some of that activity in the second half of 2016. So it's fascinating to look at where it was happy. I mean, streets starts were down 16%. But again, our view was we're going to see an expected recovery in half 2 and really more going into '17. What's fascinating to me, Jerry, is to go back and take a look at some of the key states and look at it over not a several month period but over a 2014 to 2016 time frame relative to the subject. And this is what I find. North Carolina, the change on a percentage '14 to '16, 58%; Nebraska, same time frame, up 41%; Iowa, up 18%; Arkansas, up 11%; South Carolina, up 53%; Florida, up 18%. Now with that same time frame because you did see a pullback, is Texas down, it is. But again, it just seemed that normal give-and-take in that. So again, I'm not sure that we're seeing anything relative to public transportation that's surprising to us. I think we see good momentum going into the back half of the year, and I think we see very good momentum going into 2017.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what -- based on the common good momentum heading into the back year, it sounds like weather and shipments normalized in July, I think, is the implication of that comment, is that fair?
componenttext: And what -- based on the common good momentum heading into the back year, it sounds like weather and shipments normalized in July, I think, is the implication of that comment, is that fair?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jerry, I don't want to talk specifically about July until we're talking in November. Yes, obviously, you can see what we have done with our guidance and the resilience that we have around that.
componenttext: Well, Jerry, I don't want to talk specifically about July until we're talking in November. Yes, obviously, you can see what we have done with our guidance and the resilience that we have around that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is just on incremental margins, you've outpaced your long-term targets in the second quarter. It seems like to hit the midpoint of your guidance, you need some around 60% so in line with the long term. But can you talk about some of the lev
componenttext: First question is just on incremental margins, you've outpaced your long-term targets in the second quarter. It seems like to hit the midpoint of your guidance, you need some around 60% so in line with the long term. But can you talk about some of the levers that you saw in the second quarter, in particular, on lower volume, you got 70% consolidating incremental margins, which is pretty strong. And what are you seeing as far as the levers of Austin incrementals in the back half of the year? And could we perhaps see some conservatism in the incremental margin guidance in the near to medium term.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Garik, I guess, a couple of things. Number one, I think we need to really give a tip of the hat to our operating teams. Because operating in the type of environment at which they're operating is really challenging because it stop start. And these business
componenttext: Garik, I guess, a couple of things. Number one, I think we need to really give a tip of the hat to our operating teams. Because operating in the type of environment at which they're operating is really challenging because it stop start. And these businesses don't do stop start very well. Here's what I'll tell you. So look at cost structure, momentum on the labor side has been very good, momentum on energy has been very good, momentum on maintenance and repair has gotten considerably better. One of the things that we did last year, in particular, as we accelerated the purchase of some rolling stock, particularly in the Midwest and United States and in some of my earlier comments, I spoke to the fact that, that's going to be a business that's going to be as busy this year as it can be until snow fly is there. And what we saw with incremental additions to rolling stock in that marketplace is we saw maintenance and repair hit considerably better. So again, our cost structure is doing what I believe our cost structure we're doing, again, our teams have done exceptional work. The other piece of it that I think it's worth remembering is in large part we're watching the price fall to the bottom line, and that has really been very powerful. And if you think about what you're seeing relative to the price increases, you've heard us say not for a matter of months, but you've heard us say for a matter of years that it would be most likely that you would see the Western United States on a percentage basis price increase outperform the Eastern United States and particularly in parts of Texas. And that's what we're seeing. I think the other thing to your point, Garik, on what it looks like going forward. Part of what I believe you've heard us refer to in the past is that we believe in time, Colorado, we start to see that same type of pricing performance with a lag behind Texas. We're starting to see evidence of that taking shape as well. So to your question on incrementals, cost performance has been really very good. Capital deployment has continued to drive down cost in areas that needed to drive down, prices fall into the bottom line. And importantly, it's doing exactly what we thought. And keep in mind, we thought we would see these better incrementals early on in the cycle. So, so far, no surprises.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just want to switch to Cement for a second. At Cement pricing, you did lower your guidance. Again, wanted to get some clarity on the comment in the release pricing was down slightly ahead of price increases. Just want to get what that meant. And als
componenttext: Okay. Just want to switch to Cement for a second. At Cement pricing, you did lower your guidance. Again, wanted to get some clarity on the comment in the release pricing was down slightly ahead of price increases. Just want to get what that meant. And also, may be get your take on how the July price increases have taken hold in the Texas market?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I guess, a couple of things, Garik. There were July increases in the Texas market. We anticipate more coming in October as well. That's what drives the 2 to 4 pricing that we're showing up. Clearly, when we spoke about Texas on the last earnings
componenttext: Yes. No, I guess, a couple of things, Garik. There were July increases in the Texas market. We anticipate more coming in October as well. That's what drives the 2 to 4 pricing that we're showing up. Clearly, when we spoke about Texas on the last earnings call, we said we thought Q1 maybe going into Q2. It's going to be a shakeout period we're pricing in Texas. Obviously, you've got imports that have come in at least the port of Houston that are modestly different than we've seen over the last several years. At the same time, part of what we're doing, particularly in North Texas is we're serving more of our own cement needs in that marketplace as well. So when we're looking at shipping more cement farther to feed some of our ready-mix operations. And you've also got some of the competitive postures that have been in that marketplace. That in my way of thinking is what has really held the price down in addition to the weather that we saw. So as we look at it clearly, pricing in North Texas is better than it's been in South Texas. We're seeing increases in both markets, and we feel like we've now seen nice stability in that marketplace. I can tell you, we're seeing bidding in North Texas today at numbers much closer to the 112, 113, 114 type numbers, and that's more in line with what we would have expected.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Craig Bibb with CJS Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Bibb with CJS Securities.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dallas ready-mix market looked particular strong. I'm assuming most of the things was Dallas or was that evenly split with Colorado?
componenttext: Dallas ready-mix market looked particular strong. I'm assuming most of the things was Dallas or was that evenly split with Colorado?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The ready-mix market generally looked pretty strong, but what I tell you is the Colorado ready-mix market is particularly strong. I mean, is Dallas doing better? It is, Dallas is doing considerably better, so we need to start with that. But if we're looki
componenttext: The ready-mix market generally looked pretty strong, but what I tell you is the Colorado ready-mix market is particularly strong. I mean, is Dallas doing better? It is, Dallas is doing considerably better, so we need to start with that. But if we're looking at just what's going on relative to ASP, ASPs in the Texas market have clearly outperformed. We're looking at ASPs in that overall market in the Southwest up almost 17%. So if we're looking at that type of performance in Texas, it's much better. What I'll tell you is we look across 5 different districts of ready-mix in that marketplace. There's only one that has ASPs less than $100 a cubic yard. That's getting them into a much more acceptable type of level. So yes, it's getting better in Texas. While weather was really wet, and was not necessarily ready-mix's friend. Weather was still better than it was last year during the same time, Craig, so those are your drivers.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is there anything that's likely to slow down the Dallas and the Colorado ready-mix market?
componenttext: Okay. Is there anything that's likely to slow down the Dallas and the Colorado ready-mix market?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I will say, we're just work our way north to south. Again, everything that we see in Colorado right now looks incredibly healthy. Public looks healthy, private looks healthy, both res and nonres. So we feel good about that entire I-25 corridor. As we
componenttext: What I will say, we're just work our way north to south. Again, everything that we see in Colorado right now looks incredibly healthy. Public looks healthy, private looks healthy, both res and nonres. So we feel good about that entire I-25 corridor. As we're looking at our ready-mix business in Texas, keep in mind, it's principally going to be more North Texas driven than anything else. As we look just broadly across our business footprint from an aggregate perspective and keep in mind, we want to feed ourselves, our own aggregates and our ready-mix business, about 45% of our aggregate volume in Texas is North Texas driven, about 30% is Central Texas driven, 15% Houston driven, 9% South Texas driven. We don't have any ready-mix in Houston, which is probably the single most challenged market in Texas. That's my way of coming back to your very good question. Now we feel pretty good about where we are in the ready-mix business in Texas. It's time to add notion of where you are matters, and where you want to be vertically-integrated matters. Even in a vertically-integrated market, you want to be careful. And I believe that's what we've done in Texas.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in Houston, switching gears a little bit, your competitor was talking about a lull in the large project activity along the coast. Are you guys seeing that?
componenttext: Okay. And then in Houston, switching gears a little bit, your competitor was talking about a lull in the large project activity along the coast. Are you guys seeing that?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. But we're actually seeing regional activity along the Gulf Coast in the large energy projects. I know -- my recollection spoke about 30% down in Houston yesterday. We're not seeing a number like that, we're seeing a number closer to half of that. But
componenttext: Yes. But we're actually seeing regional activity along the Gulf Coast in the large energy projects. I know -- my recollection spoke about 30% down in Houston yesterday. We're not seeing a number like that, we're seeing a number closer to half of that. But again, if you look at the way that our business is built in Texas, we're primarily a North Texas-driven company, not a South Texas-driven company. So the percentages will be hard to be apples-to-apples.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the slow down with the Texas DOT even with the benefit of Proposition 1 and, I think, it's 7, that's just the timing issue or how did that happen given the incremental funds they have?
componenttext: Okay. And the slow down with the Texas DOT even with the benefit of Proposition 1 and, I think, it's 7, that's just the timing issue or how did that happen given the incremental funds they have?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the biggest issue that you got in Texas is not a lack of work or a lack of potential volume. So I think the biggest issue that you got in Texas candidly is you've got Texas DOT feeling a little bit of growing pains right now because they have let
componenttext: I think the biggest issue that you got in Texas is not a lack of work or a lack of potential volume. So I think the biggest issue that you got in Texas candidly is you've got Texas DOT feeling a little bit of growing pains right now because they have let so much work, record work, record work on top of record work that on occasion now they're running into whenever we got a right-of-way issue here, we need to do it. But we have the utility issue here that we need to do it. So I don't think there's any funding issue at all in Texas right now. And I think, particularly in North Texas, what really needs to happen is they're more -- you hate to say it's administrative, but it's almost the first cousin to administrative issues that TxDOT needs to work its way through. I don't have any doubt that they will. I don't think anyone in Texas has any doubt that they will. As I said, it's not a matter of if, it's a matter of when.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could talk a little bit about the M&A market. I know that you always highlight your share repurchase program, but just wanted to get any thoughts what are the uses of cash, particularly in M&A.
componenttext: I was hoping you could talk a little bit about the M&A market. I know that you always highlight your share repurchase program, but just wanted to get any thoughts what are the uses of cash, particularly in M&A.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Timna, as you know, that's really #1 on the hit parade as far as uses of cash going forward. And what I'll say is this, we have been engaged in a lot of dialogue. And we're talking to a lot of closely held family businesses, in particular. And one o
componenttext: Well, Timna, as you know, that's really #1 on the hit parade as far as uses of cash going forward. And what I'll say is this, we have been engaged in a lot of dialogue. And we're talking to a lot of closely held family businesses, in particular. And one of the recurring themes that I hear is that if family-owned businesses are looking to potentially make moves with their businesses, selling into what they feel like it's an up cycle is a pretty sensible thing for them to do. Now you should equally expect us to be thoughtful around value and not put ourselves in a position that we're overpaying. But at the same time, in a marketplace I think where people can look at our space and say, this looks like it's going to be pretty good for 3 or 4 or maybe 5 years. If you're a family-owned business and you've been through a particularly different time over the last 10 years, they're probably doing some real soul-searching right now. And we want to be there to help them.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. In the last conference call, I've written down that you were seeing some cement shortages in Texas this year and I know you noted there was a little more import. But can you give us a little bit more color about what changed and how
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. In the last conference call, I've written down that you were seeing some cement shortages in Texas this year and I know you noted there was a little more import. But can you give us a little bit more color about what changed and how you see the market going forward?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually what I think, Timna, was if we had demand that we thought we're going to have in Texas, it wouldn't surprise me if we saw some shortages towards the end of the year. So clearly, I was saying that before we had 8 inches of potential rain flooding
componenttext: Actually what I think, Timna, was if we had demand that we thought we're going to have in Texas, it wouldn't surprise me if we saw some shortages towards the end of the year. So clearly, I was saying that before we had 8 inches of potential rain flooding across the entire state of Texas. So I guess my view is not that far removed from where PCA is, because if we look at what we think to be capacity additions to Texas over the next several years and who knows if all those come forward even with those capacity additions, what you're seeing is about a 3 million-ton per annum shortfall of cement. So what Texas has not had genuinely for 24 months period is normal weather. They have not had a normal Texas summer and our sense is that's going to happen. And when that happens in construction activity on the public side, which is half of our business is as robust as we believe it will. And when places like Dallas continue to be as they are today, the best housing market in the United States, those are the types of formulas that come together to create cement shortages in that type of circumstance.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay, I understand. And then the only other thing I want to ask about is just in light of your comments on the energy sector troughing. How should we think about that type of recovery that your customers are signaling to you or how to think about what that could look like going forward coming out of a trough?

componenttext: What energy looks like coming out of a trough?

componenttext: Correct. Your energy market -- your tonnage and energy end markets, yes.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, here's a way to think of it. If we're looking for the quarter, just for the quarter, on what we sold directly to Shale energy, we sold about 292,000 tons to the shale sector in the quarter. To give you a compare, last year in the second quarter, I l
componenttext: Well, here's a way to think of it. If we're looking for the quarter, just for the quarter, on what we sold directly to Shale energy, we sold about 292,000 tons to the shale sector in the quarter. To give you a compare, last year in the second quarter, I looked at over 1 million tons, and -- but that wasn't going great guns last year. This sector doesn't stay down, this sector is going to have to have return. Do I think the sector is going back to the type of volume that we were seeing in 2014, which by the way, was almost 7.5 million tons? I don't think it goes there. But I think it could very well go back to numbers that we were seeing at least in '15 or maybe in '16 if we look at full year '15, that was 3.6 million tons. So basically half of what it had been in '14. I'm not sure that, that is somewhere between that 2 5 and 3 5 wouldn't be a good steady run rate for energy as it returns. And again, I think we're pretty well placed to serve that when it does.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Trey Grooms with Stephens.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Well, first question would be on the tonnage impacted by weather, I think, you called out like 1 or maybe 1.5 million tons. Just trying to get a sense for when those can come through. I know there's a lot of moving pieces there. But if we're going to be hit in 2Q, and we're delayed, would that come through in the back half of the year or would that be something that would be more likely to add to 2017?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Trey, I think that's a great question. I think a lot of that's going to be weather-driven because if we end up with a heavy hurricane chase in the Carolinas or Florida or Georgia, it's going to be tough. If we end up with an early winter in Iowa and Color
componenttext: Trey, I think that's a great question. I think a lot of that's going to be weather-driven because if we end up with a heavy hurricane chase in the Carolinas or Florida or Georgia, it's going to be tough. If we end up with an early winter in Iowa and Colorado, it will be tough. On the other hand, if we have a dry Q3 and late winter, frankly, you could make up a lot of that. I think one of the biggest issues and as you recall, when I was pointing to the question that Jerry had, I talked about both headwinds and tailwinds. And I do think that issue, that tailwind issue that I described or the headwind issue on workers, drivers, technical trades, those type of things, in other words, everything that's in the supply chain and again, we saw some of this last year, too, when we had that wet weather coming out of Q2, I think that may end up being an issue. It's hard for us to measure right now. But my guess is that something that you'll hear in the marketplace as you do your channel checks, too.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. Well, hopefully, the weather will cooperate for you guys. I guess, the next one would be on Specialty Products. I think in the guidance, there is some implied acceleration there. Can you talk about what's driving that? Is that mostly related
componenttext: Got it, okay. Well, hopefully, the weather will cooperate for you guys. I guess, the next one would be on Specialty Products. I think in the guidance, there is some implied acceleration there. Can you talk about what's driving that? Is that mostly related to your expectations due to steel price movement? Or just any color you can give.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, you know what -- we're just -- we're seeing good MagChem work right now. I mean, we really -- if we're looking at what's going on in the steel industry, the steel industry for us if you're looking at the 2 components that drive that business broadly,
componenttext: No, you know what -- we're just -- we're seeing good MagChem work right now. I mean, we really -- if we're looking at what's going on in the steel industry, the steel industry for us if you're looking at the 2 components that drive that business broadly, is what's going on with steel capacity, that's about 72%, which is a perfectly fine place to be. If it's about 70%, we're going to be fine. Equally if you take a look at where we are relative to what's going on with natural gas pricing, I mean, you've got a 21% cost reduction versus prior year so if you've got steel at over 70%, you've got nat gas down 21%, that's helps a lot. But then when you got good business on the MagChem side and keep in mind I want to say historically about 12%, 13% of our revenue is going overseas in that business, maybe a little bit more right now. So the type of business that we're seeing that we think doesn't just have quarter-to-quarter type of impact to it, but likely has a multiple year impact to it is actually very attractive to us right now.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then I'm not sure how much you can go into detail on this one, but you guys repurchased about $190 million worth of stock I think, year-to-date and your balance sheet is still going to be in very good shape and within your parameters, well below your parameters, by the end of the year, if you kind of keep this pace up. But do you expect that the cadence could increase in the back half as we see free cash flow generation likely improving in the back half of the year?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Trey, I guess a lot of it depends on what the market opportunities are relative to transactions that we think are attractive because, again, we're going to look at the purchase of Martin Marietta. At the same way, we're going to look at the purchase of a
componenttext: Trey, I guess a lot of it depends on what the market opportunities are relative to transactions that we think are attractive because, again, we're going to look at the purchase of Martin Marietta. At the same way, we're going to look at the purchase of a business is out there right now. Of course, a number of businesses that may come up oftentimes and that being opportunistic. The other thing that I would encourage you to do and you obviously are by the nature of your question where are we on our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio because we told you, we were going to give it right at about the 2x. And in the prepared remarks I had, we were right at 1.98, so we have that bad habit of trying to do what we said we're going to do. So we'll probably keep it right at that level and then much of it's going to be driven by what's the opportunity look like.

componenttext: No, we took a deep dive on that as you would expect us to and neither geography nor product really moved it around this time. So what you see is what you get.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Stanley Elliott from Stifel.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One quick question. The ready-mix has been really, really strong. How much longer -- maybe could you help us frame this out, kind of what inning you think we are in the recovery of this business? And how we should think about that on a go-forward basis?
componenttext: One quick question. The ready-mix has been really, really strong. How much longer -- maybe could you help us frame this out, kind of what inning you think we are in the recovery of this business? And how we should think about that on a go-forward basis?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, what I would say on the ready-mix business from any perspective, it's a more mature ballgame in Colorado than it is in Texas right now relative to Denver in the marketplace north. So if you think back to it, what we've done in growing that
componenttext: Well, I guess, what I would say on the ready-mix business from any perspective, it's a more mature ballgame in Colorado than it is in Texas right now relative to Denver in the marketplace north. So if you think back to it, what we've done in growing that business in Colorado all the way down to Front Range, all the way down I-25 has really given more breadth and depth to that marketplace. So we're looking at ASPs in the Rocky Mountains, for example, that are higher than they are in the Southwest. And that's one reason I say that's a more mature business. But what I would say in the Southwest is, if we're looking at type of growth that I believe we're looking at in North Texas, if we're looking at the type of growth that I think we're looking at in the other markets that are close to that and with some of the large vertically-integrated jobs that we have in South Texas that have multiple years ahead of them. Again, I would say this is a game that's in relatively early innings in Texas right now. If you go back to the comments that I had in my prepared remarks, we anticipate seeing, from return in other perspective the Texas business looking more and more like the Colorado business. And as we said, we believe the results that we've seen so far this year, in particular, results that we saw in this quarter is good evidence that the team is moving there. We've had a very capable management team that oversees this business. They know exactly what our aims and desires are, and they're doing a very fine job right now of meeting that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And kind of to go back to balance sheet from a capital standpoint, obviously, strong credit rating. If you want to say around this 2x leverage target, by my guess and I think a lot of people out there, we should see EBITDA growth pretty significant
componenttext: Great. And kind of to go back to balance sheet from a capital standpoint, obviously, strong credit rating. If you want to say around this 2x leverage target, by my guess and I think a lot of people out there, we should see EBITDA growth pretty significantly over the next couple of years. What are the thoughts on taking advantage of some of the attractive rates that you could get now versus the 2018 notes do you have at 6 and 6.6, I believe, given the outlook for the business and the momentum that you're seeing there right now?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stanley, if you take a look at that, those transactions if we would exclude [ph] the day either at low rates would be NPV negative. But we obviously are looking at them to determine whether or not we should pull some of that forward and refinance. Our who
componenttext: Stanley, if you take a look at that, those transactions if we would exclude [ph] the day either at low rates would be NPV negative. But we obviously are looking at them to determine whether or not we should pull some of that forward and refinance. Our whole capital allocation strategy is to maintain the financial flexibility of the business, to invest in acquisitions that come long at the right acquisition and the right markets for the right price to fully fund what we need from an organic and capital perspective and then maintaining that debt-to-EBITDA at 2x, which as Trey indicated earlier, means there need to be some type of incremental activity that takes place in the second half of the year to do that should our expectations fall through. And then just keeping us with that financial flexibility to execute against the M&A opportunities when they present themselves on a broader scale.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Stanley, the other things I would add and alluded to it. Obviously, we're putting CapEx into the business right now ahead of DD&A. And part of what we've always discussed is DD&A which runs today is by $275 million is not a bad proxy for you to have a
componenttext: And Stanley, the other things I would add and alluded to it. Obviously, we're putting CapEx into the business right now ahead of DD&A. And part of what we've always discussed is DD&A which runs today is by $275 million is not a bad proxy for you to have at the back of your mind on what our stay in business CapEx needs are. And we're anticipating about $350 million capital spend this year. And if you go back to part of what we discussed earlier about what capital is doing at times for our cost structure and part of what I referenced before is the dialogue we're having, in particular, rolling stock in the Midwestern United States making sure we're in a position to invest in the right way at the right time there is really important to us. So it all rolls together very seamlessly.

componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. Can you kind of discuss how you guys asses returns as it relates to buying existing capacity that being acquisitions versus organic -- excuse me, versus greenfield opportunities and brownfield growth opportunities such as opening in
componenttext: Just a quick question. Can you kind of discuss how you guys asses returns as it relates to buying existing capacity that being acquisitions versus organic -- excuse me, versus greenfield opportunities and brownfield growth opportunities such as opening in new quarry, we're expanding existing production sites from an IRR perspective?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but we're always going to run mile on it. If we're doing transactions, we're going to look at 15% IRR on a post-tax basis. I mean, that's going to be the beginning of the analysis.
componenttext: Yes, but we're always going to run mile on it. If we're doing transactions, we're going to look at 15% IRR on a post-tax basis. I mean, that's going to be the beginning of the analysis.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just [indiscernible] on that.
componenttext: Yes, just [indiscernible] on that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Rob, at the end of the day, it's going to be driven by what our strategic plan says. I mean, keep in mind if you remember those decks that we've gone through, we look at our markets very clearly protect expand, hold, target, exit. And depending on wha
componenttext: But Rob, at the end of the day, it's going to be driven by what our strategic plan says. I mean, keep in mind if you remember those decks that we've gone through, we look at our markets very clearly protect expand, hold, target, exit. And depending on what the market is going to dictate, how we look at that market, how we want to invest or otherwise. The other thing that we are mindful of, we have the ability to greenfield. We've clearly done that in places like [indiscernible]. We're going to do some of that in [indiscernible] . I think we've done that very well. I think we've done more of that probably than others in the space. At the same time, if we go back 8, 9 years ago, this was a company that was producing and selling 205 million tons of stone on a pre-TXI basis. So really, if we're looking at greenfielding in markets, they're going to need to be compelling reasons why to do that because there's really not a lot of need right now to add capacity. The greater need is greater efficiencies and to find those attractive markets where we want to have a more compelling presence. So to the extent that we can look to drive the marketplace in which we have a 1 or 2 position. And right now it's 85% of our markets versus 65%, let's call it, 6 years ago, if we can take that 85% number up to 95% or to 90% and keep doing that, that's awfully good and high use for our dollars, so that's how we're going to think about that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Rob, as we laid out in Investor Day, we're always a pretty solid land buyer. We had a big buy in land last year, and we'll always look for those opportunities for acquiring new properties whether they be appended to existing operations or whether the
componenttext: And Rob, as we laid out in Investor Day, we're always a pretty solid land buyer. We had a big buy in land last year, and we'll always look for those opportunities for acquiring new properties whether they be appended to existing operations or whether the properties for future of greenfield.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. Again, I was asking kind of on the follow up of Timna's question on M&A because clearly over the last 6 to 12 months, it looks like we've seen a number of deals going at multiples north of 9, in some cases, north of 10x EBITDA. And
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. Again, I was asking kind of on the follow up of Timna's question on M&A because clearly over the last 6 to 12 months, it looks like we've seen a number of deals going at multiples north of 9, in some cases, north of 10x EBITDA. And then typically, you guys target wanting to pay 7 to 8x. And some of these assets that have been sold have a heavy competitive downstream businesses. So I'm just -- I'm curious if you're  really able to find that sweet spot where you've been able to get assets for 7, 8x or you're seeing these some of the exorbitant multiples paid for some transactions?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's interesting, Rob, because I think the multiple paid is really from our perspective is going to be driven by where the business is. Because candidly, our view of what you pay on a sand and gravel business versus what you pay on a hard rock business ma
componenttext: It's interesting, Rob, because I think the multiple paid is really from our perspective is going to be driven by where the business is. Because candidly, our view of what you pay on a sand and gravel business versus what you pay on a hard rock business may vary. Our view of what you may pay for a granite hard rock business versus your limestone hard rock business may vary. Or you may vary on open pit versus underground. So will there be times that we could look at in some markets a double-digit EBITDA multiple? Absolutely, there are times we could do that. We would rather not. Obviously, we rather not. But again, it's going to be driven more by the marketplace, it's going to be driven by the plan and it's going to be driven by a long term and near-term view.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And my last question, can you just kind of walk us through in the core states that you operate in, funding bills that are being voted on are moving through the various approval stages, that could provide additional funds for infrastructure fu
componenttext: Okay, great. And my last question, can you just kind of walk us through in the core states that you operate in, funding bills that are being voted on are moving through the various approval stages, that could provide additional funds for infrastructure funding. And then secondly to that, we've obviously seen success with the DOT [indiscernible] program and its contribution to funding projects. Do you think what's your opinion on that program being renewed since obviously there is not a multi-year authorization?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let's talk about it in a couple of different tranches. I mean, if we look at it in new money terms and that all of this is new, but some of the hit from some of this is going to be relatively new. In Iowa, put in $0.10 gas tax effective March 1, 201
componenttext: Sure. Let's talk about it in a couple of different tranches. I mean, if we look at it in new money terms and that all of this is new, but some of the hit from some of this is going to be relatively new. In Iowa, put in $0.10 gas tax effective March 1, 2015, that's going to basically give that state about a 30% increase of construction activity, that matters to us. Obviously, with House Bill 157 last year, Georgia basically increased their gas tax. They added almost $1 billion to annual construction budgets. We think both the Georgia and the Iowa pieces of it probably hit, obviously, more meaningfully in 2017. But we do think the back half of '16 could see some activities from that. Obviously, Texas has just a very healthy letting schedule, and they have over the last several years. That's going to continue to build on itself. I think the notions that we discussed around project delays administratively is something to be mindful of in Texas. Keep in mind that perhaps 7 money is coming when we get to September 2017 that should be about $2.5 billion per annum. Nebraska did not to the same degree that Iowa did, but they put in the gas tax increase of $0.015 on January 1, that's going to go up that same amount for the next 3 years so adds off to a $0.06 increase. That's going to about a $75 million total impact in that state. And we've got a very attractive position there. If we look at what's happened in North Carolina last year when the Legislature was in session, they basically added almost $1 billion to highway transportation spending. Now what North Carolina refers to as the biennium. So that's a 2-year process. South Carolina is looking to do more with what they call their Pennies for Progress Program, which would be delighted to see them do. Again, the work that we're seeing in South Carolina, right now in Charleston is very robust work. What we're seeing in Columbia is very good work and equally, my pence is government of Indiana wanted to see if he keeps his job as governor of Indiana because Berni is running for another one. And he's looking to invest an additional $1 billion in state roads, highways, bridges over a 4-year period there. So again, we've got a number of core states that matter a lot to us that do have a series of good initiatives coming behind them. [indiscernible] gas program, I don't know, we just have to see where that goes. I'll tell you I'm still one of those people who feels like the TIFIA program in, where it's going to be impactful can and will be going into the future. And remember what we've seen in TIFIA since 2012 is a $49 billion investment. So in markets that we care deeply about right now, we've seen 2 new applications in calendar 2015 and '16 and clearly, in a couple of projects in Colorado, we're at $1.7 billion on I-70 and 470, the loop. And then about $1.4 billion DFW project, the Midtown Express. And then we're still waiting for the Monroe bypass in Charlotte to go, and that's about an $839 million job. So I think we'll have to see what happens with Tiger brands, but I think between the FAST Act, state initiatives and what we've seen in TIFIA, it's pretty good future.

componenttext: Thanks, again, for joining our second quarter 2016 earnings call. As I think you can tell, we believe we are poised to deliver a great 2016. We continue to experience strong employment growth in our key states, good robust construction activity with increased materials demand and significant pricing opportunities. Our team's focused execution of our plan should provide a firm foundation enhancing long-term shareholder value, and we look forward to talking to you about that when we're together, again, in November. Until then, take care and be safe. Thank you very much.
