headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta Q3 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Ward
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Martin Marietta Q3 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Ward Nye, Chairman and CEO. You may begin.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Martin Marietta's Quarterly Earnings Call. With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. To facilitate today's discussion, we've made available during this webca
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for Martin Marietta's Quarterly Earnings Call. 
With me today is Anne Lloyd, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
To facilitate today's discussion, we've made available during this webcast and on our website supplemental financial information which we believe will be helpful. As detailed on Slide 2, today's teleconference may include forward-looking statements as defined by securities laws in connection with future events or future operating or financial performance. Like other businesses, we're subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially. Except as legally required, we undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether resulting from new information, future developments or otherwise. We refer you to the legal disclaimers contained in our third quarter earnings release and other filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are available on both our own and the SEC websites. 
Also, as a reminder, any margin references in our discussion are based on net sales and exclude freight and delivery revenues. These and other non-GAAP measures are explained in our supplemental financial information on our website and in our SEC filings. 
As set forth in this morning's release, Martin Marietta delivered exceptional record-breaking performance. These results validate the earnings power of our business model and demonstrate how our efforts are translating into enhanced shareholder value. 
In the third quarter of 2016, we expanded margins and set new records for quarterly net sales and profitability. Despite some notable headwinds that I will address later, we achieved record-setting performance due to several attributes that differentiate Martin Marietta. Our commitment to safety, our strategically positioned assets placed geographically in some of the nation's fastest-growing regions, our ability to achieve continued and consistent pricing gains for our valuable products and our relentless focus on cost containment. All of these led to record net sales of $1,038,000,000 and a gross margin of 28%, a 210 basis point improvement over what had been a record-setting prior year third quarter. 
Notably, our profitability growth was achieved in all business lines, demonstrating steady economic recovery across our geographic footprint and product categories. 
Overall, we earned a record $2.49 per diluted share for the quarter. The profitability growth translated into an increase in operating cash flow at nearly $95 million and a $75 million increase in earnings before interest, income taxes, depreciation depletion and amortization or EBITDA for the quarter. In fact, the year-to-date September 30, 2016 EBITDA of $742 million is within $9 million of the EBITDA generated for the entirety of 2015. 
At the moment, we believe we're in a more durable, construction-centric recovery across most of our markets. We're confident in our ability to both growth top line revenues, further increase profitability and cash flow, and importantly, continue to enhance long-term shareholder value. 
Widespread pricing gains contributed significantly to our results. Aggregates product line pricing increased approximately 9% over the prior year quarter. Nearly all markets in Texas achieved double-digit pricing growth, which helped lead the West Group's 14% increase in Aggregate average selling price. 
Consistent with our expectations, Aggregates pricing in our Colorado market, up 9% over the prior year quarter, is now beginning to trend with or ahead of the corporate average. 
The Southeast Group and Mid-America Group reported increases of 7% and 5%, respectively. 
The ready-mixed concrete business with operations primarily in Texas and Colorado, delivered a 6% average selling price increase on per cubic yard basis. 
Aggregates product line pricing strength more than offset the quarter's volumes headwinds. Consistent with our commentary into 2016 half year mark, we've seen the fourfold continuing effect of delays in Department of Transportation projects, particularly in Texas, declines in railroad ballast shipments, abnormally wet weather in many markets, and lastly, slower energy-related demand for construction materials. 
For comparative purposes, it's important to remember the third quarter of 2015 benefited from volume tailwinds following months of historic rainfall in many key Martin Marietta markets. 
By contrast, during this year's third quarter, particularly in August and September, important market such as Texas, the Carolinas and Iowa, experienced precipitation rivaling or exceeding the rainfall seen in the second quarter 2015 as best illustrated on the maps on Slide 5. These weather events, together with the second quarter significant rainfall, inevitably led to severe flooding in some areas making heavy-side construction activities oftentimes impossible. 
This circumstance was exacerbated on the Eastern seaboard of the United States in October as Hurricane Matthew left behind approximately 13 trillion gallons of water, nearly 1 billion gallons of which partially filled our Benson, North Carolina quarry. 
Matthew was the first major hurricane on record to make landfall into the Bahamas with the storm's eye wall literally passing through our free board operation. 
While some of our East Coast facilities experienced flooding, sporadic power outages and minor equipment damage, we were able to slowly and systematically resume sales at the vast majority of our affected locations, a testament to the resiliency of our operational teams. 
As is typical with natural disasters, emergency repairs to homes, businesses and transportation networks are vital in the early days and weeks post disaster. Permanent repairs to roads and other structures typically take months or years. 
In this regard, the United States government has approved the early release of federal highway funds for emergency road repairs in North Carolina. 
The personal impact of these storms in our employees and communities is not lost on us. In our home State of North Carolina loan, there are many who continue to experience the devastating effects of flooding. in fact, 34 counties have perceived disaster declarations for public systems and more than 17 Eastern North Carolina counties have disaster declarations for individual assistance. Many families will likely remain in emergency shelters through the upcoming holiday season. Our thoughts and prayers all those affected by Hurricane Matthew from the Caribbean through the Southeastern United States. We stand ready to provide help in terms of materials and support those who need it so that our neighbors can get the relief that they need to start anew. 
Our management has proven to be quite adept in dealing with unforeseen events, and we moved quickly to remedy situations as best we can. Yes, there will be short-term dislocations and sometimes, there will be delays in moving our products to customers, but we see that situation for what it is, temporary. Our business is built on long-term growth potential, and today, we are encouraged by the trends indicating strong underlying demand for our products and future growth for our business. 
This optimism is anchored in positive macroeconomic facts, including the employment growth nationally, a catalyst for construction activity, added 8 million jobs during the past 3 years. We expect the infrastructure growth to be bolstered as funding from the $305 billion FAST Act begins to meaningfully impact construction projects in 2017 and beyond. 
Additionally, many states, notably Texas and Georgia, continue to approve alternative funding sources to finance much needed infrastructure projects to support growing populations. 
In addition to improvements in infrastructure spending, we see broad positive trends in nonresidential growth despite some markets experiencing a slowdown in energy-related demand and the under present bearing interpretation of construction start data. 
For example, both Texas and Georgia are still attracting large corporate headquarter relocations, which is fueling construction activity. In fact, Dallas leads the nation in nonresidential construction growth with Atlanta not far behind ranked #4. 
Similarly, we are particularly pleased to observe positive trends across our markets in North Carolina and South Carolina, with increased investments notably in office, retail, manufacturing and industrial development. We believe construction start data is being affected by the natural ebb and flow of megaprojects through the construction cycle. 
The residential marketplace for Martin Marietta continues to slowly, steadily, and importantly, broadly recover. Dallas still leads the country in housing growth. It's notable, however, that we're seeing a changing but nonetheless, predictable evolution in many cities throughout the United States. 
Specifically, there's an emerging trend in many of our markets toward an increase more entry-level single-family housing activity. This is a natural progression as multifamily vacancy rates are low and corresponding rental rates are high. This circumstance leads to more families transitioning to traditional homes and thus, encouraging developers to open and pursue new subdivision work. 
By its nature, single-family housing is considerably more aggregate intensive than multifamily construction. We see this trend in important Martin Marietta cities such as Atlanta, Charlotte, Raleigh and Austin, just to name a few. 
Furthermore, while all the specific data points are anecdotally important, it's notable that we do not see evidence of saturation or excessive speculate building across our specific geographies. Rather, we believe our markets have room for continued growth and we're well positioned to capitalize on this increased construction activity. 
The ready-mixed concrete product line is benefiting from both strong demand and steady pricing growth. This combination led to a 12% increase in heritage net sales. Including the results from the July acquisition in Central Texas, net sales increased 26%, reflecting significant contributions from large, ongoing energy-related projects in Texas. 
Our pricing strength and relentless commitment to cost discipline, the latter being one of our core foundational pillars, is evident in our gross margin trajectory. The Aggregates business gross margin expanded 120 basis points, led by the Southeast Group, which achieved a 530 basis point improvement. Our Aggregates product line gross margin was 32%, an increase of 50 basis points.  Our Aggregates related downstream operations reported a gross margin of 19%, an increase of 390 basis points. 
For the third quarter, the Cement business generated $60 million of net sales and $30 million of gross profit. Again, this is despite facing project delays and unusually wet weather in Texas. 
Excluding the results of the divested California Cement business from the prior year, quarter which provides the same on same comparison, operational improvements and better pricing led to a 570 basis point expansion into the business's gross margin to nearly 50%. 
The 2015 impact of the now divested California Cement operations is detailed on Slide 
7. The business's third quarter results reflect $2 million of kiln maintenance cost. Fourth quarter expenses are forecasted to be $10 million. 
The Magnesia Specialties business delivered another record quarter with net sales of $60 million, an increase of 5%. Lower natural gas and kiln outage cost led to our gross margin of 38%, an improvement of 400 basis points over the prior quarter. 
Lastly, it's important to note that on a consolidated basis, we achieved an incremental gross margin of 91%, considerably above our internal target. We clearly have a host of trends that will positively affect our top line as well as the diversity of geographic regions and product categories that provide us stability in terms of our sales. Our aim is to always translate any growth into profits and cash. 
Our focus on controllable costs led to a reduction in SG&A expense as a percentage of net sales to 5.4%. Our consolidated earnings from operations for the quarter were $240 million compared with $179 million in the prior year quarter. Our business is generating significant cash, with operating cash flow increasing 30% through the 9 months ended September 30 compared with prior year period. 
Accordingly, we have both the means and the strategic plan in place to undertake value-enhancing acquisition activity as well as fund capital investment in our business, each critical to our near term and long-term strategy. 
That said, we are also appropriately focused on returning cash to shareholders. 
Based on our confidence in the outlook for our business and cash generation, Martin Marietta's Board of Directors recently approved a 5% increase in our cash dividend that was paid in September. Our annualized cash dividend rate is $1.68 per share. Together with our ongoing share repurchase program as of September 30, we returned nearly $900 million to shareholders since the beginning of 2015. 
Over the same period, we've reduced our debt-to-EBITDA leverage ratio from nearly 2.5x to 1.9x at September 30.  At the quarter's end, our ratio was in line with our target. 
During the quarter, we also extended our trade receivables borrowing facility and increased the borrowing base to $300 million. 
In today's earnings release, we updated our full year 2016 guidance. The revisions reflect the project and weather-related delays most notably in the Southwest and the impact of Hurricane Matthew. We thus lowered our aggregates product line volume guidance. Revisions to submit guidance, specifically reflect the higher percentage of shipments to our own internal ready-mixed concrete business, reflective of our recent Central Texas acquisition and the previously discussed near-term headwinds, particularly pertaining to South Texas. 
Overall, we expect strong pricing trends to continue for the full year and record consolidated pretax profitability. 
We believe overall construction markets in our geographies have broadly stabilized and anticipate steady volume growth in 2017. Pricing momentum is expected to remain robust, and we will benefit from leading positions in high-growth markets, including Atlanta, Dallas, Denver and the Carolinas. 
As we look forward to the final 2 months of 2016 and beyond, our profitability outlook is the strongest in years. Our expectation for increased levels of construction activity is underpinned by strong employment gains in our top markets and concurrence by third party forecasters. Of our key states, Florida ranks second nationally in growth while Texas ranks third. Georgia ranks fourth and North Carolina ranks eighth. 
Our longer-term outlook is consistent with those of Dodge MPCA, which forecast growth and construction starts for the remainder of 2016 and the next several years. 
The Dodge Momentum Index, which measures the initial report of nonresidential construction projects and tends to lead nonresidential construction spending by 1 full year, increased over 5% in September to 129, signaling additional growth in what we view as a multi-year recovery. 
The notion of slowing growth in residential construction in the United States has been influenced by decline in multifamily development, with the decrease largely concentrated in a few metro areas such as Miami, Houston and New York. Growth in the entry level single-family portion of residential construction remains positive. 
Dodge currently forecasting a family starts to increase 7% in 2016 followed by 9% growth in 2017 as compared to a multifamily decline of 5% and 2%, respectively. Infrastructure activity should accelerate as the FAST Act and other state funding initiatives in key Martin Marietta markets drive increased construction of highways, streets, roads and bridges. 
To conclude, we're very pleased with our record performance in the third quarter, and we look forward to completing a year of significant accomplishments. We foresee additional growth over the next several years, driven by the successful execution of our strategic plan. We remain committed to our core foundational pillars: World-class safety; ethical conduct; operational excellence; cost discipline; customer satisfaction; and sustainability. 
By doing so, we will be true to our aim of increasing long-term shareholder value. 
If the operator will now give the required instructions, we will turn our attention to addressing your questions.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Trey Grooms from Stephens Inc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Trey Grooms from Stephens Inc.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Weather has been definitely a challenge for you guys this year and Ward, you mentioned Hurricane Matthew, obviously, coming through some of your key markets and that you have tried to address that in your guidance. Could you talk about kind of how we shou
componenttext: Weather has been definitely a challenge for you guys this year and Ward, you mentioned Hurricane Matthew, obviously, coming through some of your key markets and that you have tried to address that in your guidance. Could you talk about kind of how we should be framing that up for the 4Q. What the impact that could have had on the fourth quarter, understanding that October is a very important month for the quarter? Just how that hurricane is impacting you in the guidance.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Trey, we'll try to wrap that up for you. As I said, we had about 1 billion of gallons of water that has found its way into our Benson quarry. Remarkably, that quarry is still operating from some upper benches and perhaps even more remarkably, we rem
componenttext: Sure, Trey, we'll try to wrap that up for you. As I said, we had about 1 billion of gallons of water that has found its way into our Benson quarry. Remarkably, that quarry is still operating from some upper benches and perhaps even more remarkably, we removed about half of that water from that quarry since that quarry [indiscernible] that. And all of that started hitting the Bahamas around October 6, work its way up in East Coast. Looking at process volume impacts, I got to tell you, it's hard to sort that out. But here's the way that I would encourage you to think about it. If we look over the last several years, in October, in the markets or the divisions that were affected by the storm, what we typically see for traditional workday of volumes that could be going to those markets of about 200,000 tons. So if we're starting to clock on October 6 from Matthew hit the Bahamas and consider there a lot of communities in eastern North Carolina that are still very much dealing with the storm and its aftereffects. The range of volumes could be in that 2 million-ton-ish type of framework. And again, these represent about 30% of a typical October volume from those affected areas. So it's hard to put science to it, Trey, but again, we try to look at that sort out what we believe the affect will be, and we think that's not a bad way to think about it. You've raised a very good point, and that is October is an important month. It's an important month for the aggregates industry, it's an important month for Martin Marietta because typically, you have what we're seeing here in North Carolina today. It's temperate, it's dry and clearly Matthew did not permit us to start the month under that normal recipe. But that's how we handicap it right now, Trey. Did that help?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, that was helpful. And then we definitely been seeing volatility in non-res starts recently. Could you talk about how you look at this, how you look at the starts data, the choppiness we've been seeing there this year? And what that means
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, that was helpful. And then we definitely been seeing volatility in non-res starts recently. Could you talk about how you look at this, how you look at the starts data, the choppiness we've been seeing there this year? And what that means for you as we move into next year in your geographic markets?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll try to. I mean, we look at the starts, too. And what's odd, Trey, is the way that construction starts or actually the score is kept on those because the stats typically include 100% of the total cost of the project in the month of a start. So w
componenttext: Sure, I'll try to. I mean, we look at the starts, too. And what's odd, Trey, is the way that construction starts or actually the score is kept on those because the stats typically include 100% of the total cost of the project in the month of a start. So what happens in the stats is it completely ignores the construction spending covers the period of months or years after the start. So here's what happened with those. If we look at the first half of 2015, my recollection is there's around 13 different projects across the United States valued at $1 billion or more. So there was $9 billion LNG project in Texas, there was an $8.5 billion petrochem plant in Louisiana and I think there were 2 different office starts in New York that in excess of $3.5 billion. By contrast, if you roll forward, take a look of 2016, and you're looking even from the January to July period as opposed to 13 in the previous year, there were only 4 valued at $1 billion or more. But here's what happens, as 2016 progress, you see a growing number of those large projects reach the start stage, and you see the delta in starts suddenly start to close. So as we're sitting here looking at 2016, total construction starts in '16 are estimated to be up 1% to let's call it up 676 billion. But they're expected to grow an additional 5% in 2017. So again, as we're looking at this year that I think has been impacted by a number of very different issues relative to weather, relative to the timing of starts, number one, we're not concerned about what we've seen this year; and number two, as we're looking at both the forecasters are seeing relative to nonres next year, again, this part of what gives us the confidence that I tried to portray in my opening comments.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Last one for me. I know you guys are getting into a lot of detail here on '17. But it does sound like you're looking for all of your end markets to be up next year. Can you talk about maybe high-level how we should be thinking about things as far
componenttext: Got it. Last one for me. I know you guys are getting into a lot of detail here on '17. But it does sound like you're looking for all of your end markets to be up next year. Can you talk about maybe high-level how we should be thinking about things as far as relative strength geographically and also markets that might be challenging next year for you? And then kind of with that, the timing of the FAST Act and then the tough comps in 1Q, how we should be thinking about kind of the cadence as we look into next year?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, thank you. Trey, I'll tell you what I do. I'll go through what I usually don't do on this call and try to give you an overview what we're seeing on a market-by-market basic. Before I jump into that, I don't want to tag under what you just said. And
componenttext: Sorry, thank you. Trey, I'll tell you what I do. I'll go through what I usually don't do on this call and try to give you an overview what we're seeing on a market-by-market basic. Before I jump into that, I don't want to tag under what you just said. And here's what I'll say in that regard. Q3 last year set a high bar for Q3 this year. And volume didn't equal for what we did last year, profitability exceeded what we did last year. Equally, people need to remember the construction industry across the U.S. is going to have a very difficult Q1 compare. We had remarkably warm and dry weather compared basis last year or this year in Q1 which means the entire industry is going to have a tougher comp in Q1 next year. Remember what we've always said, too in a lot of years, the last 2 weeks of March, either make or break the first quarter. So I would caution people just to think about that from a rational perspective as we go into the year. If I look at our business in summary fashion and go from west to east and start in the Rocky Mountain division, I would tell you the economic outlook there continues to be very good, private sector growth remains strong. We're putting a lot of energy to work in that marketplace. The DOT program in Colorado is very healthy. In fact, one of the biggest issues CDOT has is having enough bidders on different project. The only real headwind is this division are ballast volumes and we talked about that and clearly they've been affected as the railroads have had more issues relative to energy throughout the year. They're profitable. The outlook I think it's excellent. The ready-mix business is performing at a very high level as is there paving business. One thing that I think it's important to say about that business is I think they're in relatively early innings as far as maturity. I don't think there even stretchy getting Colorado. Midwest, if really we're talking in that context about Iowa, Nebraska, Minnesota. This is absolutely been our most consistent market. Their downs are not very low and their ups are really very steady. Presently, Iowa, which is our largest market in the Midwest, is going absolutely in all cylinders as we go into 2017. We think there will be more DOT money flowing through. We think there's a continuing positive nonres outlook in that marketplace driven by data center activity that continues. And the other thing that we're seeing and this has been a story that you heard about several years ago which you're going to higher here about it more for the next several years, it's reinvigorated wind farm market. And those are very, very aggregates intensive. The other piece of that market that strikes me as really quite good is they have a very healthy residential market. So the only headwind we have in the Midwest is you are seeing lower farm net incomes. When to give you a sense of it, we're watching that move from several years ago at about $80,000 to more like $18,000. I mean, that's a big fall. What I would tell you, too, is 15 or 20 years ago, our market in that marketplace would absolutely positively fall at Ag and that's not what is doing here today. And again, I would say that marketplace is similar to Colorado. I think it's probably in the sixth inning type phase. The Southwest in cement, you've really got to divide to a degree. You've got a North Texas economy that absolutely remains one of the best in the nation. Infrastructure is very strong. We talked about the fact that res is leading the nation as is nonres. The bulk of the I-35 corridor remains very, very positive from Dallas to San Antonio and San Antonio. And what you're seeing in pricing there to us is predictable but a very good story. I think one of the issues that they're going to have in North Texas is finding enough people to do the work, and I'm not talking about us, I'm talking about more contractor, subcontractors, material suppliers and others. I think as you look at that market in North Dallas, it's going to be tight next year. And frankly, our volumes which were very high, into this year are even higher from a backlog perspective going into next year. I think if you give a little bit farther South in Texas, clearly, Houston is feeling the effects of an energy downturn. And we have seen some of that in our business. I think it's important to remember as you think about Houston and Texas overall, 45% of our aggregates volume are in Dallas, 30% are in Central Texas and San Antonio and Austin. About 15% are in Houston. So do we feel some headwinds in Houston? We do. From our perspective, that's not really the big driver of our business. So again, we think that's likely to be a good, steady, stable marketplace. Remember, TxDOT is going to have a of healthy budget, we believe, for the next decade and about 50% of our volumes in Texas find their way to some form of TxDOT. Here's the important piece of it, Trey, and that is what we're seeing as we come across the Mississippi. Because the mid-Atlantic, which really encompasses North Carolina, Virginia and South Carolina is much healthier. We're seeing volumes up in that marketplace. We think we're going to continue to see volumes up in that marketplace. It's notable to see that in Boulder, Colorado today, a handful of years after 500-year of flooding, they still have $35 million that they're putting to flood repair in Boulder, Colorado today. That gives you some sense of a type of investment, I think, we're likely to see not for 1 year or 2, but maybe for the better part of a decade and parts of the Eastern North Carolina. There are considerable parts of I-95 that were literally underwater, and that's clearly not a good thing for highways from our perspective, we think there's going to have a lot of maintenance repair there. As we look at the Southeast and Georgia and Florida, those are 2 of the best economies in the United States today. Plenty of room to grow in the Atlanta market and part of what we're seeing as we believe we're going to see much more work along I-4 next year. I-4 was [indiscernible] from about 6 months worth of delays this year, so again if we looking at where parts of the country are as far as innings are concerned, I think that's one is probably in the third or fourth inning. And finally in the mid-east, which is really what we have in Indianapolis and Ohio and West Virginia. In Ohio, West Virginia is having a tough time. I mean, I think that's a fair observation. Energy has made that market tough. At the same time, as we look at what's going on in Indianapolis today, it has been, and it continues to be a very stable market. Good infrastructure work, better asphalt and better ready-mixed concrete work in that market that we've seen for a while, and we have seen a remarkable absorption on warehousing space and that marketplace. So as we look at that, it's probably deeper in the innings. I would give that probably a seventh inning from a deepness perspective. But that gives you your march literally from east to west or west to east, I suppose, and a sense of where we are in each one of those. I'm sorry for how long that was, but I do think that's important march.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Kathryn Thompson from Thomson Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Kathryn Thompson from Thomson Research.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: A two-part Texas question. First, to give you a little bit more color on your Central Texas acquisition. And then second, can you just maybe give more color on project delays that you discussed in the quarter? How much do you believe are driven more by we
componenttext: A two-part Texas question. First, to give you a little bit more color on your Central Texas acquisition. And then second, can you just maybe give more color on project delays that you discussed in the quarter? How much do you believe are driven more by weather or share project size, to make a project size. Is there something else we should take into consideration for those project delays in Texas?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kathryn. Let's talk a little bit about the acquisition that we've made. We purchased the remaining portion of Ratliff ready-mix. Ratliff is a company that TXI historically had a joint venture relationship with. So this is something that's been on th
componenttext: Sure, Kathryn. Let's talk a little bit about the acquisition that we've made. We purchased the remaining portion of Ratliff ready-mix. Ratliff is a company that TXI historically had a joint venture relationship with. So this is something that's been on the radar for a while. We picked up about 1.1 million cubic yards, they got 23 plants. And really, it's in that Golden triangle, Kathryn, it's on the I-35 and I-45 corridor. So if you're looking at that's really in a couple of tranches. You're  looking between DFW and Austin, and you're looking between DFW and college station. So that actually fixed an important niche for us in Texas. And as we come back to your question on delays. Our primary delays are going to be in North Texas. As you may recall, in Q2, with half year, we had indicated that we came into 2016 with about a 3.5 million ton backlog of TxDOT work and only 600,000 tons is shipped against the backlog. What I would tell you is that, again, in Q3, there was very limited activity of those projects. But we did start to see some move later in the quarter. And here's one way to think about your question more color. North Texas project delays, we got 20 major projects there in the backlog. One dating back, Kathryn, to fall of 2012, 4 finally started in September 2016, and 3 began in October 2016. 8 of the 20 have not yet begun shipping, and we have an infrastructure backlog now of about 5.4 million tons. The other thing that's important for you to glean is TxDOT has hired several hundred additional people, and we think that's of the moment. And we think that's a moment because I think there's a clear understanding within TxDOT that what they're faced with our administrative delays. We think that they are eager to remove those. So I think we will see nice movement of that in 2017. As I said, what we've seen in 2016 in Texas has been an anomaly relative to that DOT. It hasn't necessarily been that much of an anomaly relative to other state's DTOs, but it has been relative to Texas. So I tried to help on Ratliff and give you the additional color in North Texas, in particular. Is that response helpful, Kathryn?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does help. Just one follow up and I believe you answered in a previous Q&A. But we were thinking about Hurricane Matthew, how to frame it. Really, wanted to get a better sense of similarity to our differences that you're experiencing in Florida. O
componenttext: Yes, it does help. Just one follow up and I believe you answered in a previous Q&A. But we were thinking about Hurricane Matthew, how to frame it. Really, wanted to get a better sense of similarity to our differences that you're experiencing in Florida. Obviously there's a lot of flooding in Matthew but this was something that was unique about Colorado that Matthew the type wouldn't necessarily be as good as of proxy?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not particularly. In fact, what I would tell you is the flooding hit the Rockies than it had someplace to fall flow. The difference is this, flooding was coming back in rivers, and it was -- so you had rivers backing up in Eastern North Carolina, an
componenttext: We're not particularly. In fact, what I would tell you is the flooding hit the Rockies than it had someplace to fall flow. The difference is this, flooding was coming back in rivers, and it was -- so you had rivers backing up in Eastern North Carolina, and then had rain in western North Carolina finding its way to the East and it simply stayed there, and it stayed there for very long time and study my commentary. We're going to go into the holiday season and still have people look in shelters in Eastern North Carolina. So my sense is, Kathryn, that from an impacted dollar and cents perspective going forward, it's likely to be more impactful in eastern North Carolina than it was in Colorado.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, helpful. Just for you Cement business and understanding it's primarily Texas business. But could you -- there have been some a few changes in the competitive marketplace in Texas. How has this impacted pricing in the near term? How it impacted in th
componenttext: Okay, helpful. Just for you Cement business and understanding it's primarily Texas business. But could you -- there have been some a few changes in the competitive marketplace in Texas. How has this impacted pricing in the near term? How it impacted in the midterm? And any other color on your thoughts on overall capacity utilization as we look forward to '17 and '18?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I would say is several fold, Kathryn. As we look at the Texas market, you still have a target that's broadly sold that. Let's start with the notion that you still don't have enough domestic production to meet domestic needs. Clearly there ha
componenttext: I guess, what I would say is several fold, Kathryn. As we look at the Texas market, you still have a target that's broadly sold that. Let's start with the notion that you still don't have enough domestic production to meet domestic needs. Clearly there has been some sort of transactions, South Texas and [indiscernible], we understand it's not important material into used in any more. At the same time, what I would say, Kathryn, is we see 2 different things back to your point. Our Texas Cement business isn't primarily in Texas, it's wholly in Texas, and that's all we have. What we're seeing in the low hand is a very healthy market and what we're seeing their relative to volumes and what we're seeing relative to price is pretty good place. Volumes and price at hundred have been more challenge at the same time, what we have certainly spoke and our customers about is an $8 a ton price increase next year, and we have some confidence around that. So that's where we are looking at that marketplace for next year. And we feel good about where we are, Kathryn.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I'm going to get out of Texas and maybe head to another region. Just love to get a little bit of color on the primary drivers for you Mid-America Group margin expansion.
componenttext: Great. And I'm going to get out of Texas and maybe head to another region. Just love to get a little bit of color on the primary drivers for you Mid-America Group margin expansion.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's happening there is, we're just getting some our volume, Kathryn. I mean, the cost structure is good, but they're simply getting more volume. The North Carolina lost about 40% of its volume from peak to trough. So what's happening is you got Charlot
componenttext: What's happening there is, we're just getting some our volume, Kathryn. I mean, the cost structure is good, but they're simply getting more volume. The North Carolina lost about 40% of its volume from peak to trough. So what's happening is you got Charlotte market that's relatively healthy. You've a Charlotte South Carolina market that's relatively healthy. You've got a Raleigh market that's getting healthier, and it is seeing more infrastructure work in the Triad than we've seen for years. So when you're continuing to get good pricing in that marketplace, in large part that's what we're seeing, and you're adding even incremental volume to it, it's very powerful. That goes back to that notion, Kathryn, as the East begins to recover, is disproportionately impactful to our business. The southeast is important that candidly, portions of the mid-Atlantic are even more important than that.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Kathryn, just to give you some context, we saw that the Aggregates volume was down for the whole quarter for the company as a whole. We actually saw volume activity up in double digits in those areas at the mid-Atlantic.
componenttext: And Kathryn, just to give you some context, we saw that the Aggregates volume was down for the whole quarter for the company as a whole. We actually saw volume activity up in double digits in those areas at the mid-Atlantic.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ward, can you talk about the price increases actions that you've announced to the market or thinking about for Aggregates for 2017. You, in past, spoken about the need to structurally price the markets in Colorado, Texas and Florida, and I'm wondering if
componenttext: Ward, can you talk about the price increases actions that you've announced to the market or thinking about for Aggregates for 2017. You, in past, spoken about the need to structurally price the markets in Colorado, Texas and Florida, and I'm wondering if you're announcing any price increases there to tick up 2017 on that path?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll give you much better guidance on that when we come out in February, our full year results and give you real forecast for '17 at that time. I think what you've heard us say in the past though is completely fair way for you to think about it. And by t
componenttext: We'll give you much better guidance on that when we come out in February, our full year results and give you real forecast for '17 at that time. I think what you've heard us say in the past though is completely fair way for you to think about it. And by that, I mean, we see consistent, good pricing across the enterprise, yes. Will you see the Western United States on a percentage basis outperform the east? Yes, I think you will. And will we continue to see Colorado get better? I think the answer to that is yes. And part of what candidly I love about this last quarter, that's exactly what you saw. I mean, those are commentary very consistent views that we've been operating for a couple of years. And as you recall, we said probably 2 years ago, guys it's coming in Colorado just give it time and here, you finally saw it in this quarter. So what I would say is we'll give you more color on that in February. But if you just stick with that general theme, you're going to be fine.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the guidance for the year for the Aggregates product line just make sure I understand your comments around cadence you mentioned the tough compare the first quarter of '17. I think the implied guidance for fourth quarter volumes is year-ov
componenttext: And in terms of the guidance for the year for the Aggregates product line just make sure I understand your comments around cadence you mentioned the tough compare the first quarter of '17. I think the implied guidance for fourth quarter volumes is year-over-year growth, so it sounds like we've lapped a bunch of the weather headwinds and I just want to confirm that triangulation of the path is correct so fourth quarter volumes up year-over-year and then we'll see how the first quarter plays out when comps are tough?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jerry, I think you got it.
componenttext: Jerry, I think you got it.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in terms of the downstream business, you had a really nice positive revision fit to the gross profit outlook for the year. I would imagine the acquisition. But can you talk about the organic improvement in unit margins and what are the drivers?
componenttext: Okay. And in terms of the downstream business, you had a really nice positive revision fit to the gross profit outlook for the year. I would imagine the acquisition. But can you talk about the organic improvement in unit margins and what are the drivers?

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. What I would say is clearly some of that is going to be acquisition. Most of it is what we're doing with our internal business. And here's the way that's working, Jerry. I'm in our asphalt and paving business in Colorado is a very good business, and
componenttext: Sure. What I would say is clearly some of that is going to be acquisition. Most of it is what we're doing with our internal business. And here's the way that's working, Jerry. I'm in our asphalt and paving business in Colorado is a very good business, and they continue to see nice year-over-year improvement in that marketplace. Our ready-mixed concrete business in Colorado is a good, solid, mature ready-mixed concrete business. Here's what's happening: We said that you should expect our ready-mixed concrete business in Texas to continue to get better. And over time, you should see that performing the way that we seeing our business in Colorado perform. And if you look at that business, that's what's happening. The cost structure  is better, we see much better pricing activity in that business of. And here's the other piece we're seeing there. You're seeing some headwinds aggregate volume because you got more brand-new projects in parts of Texas, and you have to be working with wet soils. But when you got concrete and some other gets to be on more industrial or more mature type projects, concrete can actually goes. Here's the odd thing. We were seeing internal aggregates to our ready-mix business actually better in third quarter. We're seeing stone going down on road projects coming down in the third quarter, but tells me the underlying business is good. But what you're seeing in Q3 on the downstream businesses is just the better performance that we were expecting to see.

componenttext: I guess, what I would say is this, I mean, we're looking right now I a record backlog in Texas. And TxDOT has committed to at least $66 billion over the next 10 years. So keep in mind, Craig, even when prop 1 was at its absolute the spending from 2010 to 2015, this fiscal years for Texas was trending at about $5.2 billion, if we're looking at it right now, Prop 1 and Prop 7 should provide about $2.5 billion by 2018, rising to $3.1 billion by 2021. So if we're sitting here right now, we're looking at what we feel like it's going to be probably a plus $7 billion program in 2017, very healthy on the out years, going into the year with some of the largest backlogs that we've ever had. So again, we're looking at TxDOT and looking it at a marketplace that 50% of our volume finds its way into infrastructure that we feel very confident both in the near term and the long-term there. Undoubtedly, Texas DOT is going to find its way through these administrative delays. That's one reason I want to give the metric that I did early in the dialogue about the fact that they've hired several hundred more employees.

componenttextpreview: Ballast is sold out. If we look at where ballast is, I mean, clearly, the Class 1 railroads with what they're not moving relative to energy is pretty considerably off. And what I would say is the railroads have done what you would expect nature major indu
componenttext: Ballast is sold out. If we look at where ballast is, I mean, clearly, the Class 1 railroads with what they're not moving relative to energy is pretty considerably off. And what I would say is the railroads have done what you would expect nature major industrial company do and that is they pulled back on maintenance and repair and at the end of the day, you can only do that for so long. And what I would say is we're not going to see a host of other people come in and put quarries on rail to meet that demand. We're going to be there, we're going to be ready for it, they're very good customers of ours, we will supply their needs and they're going to have some needs but from a ballast perspective right now, it is one of the more challenged areas of our business. I guess, the good news, it's one of smaller areas of our business.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have not seen a remarkable snap back yet. But what's remarkable to me is you do see more just early, early, early activity once it starts peaking over 50. I can tell you, the energy companies are really hoping it gets to about 65. I think if you see oi
componenttext: We have not seen a remarkable snap back yet. But what's remarkable to me is you do see more just early, early, early activity once it starts peaking over 50. I can tell you, the energy companies are really hoping it gets to about 65. I think if you see oil get to about 65 level, you're going to see pretty good activity there. So in the back of our mind, that's really a marker that we have. But if I told you we were seeing much right now, that wouldn't be correct.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I would say, Garik. What we talked about was averages, right? And we said when we saw our volume fall 80 million tons, we thought that for the first 40 million tons of recovery in our heritage business, we would see it on average, it's 60% i
componenttext: I guess, what I would say, Garik. What we talked about was averages, right? And we said when we saw our volume fall 80 million tons, we thought that for the first 40 million tons of recovery in our heritage business, we would see it on average, it's 60% incremental margin. And clearly, that's what we're seeing less, we're seeing plus that. Here's what's happening. You're getting the incremental margin boost because you're seeing a shift to more of the east. And again, Garik, that's something that we've been very transparent on, and we've spoken about for years because we said we couldn't even hit the 60 all by itself if we were just counting on the Western recovery all by itself. So if you believe as I do that we're in early innings in the Southeast and in relatively early innings in the mid-Atlantic, then I think we're going to be certainly above that target as we said. Now I think we're going to show up every quarter with 90%? I'd like to say that I thought we would, but I think that will be a little bit ambitious so I'm not encouraging you to go and model that. But I think if you just come back think about that average on 60 and keep in mind, pricing is probably doing better than we thought it was going to do as we went to the cycle. So maybe at last, although a little bit longer than we thought it would from we said at first 40 million tons. So I would tell you, it has the capacity to endure. I think geographic mix is our friend. Clearly, pricing has been our friend and our cost profile is very attractive. So I think we remain pretty resilient around that.

componenttext: Great, good news. This is kind of more hypothetical, but lots of discussion out there right now about some form of physical stimulus. componenttext: That's hard to say. I mean, I think you could go back over usual highway bill and look at the rhythm and cadence of that and say it takes probably 18 months for something really to start finding its way in a meaningful fashion. So I wouldn't expect it to be immediate, but I would expect it to be pretty impactful to our business if that happens. I think one of the big issues that we need to keep in mind is looking at employment across the United States and sorting out those which that even we put this thing like I said, it going to be put workers out there who could put that down. And the good news is somewhat Marietta stays you think the can very much up and write that. But here's purpose different than I think Stanley, and it's a clear recurring theme that we're hearing from contractors and that is there busy, and they haven't done in higher a bunch of new people to come to work for them because they're busy. If they've got a heavy financial incentive to go and accelerating project, they will. If they have a strong financial disincentive to get something done, they'll follow that as well. But the it think there are a lot of contractors who are just as busy as they want to be, they're making good money, they don't want to over extend their businesses and if the don't have good multi-year backlogs and just continue to work back in '17, '18, '19 and '20, I think they're very pleased with that. And if you're seeing what we did in this quarter with down volume, if we see just good, steady, slow volume in this business based on the enterprise that we built, I think it's very powerful. And I think additional stimulus from who ever the next President is could be a very powerful in this business. Do think it's a '17 event? No. Do I think it could be a mid-'18 event? Yes, probably so.

componenttext: No, we are. But here's the way I would think if I were you, Brent, the West already seeing that happening to a degree much more than the East has. So in my prepared commentary, I think I mentioned Austin is one of those. But what you heard was I also said Atlanta and I said Charlotte and I said places like Raleigh. So now we're seeing the Eastern United States go through that same transition frankly, that we saw the Western U.S. do in 18 or 24 months ago. So directly to your point, if we're building a multifamily facility, really, it's going to take stone in the basin concrete is going to go to the fast it continues subdivision work until those roads and streets are accepted by a local municipality for maintenance, everything that we're selling on the roads, everything that we're selling on the sidewalks, everything that we're selling on the utilities, everything that we're selling on the lot counts as residential. So when we see that type of turn hitting a city like Charlotte right now and Atlanta right now and Charlotte right now. By the way, Austin and very early stages of that, it is much more aggregate intensive, and we think it's much more powerful.

componenttext: I believe the best is yet to come in that state. Remember a couple of things here. One, they had the tax initiative that referred to as T Plus. And by the way, that's what we thought '16 was going to be. And we think we'll likely to see more of that in the early phases in North Georgia, Reid Atlanta than in South Georgia. So I think you take is right, Brent.

componenttext: Yes, I guess, what I would say is we're looking to grow our business in places that we have good leading positions on, and we can value enhancing acquisitions. The other thing that I will tell you is if you're looking at Texas and how that state is going to grow between now and 2050, you're going to have 70% of the population in Texas living in the Golden Triad. And remember when you're looking at that, you're looking at a space the sun has Pennsylvania anyway, and we will have, and we do have the leading position in that marketplace. That said, do we want to grow in the Eastern U.S.? You bet we do. Are we looking to transaction potentially there? We certainly are. componenttext: Relative to transfer pricing yes, relative to transfer pricing Mike, we transfer pricing. So to answer that directly to. And relative to the share buybacks, what I can tell yes, yes we have this bad habit we joke about we try to do exactly what we said we're going to do. And we take back what we said, we want to maintain that debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 2x, but we've also said that our first priority are doing the right transactions. So if you look at where we ended the quarter and if you look at the transaction that with it and if you look at where it left our ratio, it was exactly where we said we wanted to be. So what I would tell you is if people are listening to our words, there should be no surprise in that. So that was the driver of the lack of share buybacks in Q3.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, again, for joining our third quarter 2016 earnings call. We are excited about the future of Martin Marietta, and we are in a very advantageous position through our superior geographic locations and markets that continue to experience strong employ
componenttext: Thanks, again, for joining our third quarter 2016 earnings call. We are excited about the future of Martin Marietta, and we are in a very advantageous position through our superior geographic locations and markets that continue to experience strong employment growth. The favorable construction outlook with significant pricing opportunities still to come will benefit this company for many years. Martin Marietta's focused execution of its strategic plan should provide a firm foundation to enhance long-term shareholder value. We very much look forward to discussing our full year results with you in February. Thank you for your time and support of Martin Marietta.
